review_title: Marketing Manager
job_title: Senior Marketing Manager in New York, NY
pros: Trying to reinvent themselves from a marketing standpoint, but doing it slowly.  Large, impressive brand to have on a resume.
cons: Salary is below average. They set salary guidelines but the majority of employees fall below that salary and there is no room for negotiation.  At the manager and Sr. manager level you are overworked with little work-life balance.  There is a very selfish culture of wanting to move up quickly, so a lot of the leadership are inexperienced and lack real leadership or mentorship skills.  The biggest con is the constant re-org and restructuring and tons of layoffs in the process.  I was an employee for 4 years and cant remember one year where they weren't laying people off. It creates a very stressful, unpleasant and selfish work environment. Also-terrible health benefits

review_title: Small Business Customer Care Professional (Home Based Servicing)
pros: Excellent  Pay.. Worked from home. Excellent  bonus potential based on sales goals All equipment is provided and they will setup business acct for internet service in your home (only for company use). Lots of training and team oriented.
cons: Very stressful job. Although you are hired in customer service , you are not told that your primary goal is sales. Extremely heavy selling is required. Pressured to sometimes be dishonest to customers you can't help so you won't get a bad survey. It pushes angry customer to next rep when they call in.   Wasn't pleased with health insurance deductibles, quite expensive. IIn cst survey, cst can be pleased with you but upset with Amex and you take the hit. Not cool. Not what I expected from a top employer.

review_title: analyst
job_title: Financial Analyst in West Valley City, UT
pros: Not many. Can work from home, salt lake location is just off freeway. People are really hard working and dedicated to doing their jobs well.
cons:
Where do I start! They care more about outsourcing to India than keeping there American workforce and working with India it difficult at best mostly due to their hours and They contract the India workforce so the people come and go on a project so you get sub-par quality.

Most people are on pins and needles about when/if their jobs are going to be outsourced. In the short time i  there have been there, there have been 3 rounds of "reorganizations" and now the layoff

They use excel a lot and need  to update their programs! When they build in-house applications they seem to only meet half the needs of their customers. Their IT acts as if it is a different company from the rest of the group and is extremely difficult to work with.

Your merits are based on a curve! There will always be a winner and a looser! all the managers meet at the end of the year to determine how well you did, this will determine your raise. depending how forthcoming your manager is you may fall below or above the curve, in other words your manager has little say in your raise.

review_title: Stimulating and challenging
pros: As a whole a very good organization to work for if you are full time permanent. Always an opportunity to upgrade oneself and move around in various opportunities if one desires to. This organization is also extremely good at organizing and supporting various community causes and events - ie giving back to the community.
cons: On a whole, a great place for, so no downsides to report. To note, many are contractors both within and outside of North America and though they are hard working and contributing members, the one downside is not retaining all that knowledge within the organization when contracts not renewed for long term contractors or switching to another or cheaper provider of contracted resources.

review_title: Great place to work though salaries are well below market
pros: Great international experience working with people across the globe and potential for travel. Interesting work, colleagues are great on a whole plus really good work-life balance with good opportunities for flexible working
cons:
Not a lot of career progression in the UK as most senior jobs are in the USA and a lot of functions have been outsourced to Phoenix or India. If you want to go past Manager, then you'll have to wait a VERY long time or move abroad.

Pay lags around significantly not just vs. financial services but London at a whole. This is compensated by the work-life balance.

A lot of decisions are made from the States and tend to be US-centric. A lot central control and the regions have little autonomy. As a massive multi-national, decisions are also made VERY slowly.

review_title: Good for Some, Not for Others
pros: Great perks and benefits-on site activity center, wellness center, dental care, annual health exams, cafe, walking paths
cons:
TIGHT security. No family or friends welcome, not even for lunch. Absolutely no photos on campus. No access to any outside websites on computers. All standard stuff for a financial company, but you should be aware before you accept a job there. 

Leadership is hit or miss. You can get promoted from within, but it seems like some people get promoted based on politics and not on their skills necessarily. People get promoted into management with no background, and then are left to figure out how to be a manager. And if you're working for someone like that, you're stuck with them. They don't ask for 360 reviews, for employees to review their leaders.

review_title: Lot of hype around the brand, little to show for it once you are inside.
job_title: Manager Finance in New York, NY
pros:
Apparently a good brand name to have on your resume
In general people are nice and have good pedigree
Group leaders are, in general, very nice and do understand employee's issues including concerns around career progression and salaries
Somewhat fun culture.
Very good company to work for if you are a second earner and want to coast.
cons:
Below (read way below) average salaries and benefits
Medical benefits are extremely bad
Hard to get promoted  - only way is to post for a new position in the group or outside, which is open to everyone to post for. Just doing your job very well does't lead to progression in salary or title. 
Very employee-band concious, which level VP can talk to which level VP etc.
Very heirachical, it takes a long time to make a decision- even VP level employees have little power

review_title: Good company overall, but limited in talent development
pros: Being able to move around the company to experience different parts of the company is a huge plus. A lot of external recruiters are very interested to hear about such diverse experiences even though you have only worked for one company.
cons: The pay rate at Amex is definitely below the average in the industry, which is very unfortunate because it is pushing a lot of talent out of the company. I often see people come, and then leave the company shortly thereafter because the salary is just not competitive. Some say that the lower salary is made up by the work/life balance that employees get, but that is not true in many parts of the company. The recent restructuring of the financial analyst program also has further increased the number of hoops that you have to jump through to get promoted, as well as the time that it takes for you to get promoted. The mobility that is often viewed as positive is sometimes hard to manage correctly because it depends a lot on what roles are available when you are looking to move, which is out of your control.

review_title: Disappointed in this Brand Going downhill
pros: Base pay is ok not the greatest for the work
cons: Sales is the primary focus... Looks like they're trying to weed out U.S. reps all together and send our jobs overseas for less pay  however there is a MAJOR cultural difference and they use misleading sales tactics (BIG NO NO!)and other departments such as credit/fraud have absolutely no sense of communicating well and us US  reps basically has to clean up the mess for as much as amex charges to carry their products the service has become so disgusting to say the least, compared to our competitors which is probably why we're seeing less tenured and less loyal card members since there's really nothing that stands out anymore about this company (disappointed)

review_title: After a period of time Cons outweigh Pros
job_title: Lead Business Systems Analyst in Gurgaon, Haryana
pros:
Comfortable work environment.
Flexibility in terms of work life balance is heavily promoted although it depends on your manager.
Structured performance review process.
A lot of internal job postings happen on a lateral level. Comparatively few promotions.
lot of opportunities for employees to upgrade their skills even at an interdepartmental level.
Employees are hardworking and determined achievers
cons:
Salary structure is on the lower side compared to other companies of the same level.
Technology is outdated compared to industry standards but the level of service and performance expected is extremely high.
Most compensation related issues are brushed under the carpet by the HR and management 
Vast gap in the treatment of Operations and support functions.
Company Loyalty is not considered as a trait as HR prefers hiring new inexperienced candidates from external sources at higher packages than promoting internal candidates due to which there is high attrition rate of experienced and potentially loyal employees.
Office politics is not discouraged and inter departmental politics is high.

review_title: Take this warning seriously
pros: 18+/hr starting - WAH positions available
cons: Where to start. The training isn't organized and is hard to follow. No real examples of what the job entails. You learn as you go and fill in the blanks from talking to other confused colleagues. Not all but a good bit of Team Leads are rude and short with you. Asking questions will be hard because the department is run on a teach yourself attitude. Condescending leadership. Everything you do effects their bonuses so many are not friendly. I literally have only worked here 8 months and already looking for new employment. Working here has taken my 5+ years in travel and made me re think my degree and life choices. Lol. The customers are absolutely rude and treat you like servants. Ofcourse their are a few that aren't but most will rush you and demand the moon. There's so much more. Just make sure to take the things you may be reading seriously into account. Most of it is true. I looked at Glassdoor before my start and didn't take the things I saw seriously. I fully regret that now. I'm depressed and it's time to go.

review_title: Overall Great Company to work for!
job_title: Customer Care in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
training
money
lots of easy bonuses
10 hour shifts
plenty of overtime
on site health care
on site gym
dental services every other week that come to the business
on site cafeteria 
great leadership
great coworkers
plenty of feedback for improvement
cons:
The only real cons are the system they use for scheduling, there are much better ones out there but it's almost like they chose the most confusing one possible so that tons of mistakes will be made, and people will their jobs over mistakes, I saw a lot of that.

Also the sick leave is insane. You get plenty of vacation time, but that has to be scheduled, and for sick leave if you take more than 3 sick days in a year, you are automatically fired, and no one in management can stop that. I just wish they gave you the chance to take sick days, then maybe make them up on other scheduled days off or something, because if you need to take a sick day, then you it's not likely to be scheduled.

review_title: If you like sales, this is the job for you
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Pay was decent and benefits too
cons: Things really changed when Amex lost the Costco account.  It because a sales job first, and customer service second.  The supervisors didn't care about anything except sales, sales, sales. If a customer called in to dispute a charge, pay a bill, ask a question, the rep was expected to make a sale somewhere during the call. The metrics were impossible. Once Amex lost the Costco account, they were scrambling to keep customers. It was sad.  I asked in my initial interview if this was a sales job, and was told it was not. Within 2 years, it was a sales job.  Very little training, but they had such high expectations that it was impossible to meet them.  I had such high hopes for this company, but they because just another credit card company, and nothing special.

review_title: Was a great place to work - needs to get its act together again.
pros: Great people (those who continue to survive the illogical purges of the last year plus), no dearth of challenges within the tech environment to keep the job interesting, reasonable compensation levels in Phoenix.
cons: Going through significant restructuring, under tremendous pressure (post Costco and other high profile partnerships falling through over the last year) from Wall Street to get back to real growth with viable strategy to stay relevant for the long term. The organization is obviously struggling to get there. Immensely political environment at this point in time, especially at middle management and above levels.

review_title: No Change...
pros: Flexible working, cultural diversity, great training resources and programs, supporting local communities. Opportunities are great to learn, develop yourself and connect with wider global network.
cons: Innovation is limited due to size and complex structure of the organisation, reengineering is constant with huge obsession for cost savings and ongoing lack of focus on revenue growth. Management knows well how to play with the numbers to deliver on short term targets. Unfortunately "change" does not last long due to the same old politics and US centrism. Senior executives seem somehow very comfortable and even not trying hard to lead by example. Career progress is dependant on networking and superficial requirements on how you need to fit in the corp institution. Leaders look very robotic and out of touch.

review_title: Great if you want to have work life balance but...
pros:
The brand itself is a great one with its huge loyal base of charge cards (gold, green and platinum). The brand has a positive image and is know for outstanding customer service. 

 The work life balance is great especially for women. The paid time off is 4 weeks, pretty good by industry standards. Add to it the flex days, sick days and multiple fun events during the year, and it's a pretty decent life you get.  You will find good natured people throughout company and you may not see as much back biting.

A few years in American Express can add much to your resume. And the opportunities to work in diverse fields and internationally  add much to the value.
cons: The brand relies too much on the loyal customer base it has held for some time. The value proposition of an American Express Card for youth is debatable, especially charge cards. The more recent exposure to credit cards may cause some problems.

review_title: 15 years in the International card business
pros: Incredible blue chip company that historically has always made the changes necessary to reinvent itself while consistently maintaining and promoting its core values. Strong levels of integrity throughout the organization. Fairly transparent internal job market, with opportunities to move across countries, functions and lines of business. Great developer of talent, driven by lean staffing levels, which increases exposure and accountability. Genuinely nice people. Warm and fuzzy culture. Very easy to build a long-term career there, and many people historically have.
cons: Highly consensual approach tends to slow action and decision-making. Building strong internal networks critical to getting things done. Difficult to take risks without executive sponsorship. Performance management process overly time-consuming/bureaucratic and not as meritocratic as it pretends to be. Executive sponsorship critical for a advancement to senior levels. Moving to a GE-style approach to talent management.

review_title: Surprised that it's the "Best Place to Work"
pros: Work environment depends entirely on team and manager. In other teams, people had work life balance
cons:
However, in my team, it was a hellish work environment. My boss used to berate and abuse her "chosen" subordinates publicly. Every 6 months she would single out an "underperforming " subordinate who would take the fall for her incompetence. She would explicitly order us to work on weekends, and we resisted she would shout personal insults to us. 

I didn't get any recognition despite working many weekends and outside office hours on the explicit command of my manager.

I thought that this is a one off case of a poor manager in a good company. However, I have seen her shielded by her bosses, and that has made  me lose faith in the company. 

I wish the person who had referred me been honest about my old boss and the company values. I would have done anything other than join this company.

I had to undergo a classic case of workplace harassment and bullying. I considered filing a court case but in the end I didn't because I didn't have the resources to fight a case for years.

Also, in general, it is a sycophantic culture.

review_title: No communications between groups like HR and the rest of the firm
job_title: Planning Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Good work-life balance, can work home on Fridays and some days during the week. Taking vacation is easy
cons: HR does not know what other groups are doing (ei. What the groups bonus policy). The company is very rigid, you are not up for promotion until you are in your position for 18 months and even then you have to interview for the position against other canditates. Compensation is below market and anyone who is not a manager or above (band 35 or higher) does not get a bonus even if you doing a managers job. It is very hard to move from one group to another (Global travel to consumer cards to loyalty programs). The health benefits are horrible and vacation time is good but the total number of days off are less than what they say - they include holidays so if they tell you 23 days off its really only 14, 9 days are holidays.

review_title: Great Company, but poor lower level management.
pros: The benefits are excellent, the income potential also is excellent, the company does make sure that you are well aware of the tasks that needs to be fulfilled.
cons: The company has really taken a step back, it used to be strong in how it operates and how they deal with talented employees and customer service reps on a whole.  The company has taken a severe step back and are now more willing to outsource to save a penny than be loyal to their long standing agents, some who have been with the company for well over 30 years are now being laid off. Very poor company for agents at this point and it will continue to go down as management are solely about profits.

review_title: It was pure sales, not much else in terms of development.
job_title: Manager of Business Development in New York, NY
pros: Smart coworkers, efficient technology and processes, work from home and great managers.  The overall Middle Market Business Development role had a respectable image in the field with customers.  Typically, customers were gracious to have a local presence from such a huge company.
cons: Working from home isn't for everyone.  Learning and help when you need it is dependent on finding someone to help you, and finding someone willing to help.  Everyone is willing, however, their time is valuable also.  The quotas are outrageous in sales roles also.  Nobody has any idea how they will reach the number, they just put their head down and pray something comes their way.

review_title: Pros and cons, mostly pro. Mostly.
job_title: Scrum Master/Senior Project Manager in Laveen, AZ
pros: Salary is great, some of the most competitive you'll ever find. Work from home options are flexible. Great credibility to your resume. You'll look like a rock star after doing your tenure. Lots of little perks like discounts, good cheap food, etc. If you're decent at your job, you'll be ensured a long tenure.
cons: It's corporate as corporate gets. Lots of oversight, hoops, and ridiculous things to steer through in terms of approvals, signoffs, etc. You'll feel like you're working in a government institution sometimes. And there's the odd little fact that most of the employees, for whatever reason, hate their jobs, even when their job isn't that bad. Also, if you're a contractor, the chances of you going permanant are slim to none, due to a truly bizarre set of rules and restrictions, and buy out clauses.

review_title: Business Analyst
pros:
1.  At one point I worked with one of the most diverse and interesting teams I've worked with in 10+ years in similar roles.  
2.  Not bad reward system and bonuses  -- blue dollars management and fellow employees can reward you with points exchangeable for gift cards and misc items for excellent performance.  It is just a nice touch.  
3.  Variety of work available if you look and fight for it.
cons:
1.  Lots of work offshore -- so not uncommon to have crazy hours.
2.  Was not impressed with technologies group.  Everything piece of software seemed to have issues, sometimes costly.
3.  Very little training provided for new skills -- expect to pick up a lot on your own.

review_title: Customer care
job_title: New Accounts Division in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: the company was a great company till about 2005 then things went down hill. over 280 hrs of pto per year or more longer you work there (When you can use it is a whole different story) Pay ok could survive on it. When started it was an employee friendly( decided the J.D. Power awards were more important at any cost by micro managing every word  said) Health Care was great once (10 years ago)
cons: NO job security. Almost all conversations have been modified to follow a script. Once they script the job it is sent to INDIA. you are always on edge wondering when your job function is next and then  trying to move to a new area when the one your in goes over seas is a popularity contest. It does not matter if you were a top performer all that matters is who you know, who you hang with after work, who you go drinking with and who you are married to with in the company. (they will make up a job for you if you fill all those areas). MAJOR NEPOTISM with in the building

review_title: Senior Engineer
pros: Technology is just 1-2 years behind the current trend. Folks at engineer levels are good techie resources but most of the coding is done by junior level folks.
cons: Too much flamboyance - engineers talks more than code. Culture is top - down - very heavy at the top(unnecessary hierarchy which is good for nobody). If your manager doesn't like you - you should be looking for a new job. Too much favoritism and relationships - it's more important whom you know rather what you know.

review_title: It's up to you how far you will grow
pros: I started at American Express as a CCP. During my 9 year employment I held 7 positions. This company allowed me to grow, learn and choose my own path to success. Don't get me wrong it's not a perfect place by any means but the company puts women and minorities on a more level playing field. They offered benefits for life partners from the beginning, held cultural events designed to teach you about the world and even brought in financial advisers to help you shape your financial future into retirement.
cons: The cons are the same at any company. There were managers/leaders that were not a good fit for their role. The systems used inside the company were not always reliable or efficient. Etc.

review_title: Your manager will shape your experience at Amex
pros: Benefits, ability to work from home, resources you'd expect from a Fortune 100 company.  Generous time off policy.  When I joined the opportunities seemed abundant.  Lots of promotions and movement in my (broader) group.  Some groups embrace work from home and other flexible options and it has no negative impact on your career progression.  Amex has lots of employee recognition opportunities and they typically have a cash award.  They maintain a very comprehensive performance management process, though aligning to a performance curve can have negative results with high performing teams.
cons: Pay tends to lag behind the market a bit, working from home will stunt your career growth, very New York-centric environment.  If your manager's career is stagnant you can expect yours to be as well.  Some opportunities are not afforded to employees if they are not in New York, regardless of their strong, documented performance.  Tend to have a significant number of reorganizations yielding lay offs.

review_title: Future?
pros: Great work/life balance.  Friendly colleagues, depending on the group you end up in.  Good benefits.  Great office location.  Good brand.
cons: A culture as rapidly moving as molasses and lethal as quicksand.  Gossip verging on back-stabbing is a norm.  Unbelievably slow and risk-averse, reflected in hiring based on capabilities rather than aptitude - and leading to stagnation.  So consensus-driven that nothing happens, and it feels like most management drive forward by checking themselves out in the vanity mirror.  Dangerous HR policies to promote certain classes of individuals actually end up encouraging leaders to hire/promote really poor candidates.

review_title: Great Place to work
pros: The atmosphere, People, Team Members, To and Fro Transport except couple of non hiring zones.
cons:
We used to get calls from Dir of Sales across the US states and trust me they were so professional and amazing unlike the upper mangers here, who kind of feel bad even replying back to your greetings. (That Sucks real bad)

You really cannot make someone a Manager if he/she has spent 5 or 6 years in the office.(I firmly believe Time Duration can never be an attribute of Promotions this just violates the sanctity of  the profile)

review_title: Travel Counselor
pros: Pretty decent pay for the work you do. Great benefits at a pretty good rate. They give you a $30 discount on your monthly premium for non smokers. A LOT of paid time off.
cons: To meet your metrics, you need to slam through your calls, one right after the other, non stop. There are always about 65 or more calls in queue, so it is usually always very busy. You also have to meet a certain percentage of surveys from the card members. This metric can get you bonuses BUT sometimes the survey will not pertain to you, it may be about another agent or department. So, if it's negative it still counts against you. They do not take that survey off. And THAT can make you not qualify for a bonus.

review_title: Barely Legal Practices
pros:
Some of the people you work with are nice 
Saying you worked for Amex goes a long way
Youll do well in the company if youre happy to trample on everyone else on the way up
cons:
In an attempt to save money amex have outsourced A LOT of their employees to Manilla/India. This has caused job layoffs in Brighton and animosity with the Brighton employees as not only do they not feel their jobs are secure, but the training of these people abroad is not adequate so we ended up taking the hit from everything.
Amex pays staff below the market average for wages across the board, unless you earn commission (which theyve even cut back on massively from customer services)
I have seen staff treated illegally and refused requests to see the occupational health dr because they werent believed, they ended up coming to work when they were unwell for fear of punishment 
Big pay differences for people doing the same job 
You are VERY disposable to them. I saw someone lose their job as there was 'no need for it', only for someone else to come into the role a few months later 
Youre expected to give up all your free time for amex

review_title: Rude to Contractors - Delayed with times
pros: They spent their money in presentation, nice people, and overall a good place for full time staff.
cons: As a former contractor and turning to full time there was one thing that bothered me so much with Amex. I have been contracted before at other companies but never experienced the separation and exclusiveness of bullying they have towards contractors. Im a manager, and they should be ashamed to do this. Contractors don’t have access to even check their emails, let alone join their networks or feel part of the organization. Oh and did I mention the “red” and “blue” ID badge. I had an analyst tell me, we hope one day you “turn” blue like us. Way to go amex. They do take care of their full time employees but the sad culture they live in on being better than contractors is caused by the company policies of Amex. Also, is a shame that people have been there 15 years and work so slow.

review_title: Its worst job
pros: Nothing to say good about company.
cons:
1)You have to generate lead , you have to close deal you have to do documentation part , you have to do customer service part ,so basically from start to end everything you do ,
2)even they dont have doc-boys , so that part also you have to do.....
3)no telesales team so lead you have to generate
4)work environment is worst, its like pressure cooker or boiler , language use by manager is pathetic, 
Offrole employee treated as dogs only.
5) incentive structure is have so many conditions so its almost impossible to get one .
6)no matter how many meetings you do you will get travelling only if card get approved.
7) actual job timing is 9 30 to 6 30 , but that on paper only ....you have to work till 9 30 moat of day
8 ) they will tell 2 sat and all sundays are off 
But once sat off they will give According to there comfort and many times on sunday also you have to work , if they feel they will send you mall and other places for sale.

So basically if you hate your health, personal life , you can join this company.

review_title: Micro-management Senior Executive, he acts more like a field general then a strategist.
job_title: Director, Business Development in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great colleagues, The directors are collaborative on the west. All directors were new to the job in 2010 and they all embrace change and worked well together.
cons: Commission plan is flawed. The quotas continue to change and the OTE for the field does not promote the correct habits. You are paid 6-8 weeks after the quarter ends.  Resources are in short supply and the operations team are short handed so you have to wait 8 weeks before you get an implementation team.  The sales ops and Sales teams are paid on two plans

review_title: Blue Box values
job_title: Specialized Travel Counselor in Tampa, FL
pros:
Great benefits and better than average pay, with great employees. 
If you are after security and a lifetime career then American Express is for you.
cons:
American Express Europe are much more pro the employee than American Express in the U.S.
If you work in a large travel call center you will be monitored from the time you walk into the building until you leave, and only allowed to move from your cubicle at times allotted by Staff Planning. Vacation time is subject to a bidding system with longest serving getting first pickings. Promotion can be subject to favoritism rather than skill and hard work.

review_title: Underpaid but fantastic atmosphere
job_title: Program Manager in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: In general, the quality of people you work with is much higher than that of other phone shops. Amex seems to care about their employees, they make a concerted effort to provide decent benefits and room for growth. They have a gym onsite, a nurse onsite, multiple game rooms stocked with consoles, ping pong tables, etc. It was a lot of fun to work here.
cons: Ultimately it will be the low wages that can divert you away from a future with the company. Unless you are lucky enough to get into a professional role and in upper management's pocket, the growth (while abundant) is slow and difficult. Given the size of the company, the competition for one-off roles is very stiff. I suppose that's good as there are many bright people working here, just too slow for my ambitions.

review_title: The worst management you will have ever worked for, period.
pros: Your last day of work
cons: Salaried employees working at the company are subject to rank and yank type performance reviews.  Management in the Financial Crimes Reporting Unit is completely inept.  They hired people managers instead of people who actually know how to do the work.  This place is ripe with favorites, if you aren't one, good luck to you.  The technology in the phoenix office is so out of date the phones look like the original prototype for avaya systems.  I could have made this shorter and just told you to picture every terrible thing you have ever experienced at an old job or your current job, roll that into one company, and that is what you get when you work for American Express in Phoenix, AZ

review_title: This is a tough gig that requires you to be sharp and present on every call.
job_title: Customer Care Professional in Sunrise, FL
pros:
A lot of pros at AMEX:

-Base Pay 
-Incentive/Commission structure (payouts)
-Employee Benefits are one of the best you’ll find 
-The Sunrise facility has a lot of nice resources such as cafeteria, lounge/game areas, fitness space, daycare, Starbucks, and concession areas
-On-site nurse, physical therapist, and more things that I’m probably not aware of.
cons: Customer service call centers are high-speed, high-stress environments and every move you make is being coded and recorded towards a compliance metric. Something as simple as taking off your headset to go to the restroom at your own discretion is not so simple at AMEX. You’re taking 50-80 calls a day and when you’re making that much contact with different people all over the country with their own issues and sass , it can be overwhelming, exhausting, and daunting.

review_title: Slightly above average company
pros: Company promotes work life balance and professional development.  As people, the employees in general are open, friendly and cheerful.  As colleagues, most employees are team oriented, friendly and helpful.  Employees openly and enthusiastically promote the company's services and products.  Company encourages hiring internally.
cons: Although the company promotes work life balance and professional development, (like most things in life) it is only as good as your leader's follow-through.  Relationships are really important, often times more important than actual performance.  Many employees are upset after their annual review because delivering on goals doesn't matter if the leadership prefers your peer.  Also if your leader isn't well liked, you won't get a good rating.  Because relationships are so important, a poor review can mean that you'll have a very hard time getting another job in the company.  Things move slowly due to consensus building, large teams and conservatism.

review_title: The only thing constant is change
pros:
- Dynamic, market driven and competitive organisation determined to remain a big player in financial services.
- Committed to invest in developing digital products and tools for consumers and businesses.
- Popular Board Leadership - Ken Chenault and his team are visionary, driven and passionate and that comes across in all of their communications.
cons:
- Focus has shifted more heavily toward the shareholder in recent years, with the employee feeling less part of a business 'family' and more a nameless commodity, albeit a reasonably paid commodity. This affects employee loyalty, commitment and enthusiasm.
- IS/IT infrastructure (especially employee intranet) is challenging to work with.
- Recent introduction of Blue Working in Servicing Centres adds to sterile/impersonal working environment.
- Flawed meritocracy due to poorly coordinated and top down commitment to goals and deliverables, reliable metrics.
- Gaps in leadership ability, quality, and credibility between the Board in New York and Regional/Local centres sometimes expose middle management.

review_title: Great company and brand
pros:
Strong base salary and car allowances paid 
Commission structure is satisfactory 
Amex offer discounted health insurance and card products 
Great people to work with 
Leverage warm leads and work strategically on new business through the many Amex business units 
Strong brand behind you
cons:
Limited work life balance at times, perception is if your not in he office your not working 
Many challenges with their processes and paperwork, need to bring in new systems/technology to change and improve 
You need to become "blue box" to make it in the company. You need to know the right people to progress your career. They don't recognise or value their committed and hard working employees so limited progression if you don't play the political game and stroke egos 
If you don't perform you will be on a performance management plan straight away

review_title: Travel Dept is terrrible!
pros: Ok salaries and can be interesting and varied  if the consultant was allowed to do their job.
cons: The environment is very oppressive in travel.  They are not loyal to their staff and are always looking to find a reason to put you on "counselling" which means you don't get your incentives.  They always come up with new rules to make sure you don't get your incentives and always feel like you are about to loose your job.  They will take your incentive away even if the client was grading your call on AMEX and NOT YOUR SERVICE!  You can be out of a job very easily here, even when you give great customer service and sales.

review_title: Great company going through a business overhaul
pros: Fantastic flexible working environment with great work life balance dependant on what you want out of the role. Good benefits and varied work. Senior leadership generally approachable and amenable albeit not as accessible if based overseas.
cons: Very silo'd business with effectively lots of individual, smaller companies working within often competing against each others' priorities which they're attempting to address. Slow to get things gone leading to old infrastructure although now moved on from Lotus Notes. Such things hamper the innovative approach the company strives for. Networking and sponsorship is paramount, without which, career progression becomes a little tricky.

review_title: Incompetent management sabotages everything at Amex.
job_title: Senior Programmer Analyst in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Pay and work environment are adequate.  Co-workers by and large are dedicated, friendly and helpful.
cons: Senior management is hopelessly out of touch and insulate themselves against the realities of the people who actually do the work.  Middle management is completely free of integrity and honesty.  Vast majority are incompetent and wholly unsuited for managing people.  Their only concern is keeping their own butts out of trouble.  Human Resources group appear to be psychopathic and delusional.  Career advancement is independent of talent and skills, but is based 99% on how much management likes you.  Outsourcing to offshore "resources" has been an utter disaster, management chooses to ignore all the problems.  Benefits are third-rate, retirement benefits miserly.

review_title: with the economy right now... value statements and benefits reinforcement cannot turn around the situation...
pros: great environment..great people...it maybe w/in the US or an outsourcing company...American Express is a big company...one of the largest and one of best well known credit card company in the US. i always smile every time I hear card members says they love to be with American Express...because they love the service that they always got. but it is so frustrating if you hear them say, American Express is going down especially with the economy right now. i just hope, management would listen to the opinions of their card holders. i hope American Express will continue to provide the extraordinary customer care not only for their customers but also to their employees.
cons: the metrics that we have to meet especially TBASS which is a survey for customers that cannot be controlled... and the employee suffers even if it's not her/his call

review_title: Amex - A Nice Place to Work
job_title: Finance Manager in New York, NY
pros:
- People / Culture:  Smart, fun, competitive but not cut-throat.  And very diverse, too!
- Employee Development: Expected to swtich positions every 18-24 months, potential for movement globally or across functions.
- Work/Life Balance: Not always, but at least they try - It's always a goal each year.
cons: As with many large organizations, politics plays a big part in your career.  Be aware that you must "play the game" if you want to get promoted, especially today where there are fewer promotion opportunities available yet the talent pool is filled with MBAs from top business schools, most of whom are smart and capable.  Doing a great job will not get your promoted unless you have the right people/leaders helping you along the way.

review_title: Almost every IT function and service that can be outsourced has been outsourced. Better enjoy working with many vendors.
job_title: Lead Technical Architect in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Pay is staggeringly good compared to other industries. It's a finance company, so of course they're doing well and they pay top performers (1 rating) handsomely with 20-30% bonuses - but basically you have to work two jobs worth of effort and hours to get it, so it's a bargain for Amex - effectively two head count for the price of one and a third with the rest striving for that bonus working equally as hard.
cons: Outsourcing. You squeeze your talent so hard or shuffle them off to a vendor who then downsizes, cuts their pay, outsources their job, at the expense of the Americans in American Express.

review_title: Great Place to Work for 15 years
pros:
Paid - Vacations, Sick Time / Benefits / 401K
Professional Employees who know how to act professional.
When there is a reason to "party" or if they have extra money to treat their top employees - AMEX goes all out.
cons: A lot of cliques. If you plan to move up, identify the "right" cliques and dont stay in one job too long - move around! Network, network, network! If layoff is a factor, dont relocate unless you need a way to get back home and the new location is located near your hometown. If you are relocating, chances are in 6 months your job will be shipped off shore and youll be layed off anyway.

review_title: Good perks and work life balance.
pros:
Encouraged Blue works (hot desking) and working from home. 

Interesting and challenging work. 

Depending on department, good work hours 9am-5pm.

Good benefits package.:

25 days annual leave (3 yrs service + 1 day, 5 yrs service + 2 days, etc). 

Pension - 4% basic salary by Amex (non contributory), matching up to 7% basic salary.

Car allowance - Manager Band 35 at £350/mth cash, Director Band 40 at £450/mth cash.

Private medical - Yearly excess £100. No excess for back problems/ Physio.

Dental - cover to £500 a year.

Gym/ classes - heavily subsidised if on-site, free gym classes for some locations, Physio on-site.
cons:
Basic salary - low compared with comparable companies. HR salary banding benchmarking for some departments are out of date.

Location - Some functions are based in Burgess Hill or Brighton is West Sussex. Time/cost to travel to, if from north London or Home Counties.

Little promotion prospects, unless willing to move departments or countries.

Dependent on the department, crazy work hours till 2-3am and during holidays/weekends. But get time back in lieu. Senior management does not seem to appreciate downstream dedication.

review_title: Great people but poor management
pros:
* very nice colleagues from all around the world, easy to build relations
* classical M-F 9-5 job with an hour lunch
* brand new office building with  subsidised canteen area and coffee shop, amazing views from top floors
* regular gathering with team-mates after work
cons:
* inconsistent training with lack of role play and basically does not prepare the new joiners for the actual daily work they will have to do
* too much calls especially on the UK and German market floor, many rude and angry customers
* lack of help provided by the management - team members try to help each other but they have very little time because of calls...
* favouritism
* salary is below industry standards (especially for Brighton prices) and the OTE is   extremely hard to achieve but it does not worth the effort
* lack of recognition, constant criticising which can be quite humiliating sometimes
* it is all about the surveys, nothing else matters

review_title: One of the best places to work for
pros:
Working at American Express is a privilege. Employee satisfaction is one of the big blue box values for the management. Colleagues are extremely courteous, super helpful. You can literally go up to anyone no matter their destination and have a discussion. 
Everyone is proud of the company and take blue box values very seriously. I work in technology and Amex is no less than other niche tech giants. You are encouraged to innovative, and most importantly, heard by the upper management. Amex offers most competitive salary in the market with dozens of perks and privileges, so you know, your organization has your back in good and bad days. Moreover it is super flexible with work timing and locations. Ample work from homes and leaves are provided, so work life balance isn't an issue. No doubt it ranks in fortune top 10 places to work for.
cons: Not much of cons here, but not all the teams work on exciting projects. But you can change teams in 18 months, so that's no issue.

review_title: Just not what I expected as a home based customer service representative
pros: Pay and bonuses are great, flexible time off, get to work from home.
cons: Currently looking for another job mainly because I am so bored. The calls are back to back with mostly upset customers.  Usually get about 30 calls an hour and it makes the days seem so long. Also the breaks are so short.  So much relies on the customer surveys and it makes my postion stressful bc TL is constantly listening and trying to find a way to get excellent surveys.  Hard to get excellent surveys from upset customers but there is a technique to it.  Also the heath insurance is aweful.  Research high deductible health insurance before applying for this job.  So worried about having a major illness because I would have to pay so much money.

review_title: Global Certification Services (GCS)
pros: Great collaborative environment and nice people to work with. Management really cares about work-life balance and is always requesting feedback on a weekly basis with one-on-one meetings with your manager. Communication within the team is far superior to other companies that I have worked for. Management does not micro manage and focuses more on the results rather than obsessing on where your time is spent or what you did exactly, which is how it should be. So long as your projects and customers are met with customer satisfaction and your personal goals within the team goals are met or exceeded you will be successful.
cons: Work can pile on and deadlines will be tight at times and cause unwanted stress but this is normal and expected in most if not all businesses. Working with other teams or businesses can be difficult at times and cause delays. Nothing really negative to say..

review_title: Company with a strong brand and reputation, on a down spiral
pros:
High quality people - recruited from top schools, top organizations
Company culture encourages internal mobility - you're able to pick up new skills every 2 yrs as you rotate jobs
World/life balance like no other - mandated work from home 2 days a week in most depts., flexible work from home as needed for dr. appts, due to bad weather, etc.
cons:
Company culture has gone down over the years; less focus on leadership development.
Lack of meritocracy - top performers not rewarded with promotions or given career opportunities; you need to get backed by multiple senior people to get ahead.
Slow decision-making and pace of innovation

review_title: good place to waste a time . (this is for ESS lob in VSSi)
pros:
company and ESS as LOB is doing really good (no use for base level employee).

you get lot of time to prepare for your next job interview.
cons:
no body will be bother of your performance unless its appraisal time .

shift allowances are good how ever shift allowances are paid in installments .

please your manager with gifts, alcohol, smoke/joint or party, and you'll receive the award for best performer.(i'm not sure if this should be in pros or in Cons).

if you wanna grow you have be the underdog of the manager.

salary issues. sometimes employee has to calculate their own salaries and send it to mgmt and payroll team.

management acts like school teacher. keeping track of "how much time you spend in washroom".

employees are treated like "slaves" by mgmt.

HR has no role in ESS, they have to agree to the decision taken by management,

Neither HR nor mgmt is approachable 

if you implement an Idea successfully , the credit and appreciation will go to mgmt/ their favorites.

Internal Job Posting is Pathetic Joke.

review_title: Platinum Customer Care
job_title: Customer Care Professional in Plantation, FL
pros: The #1 best thing about working for AMEX is their benefits. They are top of the line. (medical, dental, 401 matching, dependent care benefits, PTO/Sick time) Now depending on your role, you may feel like you are 1 of 100s of people and don't feel important (call center) or your team may be actually contributors of change. Regardless, you are paid generously for any role you are in.
cons: Your career advancement is directly related to the politics of your workplace and your supervisor. If you want to advance, (as in any job in corporate America), you need to know how to play the inter- company politics, and be sharp in your current role at all times, to be seen as a high potential candidate. If you are a call center rep, you have to BUST YOUR BEHIND to get out of that role. ATTENDANCE IS #1 key on call center roles.

review_title: I am proud to work for Amex
pros: American Express takes care of their employees in so many ways. Aside from the endless benefits, it is truly the best place to work. There are so many career growth opportunities and they invest in their employees. I am so proud to be a Team Leader at American Express which gives me the platform to help others understand the value of the company not only for the members they service but also the value it brings to them as employees. Amex has changed my life in so many ways and I will be forever grateful for the opportunities I have been blessed with in this company. I have met some of my closest friends here at Amex and truly thrive on the relationships I've built across the network.
cons: None! I sincerely love my job

review_title: Two different cultures at Amex
pros: Overall, a great company to work for. Flexible hours, remote work, they understand that life happens. A great place to learn new technologies. If you have a great manager who actually cares about you enough to invest in you, appreciate your work, and want to see you succeed, that can make all the difference.
cons:
I genuinely have no idea how some people are managers. Doesn't a manager have to actually manage? Some managers cannot be contacted and never actually show up. Lots of backstabbing and leaders who only care about themselves - it's really unfortunate to know that leadership doesn't have your back.

Technology jobs being moved overseas more and more.

FTE's and temps, working side-by-side on the same team, doing the same exact work. Complete and total reluctance to ever hire temps for years and years. You see, there is no room to add to headcount - oh, expect for these 10 new positions in India

review_title: A great company!
pros: The Amex "Commercial Card Sales" opportunity is an outstanding one for the individual who is ready to elevate their career.  You are representing a solid, well-respected company, who will make significant investments in your career growth and professional development.  Starting with the CEO, and throughout all levels of management, there is a strong sense of commitment, not only to the customer, but also to the employees of the company.  The compensation and benefits package is strong, likely better than most others in the industry.
cons: The Commercial Card Sales positions are challenging, often involving more time spent on administration than on actual sellling activities.  Although it continues to improve, sales professionals still must constantly overcome prospect perceptions of inferior merchant acceptance of Amex cards.

review_title: Decent company to work for.
job_title: Business Analyst in New York, NY
pros:
Overall, I would work at American Express again.

Good culture, but that can depend on which organization you work in. Certain organizations do not espouse the Blue Box values.

Good work/life balance. Same caveat.

Good vacation allowance.

Great direct management and good management one to two levels up.
cons:
Salaries near the bottom of the industry and comparatively poor against other companies in like for like roles. 

US citizens have poor job security.  Watched many talented individuals lose their jobs so that the company could hire replacements in India. Not because those individuals did not perform well, but only because they were tenured and at the top of their pay ranges.

Three levels up and further, they're typical executives that see you as a cog and not a person. They see your work as dollars that make up their bonus. They make changes, not because they're beneficial, but because they need to put their stamp on things.

review_title: Great company, strong focus on employee development
pros: High focus on employee development with good review and goal structure that ensures everyone in the company wants to grow and develop themselves as well as grow their colleagues. Ability to move jobs every 18 months, this is highly encouraged and happens easily through networking, recommendations and formal job applications. Large enough company to enable various experiences in different business units, different functions as well as different level (i.e. central vs. local).
cons: Somewhat slow processes, due to the fact that it is an old and large company in a field highly regulated and requiring high data protection. New products, projects, ideas can take a very long time to be approved. Mentalities are also sometimes difficult to change because people tend to stay in the company for a very long time and are therefore less keen on changing the way they work.

review_title: Great company culture but long hours depending on department
pros:
-Great work/life balance opportunities. Some groups offer ability to work from home 1-2 days a week. General work hours in NY are 50/week. Other offices outside of NY tend to have better work/life balance.
-The people are generally great to work with (friendly, collaborative).
-The company is very encouraging of gaining varied experience by moving from business group to business group.
cons:
-Very PowerPoint presentation heavy. Anything that gets presented to leadership has to have a deck prepared.
-Too much time is wasted in having meetings (a lot of times, you'll have meetings to prepare for meetings).
-Depending on business group, there may be a culture of working long hours or encountering frequent work fire drills (drop everything to get something done)
-Salary is below industry average (we are told that this in exchange we have a better work/life balance).

review_title: Depending on what you want out of your job/career, Amex could be a great fit
pros:
- genuinely good people are your coworkers
- cares strongly for the end customer
- deep respect for personal life situations (e.g., children, sexual orientation, etc)
- great nyc benefits (e.g., Tribeca Film Festival employee promotions, free admission to major museums, etc)
- fairly good health center
- large company -- if you look for a specific role, it probably exists somewhere
cons:
- compensation for stellar employees is lacking, producing a culture of employees with mediocre levels of ambition
- hard to "get rid of lemons", so you'll likely end up working with some bad apple(s) that you can't avoid
- very director- and vp-driven office/team norms where you could find yourself working for a leader who is very pro or very against working virtually or a leader who is very into facetime or not which vastly changes your expected hours in the office

review_title: Great Company to Work For!
pros:
* Great work/life balance, but comes in peaks and troughs often
* Excellent brand on your CV
* Great community and peers/seniors to develop yourself
* Good benefits and over average remuneration
* Truly global blue chip with a lot of opportunities abroad
* Great office locations
* Very flexible with home-working
* Good holiday allowances
cons:
* Need to improve support technology, like expense management systems, PTO trackers, etc
* Could use CRM better
* Salaries are on the peak of the bell-curve (or just to the wrong side), is a driver in some good people leaving
* Need to remove some of the technological systems that are out of date and take up time from field-staff's day
* sometimes you get thrown in the deep end if you're a joiner
* training is below par
* difficult to find adequate cover for some roles when you need PTO

review_title: Travel Consultant
pros: Better pay than many travel agent salaries. There are advantages of working from home.
cons: I had to deal with dated software requiring multiple reboots and calls to tech team in attempts to resolve issues. Corrupt files caused many crashes and freezes. Multiple booking portals are required to keep open during the shift and if one crashes it can impact other systems causing significant frustration. Management without any travel sales experience. American Express is primarily a bank card with travel services taking a back seat. Cardmembers constantly complain about the website and the delays in booking by phone. Requires constant follow up with many departments to verify ticketing and for travel changes - often after hours. Agents get stuck with negative cardmember reviews for complaints over which they have no control.

review_title: Okay pay, great time off, downer health plan, treats employees well
job_title: Accounting Manager in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Time off policy is great - better than most other companies out there.  At the manager level, you get 28 days of PTO (inclusive of all holidays) walking in the door.  There's also a very generous 401k match plus profit sharing (last year was around 10% of base pay).
cons: Salary levels seem to be slightly lower than similar positions elsewhere.  The health plan is a high deductible plan with an HSA which can be a big downer if you have something major one year.  I don't think the premiums are low enough to justify the decrease in benefits.

review_title: Great place to work.
pros:
- Strong culture and global brand
- High rebound rate of employees leaving and returning to Amex (even after displacements)
- Volume of opportunities to drive own career, numerous paths
- Strives to deliver transparent feedback including sincere diversity efforts
- Numerous examples of long career trajectories
- Focus on the success at the front line and senior leadership levels
cons:
- Hard to understand the org matrix
- Difficult to gain visibility outside of role/unit
- Very leadership driven - so if poor leader, employee career can be blocked/sabotaged
- Consensus driven - decisions often take a myriad of socialization/team perspectives to get off the ground let alone to implementation
- Not a great place for innovative, fast moving change agents
- Unfortunate off shore relocation of call centers
- Certain roles and career paths still very dependent on the people leader

review_title: Good salary, interesting job, nice people -but quite rigid, with growing pressure and ever-changing rules
pros: Great benefits package, (one of the) best salary in Madrid, relaxed attitude (e.g. re working clothes), nice relationship with bosses who are quite laid-back and friend-like. I liked working there!
cons: The rules were getting stricter and stricter, and didn't always make sense. We were put under quite some pressure with that. Some of the teamleaders I had were useless, and mostly let the seniors (sub-ordinates) do all their work, but took the praise for it.

review_title: Run Run Run
pros: Ability to work from home
cons: Terrible Terribly company.  Felt like a slave, back to back phone calls of mostly angry customers that it is beyond your power to help.  What is even worse is how you are treated by the other departments when you do need help.  Most of the time I could not even get help from manager when it was needed. Very short breaks not even a moment to catch your breath between calls.  Boring monotonous job even though you are at home you are chained to computer and calls for entire shift with very brief breaks.  Good luck if you have a sick child or emergency you are expected to work your shift regardless of circumstances.  Seems like you are punished for doing well.  The more you succeed with surveys and points you are put in more gates and receive even more phone calls.

review_title: Great company!
pros: American Express provides great benefits to employees. Even new employees receive great compensation, profit sharing, tuition reimbursement and 4 weeks of vacation with the option to buy an additional week. There are always job postings for other departments on the companies intranet so that you can continue to grow with the company.
cons: Being such a large company it is somewhat difficult to learn the necessary skills that will help you get to the top. Networking is key to getting the job you want. I have found that many times when there is an opportunity to get a promotion management already knows who they want.

review_title: Financial Manager (Controllership)
job_title: Financial Manager in New York, NY
pros:
Great Work Life balance - virtual working, a reasonable workload (compared to the big banks), generous vacation & sick day package.  
Very good compensation with great benefits (profit sharing, 401K match, etc)
Really great culture - smart, nice people.  Not a cuthroat environment at all, very supportive. 
Decent amount of fun company events, happy hours, etc.
Compared to other Fortune 500 companies, this company really cares about its people.  They make a real effort at all levels of management to listen to employees, give them opportunities, & treat them well.
cons: company can be pretty beauracratic. Tends to be a "wait for your boss to quit" culture for promotion (very structured and heirarchial) - pretty difficult to get promoted outside of your immediate team.  Not great with internal hiring (moving talent across different roles)

review_title: Results driven
pros:
-> smart people to be around
-> competitive
-> focused on clients and projects to improve their experience
-> you have a feeling that company is set for winning
-> people know that they are here to do the job and get things done
-> invests in technology
-> focused on driving employees careers and finding best talents so business can benefit from it
-> investing in big data and improving current systems
-> lives up to their reputation
-> great opportunities to move to a different locations
cons:
-> still very US centric company, if they cut investments they start from other regions, if they put money in they start from US
-> it's not actually a con but it's very political and you accelerate your career if you made right connections backed-up with work/results. it's in your interest to ensure that you are recognized for hard work that you are doing
-> some decisions are run through US even if they don't know situation and context

review_title: Customer Care Professional
job_title: Customer Care Professional in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: Commissions were amazing. I made almost 2k-3k extra a month on top of my hourly salary. Schedule flexibility was amazing...as long as time off was  available in they system, you could take it off....no need to request time off...if its available, you take it off.
cons: Call center environment...call after call after call, after call....especially if you worked the 10 hours schedule 4 days a week like I did. I would urge you to stay away from the 4 by 10 and just do the regular 8 hours a day, 5 days a week.  Also no upward mobility....but if your making good sales then upward mobility doesn't matter.  You can make 6 figures a year staying in the same position if you want...but if you have bad surveys, It can affect your commissions

review_title: Good place to start a career.
job_title: Finance Manager in New York, NY
pros: There are many opportunities to gain a broad range of experiences in the Finance organization at American Express.  In general, moving into different Finance roles is possible if you put in the time to network and build relationships.  From the point of view of someone starting a career in Finance, this opportunity for movement is very attractive.
cons: It's been painfully repeated on many other posts, but I'll say one more time that the salary is not comparable to other financial firms.  You get a good work-life balance in most (not all) areas of the company, but the pay is simply not competitive.  I know more than a few people who plan on jumping ship for the bigger paydays once they've gained some experience and--hopefully--a few promotions.

review_title: Taking the good with just a little bad
job_title: Senior Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Great marketing company with driven, intelligent employees and leaders.  The corporate culture is relaxed and respects work-life balance at all levels.  I can't say enough about the people.  Amex employees are very social, involved and generally very nice people to work with.  The company has a great reputation as a customer-focused marketing company.  Innovation and creativity are valued and rewarded.  Although the economy has had an effect on job mobility within the company, there is a strong culture of trying many roles within the company and this mobility is a key selling point for many employees.
cons: Decision-by-consensus often means that projects move slowly.  Upward mobility at the lower levels can be hindered by lack of MBA.  Lately, job mobility has been stagnant, which has caused some employee unrest (this should free up soon.)  Morale and corporate culture can vary dramatically by role, but even the "bad" groups are pretty good.

review_title: It was a great place to work, but it's not the company it once was
job_title: Marketing Director in New York, NY
pros: Great benefits, opportunity to gain valuable career experience in a variety of roles - an ideal place to start a career, many talented people, prestige of working for a company  highly regarded[less so now] as "cutting edge" in its day.
cons: Job secruity seems to be an anachronism. Like many large companies in the last 10+ years, management has moved to an out-sourcing model in many areas, especially in IT which makes everything "go" .  The hoped for longterm efficiencies haven't been realized - phasing out/displacing functions in the west to outsource to an allegedly cheaper workforce. There's a serious knowledge drain no one seems to be doing anything about. This directly affects the quality of customer service which was the hallmark of this great company.

review_title: Company is great, Some leaders make good people leave the company.
pros:
1. Good policies for Employees' benefits

2. Pride for the Brand

3. Senior Management, say the Executive team

4. Knowledge sharing and extra-curricular activities
cons:
1. Some folks put into leadership position run their teams as shops with no sense of professionalism & maturity

2. Perception is the only thing on which people are treated, appraised, rate & promoted. 

3.  Support functions like HR are almost non-functional when it comes to offer genuine assistance to employees

review_title: AMEX Stack Ranks - Just Like Microsoft
pros: It's a job in a tough economy, but no longer a proud AMERICAN Company under the current leadership.
cons: ...conversations reveal that a management system known as “stack ranking”—a program that forces every unit to declare a certain percentage of employees as top performers, good performers, average, and poor—effectively crippled Microsoft’s ability to innovate. “Every current and former Microsoft employee I interviewed—every one—cited stack ranking as the most destructive process inside of Microsoft, something that drove out untold numbers of employees,” ...writes. “If you were on a team of 10 people, you walked in the first day knowing that, no matter how good everyone was, 2 people were going to get a great review, 7 were going to get mediocre reviews, and 1 was going to get a terrible review,” says a former software developer. “It leads to employees focusing on competing with each other rather than competing with other companies.” ~ Vanity Fair Magazine Article about Microsoft

review_title: Fast changing environment, can be like trying to run on shifting sands.  Only consider them if you're a Type-A.
pros: Most teams support flexible working arrangements, there's lots of training provided to employees and they hire very good and friendly people.  The people you work with on a day to day basis will be great.  Benefits are good if you have a family.
cons: Promotions are difficult as the upper management tend to stay on in the company and it's about who you know rather than rewarding the best people.  Although they have a large finance presence in Sussex, the main movers and shakers are in London so you'll need to take a role there to really get on.  The Corporate "family" values of the company don't seem to be embodied by the upper management and seem only to be there to keep the masses content.  There is also constant restructuring - I've been through it each year I've worked there.

review_title: Executive Travel Counselor
pros: Benefits are still worth while.  They offer of course any medical, they have retirement plans, and work life balance programs.  In addition a travel agent always has the chance of getting discounted trips or offers, and sometimes trips completely paid for by the company.
cons:
Right now the company sucks.  You are called on to sell and that's fine but you are at risk when you pick up that phone that someone is not going to like either you, the company , or the cost of ticket, the hotel , and many many other things.  However american express doesnt care about any of that.  They rate you on your call and they send out surveys to clients.  If that client gives a bad overall score ...no matter if they said they think your great and the greatest employee ever...if they give a bad overall score, YOU are held accountable. 
This is going to affect your bonuses and more importantly your JOB.

review_title: Horrible, Revolving Door Environment
job_title: Travel and Lifestyle Services in Seattle, WA
pros: Decent benefits, good PTO policy.
cons: Management has changed drastically from when I first worked for Amex.  Was recruited back after 20 years and found that front line folks are not appreciated.  Punitive management style.  Cardholders send in surveys that you may not have had anything to do with aside from answering the phone.  The surveys dictate your schedule bid (once or twice a year) and one bad survey can put you so far down the list you are working nights and weekends.  My team lead was incredibly condescending..no one on our team respected her. We started with 18 highly experienced agents in our training class, a year later only 6 are left.  And they are looking for other jobs.  Very little management support.  Also, the new online booking tool, Encore, was a bust...very disappointing considering the fact Amex piled millions into the product.  I lasted 8 months, was productive and had zero customer complaints but I just couldn't stomach it anymore and I left. .  It is not pleasant being a highly valued and skilled agent for 30 years only to be treated like you are expendable.  Not worth it.

review_title: Responsible Lending Actions Team (RLA)
pros: The people you work with are excellent and are always more than willing to help you in a situation no matter what! Gives better insight on how credit works and a clear understanding of the fact of how risk is reviewed by financial/lending institutions.
cons: Stress levels are at an all time high. You are expected to deliver the worst of news to the card members with an expectation of them rating you the best for breaking the news to them. Always treated as the unwanted child and have face low pay scales and disrespect. At times also need to deliver information to card members which can/would be erroneous down to the punctuation and still not accept it that the information provided by American Express is not vetted with the credit bureaus as claimed by American Express.

review_title: I want something different but a good company to work for
job_title: Customer Care Professional in Plantation, FL
pros:
-Very competitive salary
-Excellent benefits - 7 weeks paid vacation after 5 yrs! 
-On site nurse practitioner... no wasted time going to doctors... just go downstairs and they will write you a prescription if needed
-A lot of room to go grow if you work hard
-Tuition reimbursement- 100% up to $5k a year (if you go to work full time and school part time you can pretty much finish school with no debt) (must be a degree that can be used at Amex
cons:
-If you work in customer facing roles or manage the people in customer facing roles you go through shift bids sometimes every 6 months... can't really get used to the schedule you're on which can be good or bad depending how you feel about your schedule. I prefer having consistency.
-As a Customer Care Professional it is a very stressful job and you are constantly worried about making your numbers and making mistakes.

review_title: Where creativity goes to die
job_title: Senior Marketing Analyst in New York, NY
pros: -Great working from home policy
cons:
-Don't come to American Express, thinking that you'll be able to actually be a part of a creative marketing campaign. All messages are scrutinized by several compliance and legal groups and usually rejected for very small reasons.
-The company structure is extremely hierarchical
- If you play the game, suck up to your boss and speak up even if you have nothing valuable to add, you'll move up the ranks quickly 
-Quality of work has little to do with how you're evaluated. Your direct manager is usually not in the meetings that determine promotions and raises, therefore you're judged on how much others know about what you do (at a company of thousands of people...)
-Too many cooks in the kitchen on every project destroy the original vision for most products
-Pay is low compared to the competition - which leads to all of the good people jumping ship

review_title: Great Company, Terrible Job
job_title: Platinum Customer Care Professional in Plantation, FL
pros: great benefits; variety of schedules; good pay with bonuses; thorough training; on-site resources; opportunities for overtime; room for growth; friendly coworkers
cons: Call center environment was toxic; no flexibility during shift; timed bathroom breaks; favoritism among management; very competitive for promotions; a single call can affect your stats and bonus for the entire month; heavy call volume of angry, elitist people is draining and can affect your mental well-being

review_title: Exciting time to be working in Technology at American Express.
pros:
- Truly attempts to uphold what Amex calls "Blue Box Values". Not just lip-service.
- With recent transformations especially using the Technology-first approach, the company has molted from its state in the first decade of the millennium. 
- Like with any very large global corporation, cannot expect the agility of a startup but company places very high value on agility and speed of decision making.
- You are treated as a person, not just a body with a brain and hands.
- Senior management takes employee feedback seriously.
cons:
- Very large matrixed global multinational (couple more adjectives) corporation. Makes it a challenge to get a grasp on the who's-who in the company.
- Being a bank-holding company, technology decision making does get impeded due to strict government regulations around the finance sector.

review_title: Great once - Used to love it. Employee satisfaction and lowered attrition are clearly no longer a focus
pros: Decent pay, better than average benefits, paid time off.
cons: Constant threat of layoffs, even for top performers (and especially top paid) has led to widespread morale issues company wide. There is widespread fear, in spite of decent Company performance (and a CEO who makes 20mil + at the end of the day) that even tenured and dedicated employees will loose their jobs in order to drive stock up a few percentage points. Amex used to be a highly respected , sought after and recommended employer. Times have certainly changed unfortunately. The employee surveys are adjusted to make the Company and managers look good, and feedback is rarely actioned any longer.

review_title: Honest Review
pros: Salary is good , in house nurse, gym, Starbucks, off the 101
cons: Your just a number, another worker on the phone. Benefits suck. They make you pay 100% of office visits until you hit deductible. They make you use express scripts which is horrible because they never get your meds right. You go through a horrible stressful 8 week process, you have to pass or you do not even make it on the floor. So if you want to risk everything just to lose it at the end, go for it. Almost every department you are graded on just surveys and basically if you get bad surveys, you cannot get up from it and after strike 3 you are fired. They do not give you any time of the phones, moral is low, and if your not in the "in" crowd you are shunned.

review_title: Great Company with lots of leaders
job_title: Software Engineer in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros:
Benefits are solid.  401K matching is great.
Good work/life balance
A lot of opportunity to move around if you are located in a Hub cite (NY, AZ, FL, UT)
Empowered to make changes once alignment is obtained...have to sell it.
cons:
Too much management layer.  Umpteen VPs in chain of command.
Collocate push is nonsense.  Wants to be like Yahoo and seems to be working out exactly the same way.
Layoffs seem to happen more than you would think.  When the company does well there are layoffs.  When the company does poorly there are layoffs.  No safe season.
