review_title: Great place to work but..
job_title: Senior Marketing Manager in London, England
pros: Great place to work if you want lots of development opportunities. People are very smart and many are tenured, which speaks to itself. Great benefits and life/work balance. Working from home a day or two a week is a norm in some functions. Career opportunities are aplenty and moving across the company’s businesses is easy. Hard working people get noticed and promoted quickly. Great mentorship programmes and career advice.
cons: Constant reorganisation that disrupts whole departments. Sometimes it feels like there is no clear vision on where the company should be moving. Salary is very average, bonuses are minuscule and merit increases are hard to notice on your payslip. Lots of admin and bureaucracy that demotivates and takes out a lot of your time. Management is very political and there is a lot of favouritism going on. This all results in lots of bright people leaving to work for competitors.

review_title: Good for starting, and retirement
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
* Environment is challenging
* Adopt new technologies
* Leadership approachable 
* Insights to all employees with Town halls
* Emerging as a in-house IT company
* 401K plan is good
* Share profits
* Help in education
cons:
* Internal Politics
* Overloaded with work
* Promotion is luck, and after pretending brilliant employee with fake applauds
* More leaders, less deployers (overburdened with updates, and weekend deployments)
* Leadership doesn't feel that people have personal life too
* They don't hire people, until delivery affected, while existing employees are depressed
* If starting career here, wait for 10-15 years to be promoted as manager only. 
* No remote option
* Don't use get off chair, clearly you have super availability

review_title: Amex Leadership, how disappointing.
pros: I used to think Amex was a great place to work.  I'm a Team Leader in a large travel call center in Michigan and a few years ago I watched my current boss railroad a couple of Managers in the office.  The company was restructuring positions and these two guys gave everything to Amex, their time, vacation time, days off, etc.  and for what to have one woman who is still there be on a power trip and got rid of both of them.  I've been disappointed in Amex for years.  The best reason to stay is for the benefits!!
cons: The current Director in the call center, she is not professional but expects others to be.  She is real quick to point out what we the employees are doing wrong, but she has no accountability in her actions.

review_title: Not the most competitive salary-wise, but truly a great company to work for
pros: A Fortune 500 company and one of the 30 stocks that comprise the DJIA, American Express is a leader in the payments and travel industries.  It is a strong and highly-respected brand with a unique business model that is the envy of its credit card competitors.  The company is full of very smart and talented people and places a strong emphasis on work-life balance.  Work culture leans more towards teamwork, not competition, and strongly focused on delivering premium value to its Cardmembers.  Its global reach and presence allows for collaboration across borders and encourages diversity of ideas.
cons: American Express offers salaries that are at par with its peers in the payments industry, but not exactly highly competitive.  The benefits package has undergone changes in the last few years, leading to dissatisfaction among some existing employees.  The company as a whole could also do a better job at meritocracy.

review_title: Company of individuals wrapped up in their own greed.
pros: Stable, and relative freedom if you stay away from management.
cons: Dilbert principle is rife, blame intensive company, fear of failure at the cornerstone of making people work harder, anybody who works smarter is cornered off by an intrinsic inner network of bureaucrats who have no real power other than to target defensive attacks on their ivory towers.  Consumes good people for the benefit of middle/upper management.   Upper management have very little concrete delivered results by their own efforts, as the rely on good people they push around or get rid off over time.  The company in general after 20 years is destabilising under the forces of new technology and leaders who are out of touch.  The best approach of fixing it is to hire new graduates who haven't been burn't by the company.

review_title: I was employed by American Express for five years and enjoyed working there during economically challenged times.
job_title: Director of Sales Operations in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: The benefit package provided by American Express is good.  Adequate time off, 401K match, flexibility in work schedules for most positions.  Most leaders are very conscious about work life balance and very understanding when circumstances arise that require you to miss a little work.  I believe the executive leaders in the company (CEO, EVP's) are very bright and knowledgable about running the business.
cons: Healthcare benefits are lacking and overly expensive for a company this size, but if you consider the overall benefit package the company is quite generous.  As for leadership... More care needs to be taken in the selection and retention of leaders at the senior level (site leaders and functional VP's).  Recent decisions have been made which may hinder short to mid-term growth.

review_title: Too bureaucratic and too many decision makers.
pros: The comapny genuinely cares about its employees and will do everything it can to make it a better place to work.  The system will well protect you and you will also have a chance to speak out.  Work hours are good and most people share great respect of colleagues.  One wouldn't be surprised to see colleagues who have worked in the Company for many years.
cons: There is an incredible amount of bureaucracy in the entire company and there are levels and levels of approval to go through for each tiny little decision.  Innovation is usually sacrificed and it can easily get boring and run of the mill after a few attempts.  The internal mechansim has created so much unnecessary work and waste which is frustrating to some departments and users.

review_title: Could be better
job_title: Customer Care Professional in London, England
pros: Apparently I must enter five words for 'pros'  honestly all I can five is; the monthly salary and a small group of colleagues who support each other through the daily mess and grind.
cons: Team Leaders and Management they have no idea what front line staff have to go through offering no support but blindly enforcing processes and policies.  Communication is non existent, any suggestions for improvements fall on deaf ears or slip into the long process of evaluation that is never ending. To get anywhere you have to be able to be a yes person if you don't do this you will not fit in and progression of any sort will be non existent.  The customer calls are surprisingly typical call center types - intense and very often abusive - there is no support only critical analysis.  I expected more/better from this company, I was badly disappointed and for all the benefits the company may offer you very rarely get them including bonuses which they make nigh on impossible of achieving.   I left my position feeling inadequate and stressed.  A totally wasted year.

review_title: Finance at Amex.  Not the place it used to be....
job_title: Finance Director in New York, NY
pros: The people here are still great - Smart, fun, competitive but not cut-throat. And diverse too.
cons: This is not the Amex I joined 5+ years ago.  Everyone is expected to work longer, harder, with less pay and opportunities for movement.  Morale is weak.  Senior leadership in Finance is extremely demanding but for no good reason.  Leadership does not know how to prioritize even though it's a constant focus.  Many leaders are selfish and very focused on their own reputation/ego, pushing unnecessary work down to the teams .  Work-life balance is now practically non-existent, although it is always a goal every year.

review_title: Good company with work life balance but not much to learn
job_title: Quality Assurance Engineer in Gurgaon, Haryana
pros:
> Good company with good culture and work life balance
> Nice gym facilities - you get access to some nice gyms at just rs 70 a month
> Spend good money on doing certifications for people
cons:
> Not much to learn. Was there for 4 years but wasn't able to learn much
> Politics. People who are sycophants get to the top, get promotions but no respect for skills. 
> I was hired as a QA in Amex for automation but automation testing doesn't have respect in the company. After hiring me as an automation engineer, I was put into manual team and for 4 years, I have majorly done manual testing. It's like forgetting the skill set which you have done all your career.
> Good for scrum masters but not good for rest of the scrum team

review_title: Review all your options before joining American Express as your tenure may be short lived.
pros: Many posted job opportunities worldwide, however the interview process is flawed sometimes based on the hiring leader and apparent bias.
cons: Too many RIF situations, senior leadership will rather lay-off than work through the process of reductions in other areas, there are many corporations that do not look at reducing the workforce first, but rather last.

review_title: Company needs to focus on the client and customer more
job_title: Former Manager of Business Development in Philadelphia, PA
pros: I have to say the best reason to work for Amex is to obtain work experience related to the industry you are in.  Many companies out there are willing to listed to what Amex has to offer them simply because of the brand name and people's preconception that Amex = Great Customer Service.
cons: The most senior level management seems to turn a cold shoulder to the effects of many of the less than thought out decisions that are made.  The training of new hires is little to non existent.  In order to succeed, you must seek to learn the position on your own otherwise you will be shown the door.

review_title: In Financial Services, good work life balance, innovative, just too much internal politics
job_title: Senior Manager in New York, NY
pros:
Work Life Balance
Innovative
Friendly culture
Best place in Consumer Banking
cons:
TOO MUCH internal politics. At a point when you want to get to a Director or VP level, your skills at playing politics become VERY important. This can get very annoying.
Amex has a young work force, at least in New York, so if you are not a Director by the time you are about 33 or so, you start feeling a little out of place.
The salaries at Amex are usually lower than at other Consumer Banking companies, they compensate for this with their better and more innovative culture. I used to work at Citi and the culture at Amex was a lot better, but they pay less (usually).

review_title: Corporate Service Inbound Representative
job_title: Globel Corporate Services in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Benefits are good.  Company receives many awards everything from health to best company's to work for.  Great salary for those hired with any form of higher education.
cons: Employees hired with higher education get paid a lot more no matter if that education is related to the job they are hired for vs the employee that has been there many years and teaches the new employees and makes a lot less an hour ---fair, I say not.  Health benefits are great after you get past high deductible.  Awards for healthy employer is a joke as you can come though the building at any time to see over 70% of people grossly over weight.  Company never satisfied with surveys--very stressful environment.  As a global company you would think they would try to keep jobs in America,  everything is going overseas.  Soon there will be little to no American in American Express.

review_title: Director of Engineering
job_title: Director of Engineering in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Like people who are doers at working class level, and engineers.
cons:
Palo Alto office only hiring their relatives, friends who has no knowledge in the areas of expertise of technologies. Old school thoughts. One hand the leadership says business projections on track on another had they say quality is bad. No direct correlation. Please leaders by giving fat data meaningless that no one captures in software delivery for cloud tech stacks.
Lack of leadership.  
 Any one questioning “status quo” gets into bad politics. Many smart people left or got laid off because they spoke to make improvements or challenge old school thoughts.
Very bad Leaders making hostile environment where you can not say anything. You lose your brightness abilities working with dumb old school thoughts. You work long hours literally 7 days a week for releases that is meaninglessness. 
Bringing contractors without interviews, knowledge. Looks some personal scam going on where management are making money, keeping in their pockets.
Some ethnically issues going on. Talk to any doers they all feel this. Fix gaps with modern work culture.

review_title: Some interesting work, low pay, way too much offshore and outsourcing.
job_title: Lead Technical Architect in New York, NY
pros: It's a large company with a lot of interesting technology.  Looks good on your resume.  Thats a good thing because you will always be thinking about leaving.
cons:
So many internal services are outsourced that it is very difficult to get anything done well or in a reasonable period of time.  It is frowned upon to mention this.  I've really never seen anything like it.
Low salaries.  Extensive offshoring means US salaries are driven down and quality of work for offshore is much lower than most onshore. But it's cheap which is all anyone seems to care about.
It's never hit me but there are often reorgs with good people losing their jobs for no apparent reason.  This makes everyone nervous whenever there is a change and alot of people always have one eye on the next job as a result.

review_title: Yin & Yang
pros: Friendly work environment among all the lower level workers and management. AMEX has many incentives for you to work harder to earn more money.  Benefits were very good and started day one.
cons: A lot of favoritism in upper management made advancement difficult as well as they strange "star story" interview process. Downsizing to send more work out of country even though customers hate speaking to those they can't understand and those of us in America are stressed about losing our jobs.

review_title: American Express
job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: Challenging and interesting problems. Large majority of people are collaborative team players. Smart peers. Career moves through different groups are encouraged. Strength of brand and reputation. Company is self-aware on attention to people/talent/work-life balance - questionable on whether awareness has driven change.
cons: Extremely consensus-driven & matrixed. Lots of churn for little forward motion. For a company based on information (underwriting, consumer/merchant demographics, transaction information, etc.), data is extremely hard to access and users have low levels of fluency. Probably still overstaffed by 20%.

review_title: Generous To A Fault
job_title: Executive Administrative Assistant in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Most of the people that work for American Express are nice. The pay is above average and the vacation time provided is more than most companies offer. They promote applying for other jobs within the company. Amex matches dollar per dollar donations to non profits one month out of the year.
cons: It's difficult to get anything accomplished in such a big company. Plus, they are about 10 years behind in technology.  Additionally, one never knows if they will be the next person to be laid off. Consequently, the stress level is very high at this company.

review_title: Wonderful employer but full of politics
pros:
Awesome income opportunities and bonuses
Ability to work from the comfort of your home
Split schedule
cons:
Lots of politics involved
Opportunity for growth is extremely limited if you work from home. 
If your stress level is not high, this is not for you. I don't really get stressed but I have seen people cry when the time came to log in.
Although they offer split schedules and opportunity to work from home, they are not very flexible when it comes to school and life. It is all about them, which is somewhat understandable. I have seen people resign because they were denied the opportunity at a better schedule to accommodate their education.

review_title: Great Employer
pros: Shift Flexibility/Excellent Training/Flexible Locations/Great Benefits
cons: Sometimes there are just too many hands in the pot.

review_title: AMERICAN Express or INDIAN Express???
pros: Good starting place for a new grad
cons:
- Nepotism is HUGE! There was a huge reorganization in 2016. In 2017, the diversity in the mid-manager level of Risk department had significantly decrease as I observed. The upper executives promoted/hired his/her homies. Competency is not as important. The reorg was supposed to trim fat. However, AMEX became more bureaucratic with more redundant and incompetent mid-managers . As a result, smart talents were treated unfairly and there was a talents exodus in 2017 to 2018. 
- I still remember 2 years ago when my boss saw beef in my lunch box she would give me a stupid look, and sometimes gave me some hard time to humiliate me. THIS IS the U.S.. I am not up for whatsoever religious reasons and I LOVE BEEF. I didn't bother to report to the HR back then because I know the AMEX bureaucracy doesn't care. Plus I got a great opportunity that pays way better elsewhere, so I wasted no time at AMEX.

review_title: Very stressful.
pros: They train people with no travel experience to become Travel Counselors.  They do rehire people who leave on good terms with the company.  You get all the travel agents benefits with your IATAN card.
cons: The job is very stressful.  They change their game plan often.  You learn one difficult task or requirement of the job, get rated for your ability to apply that new task,  and then a few months later they decide to remove that skill.  They don't offer part-time or flex-time options, only full-time.  The company is 'clicky' and they do hire and promote their favorites regardless of whether or not that person is qualified.  There is a lot of 'talk' about making changes to better the environment but it's all a lot of hot air.

review_title: Would not recommend unless you are desperate
pros:
Volunteer opportunities
Healthy food choices in cafeteria
cons:
No perceived job security
1st day orientation, was told AMEX not here to provide jobs, but to be profitable 
Leaders lacking maturity
Incentive plan creates "me, me, me" mentality, not in the best interest of client
Parking is equivalent to the holiday season at the local mall, except it is everyday 
Health care costs vs value
Employee recognition 
Development resources
No employee refrigerators or freezers
Dirty work environment

review_title: Lots of offshoring and outsourcing going on
pros: Benefits are ok. Salary ok for tenured employees. On site day care and gym if you use them.  On site cafe.
cons: Lack of planning outsourcing with out proper planning.  Appear not to want to hire displaced management level employees. Used to be where you want to stay got a carrier now no one is ever sure if their job or department is next to go.  Customer service does not appear number one priority anymore.

review_title: Awesome place to work with great folks/management
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in New York, NY
pros:
Most managers/coworkers are extremely friendly and helpful, and are frequently responsible for mentoring new hires or junior developers 
You can really feel that those in charge genuinely want to help their employees; benefits are excellent, accepting and friendly culture is constantly reinforced/encouraged, community events (at least in NYC) are consistent and open to all employees, cross-organization learning sessions are common. 
Salary is fairly competitive, especially for locations outside of NYC (not to say that NYC salaries are low though)
Excellent work/life balance, and the company is constantly improving its agile methodology/workflow to ensure working late on the job is a thing of the past
cons: Career growth can be limited within a team, especially larger ones - you may need to apply to positions in other organizations for promotions. If you want to stay in your team, you need to constantly push your boss for raises/promotions as they aren't likely to come to you naturally (which isn't necessarily uncommon across various companies)

review_title: Amex is great if you want to learn more, just be careful what group you go into.
job_title: Senior Manager in New York, NY
pros:
American Express is very supportive of  employees need to advance as well as in making lateral moves for skill expansion. There are many opportunities to move between business units or to specialize in one area.
Also, take advantage of all the various employee networks that are invaluable in meeting people in other groups and learning about other business units.
cons: Legacy technology sometimes slows down innovation, as well as makes it hard to learn your way around unless you find another employee to mentor you.  There aren't sufficient self-study options for systems, so you have to ensure you network in order to get properly trained.  Training classes are available but not always when you need them.

review_title: Good but wish it was better
pros:
Good benefits.
Very work/life balance friendly.
Lots of PTO and sick hours
Very diverse culture
Great pride to work here amongst employees
Co-workers are awesome
cons:
You have to know somebody to get promoted. Manager's already tend to have someone in mind when posting for a position, and post a job only because they are "required" to give everyone an opportunity to apply. 
So unless you are  a VP or Director's favorite, forget it. You will stay in the same role forever. 
You can get replaced very easily. Management always has someone next in line to replace you, should they push you out or you are pressured to resign. 
Restructuring and layoffs happen quite frequently.

review_title: From great to good.. What's next?
pros:
Lot of learning opportunities and variety of jobs
Good people
Leadership is quite talented 
Trying to be more lean and agile
cons:
Traditional mind set
Lot of disparity in income at same level 
Company has lost it employee focus and from having employees being an asset, it has become a cost. 
Limited growth opportunities in India. 
HR is worst department and has been key to creating bad employee experience. While I was leaving, nobody bothered to talk to me why I was leaving and take feedback, besides my leader for 10-15 mins when I told my decision. No exit interview. 
To reduce costs there are lot of opportunities to improve efficiency of departments and impact 10-15% profits.

review_title: Platinum Travel consultant Sydney
pros:
great people, great training and development programs
Nice location and office
Sold luxury holiday packages and high end products so we enjoyed luxury first and Business class famils
cons:
Flawed business model that allows Card members to abuse the system to get what they want and management ALWAYS supports the members over staff even if members are in the wrong.
Fancy reputation but low pay, no commision, understaffed and unsupported by management, hence high turn over of staff...I couldn't take it after 18months..felt like a slave chained to my desk in a call centre environment.

review_title: Fair Company with smart & nice people
pros: I really liked working at Amex for 5+ yrs.  It was great to work with smart and nice people, who generally were happy to collaborate to get the job done.  They are able to balance hard, intelligent (not emotional) work with lots of fun too.  Ken Chenault, the CEO, is a wonderful leader and makes everyone feel that the company is going in the right direction.  I was offered job flexibility with regards to condensed hours and working from home, which made managing my career and family doable.
cons: Like in any large corporation, there is some politics.   Divisions have their own culture, so I was lucky to be able to work in two different divisions.

review_title: Great company to work from and learn at
job_title: Financial Analyst in New York, NY
pros: You will work with smart people who appreciate the importance of work/life balance. There are plenty of opportunities to move around and see different areas of the company and they do care deeply about career development. You could go somewhere else and make more money, but AmEx offers a ton of flexibility (Working from home every Friday) and has really great benefits.
cons: As with any Fortune 500 company, if you are going to move up at AmEx, you're going to need to network. You can be a great worker, but if you don't show the hunger and the energy to get yourself noticed, it'll be tough sledding. This is not a place where you'll look around and see innovation day in and day out. That being said, it's still a successful company after 160 years for a reason.

review_title: American Express Technologies - Fire, Ready, Aim
pros: Great PTO / sick time benefits
cons: Currently not much stability / job security due to business reorgs and team realignments; the enterprise is highly siloed making inter business unit cooperation somewhat challenging at times due to leadership "turf wars".  The current partnership with IBM has proved to detrimental the to agile culture that AET is attempting introduce / transition in that contracted change SLAs consistently blow sprint capacities.  Characteristic of most Financial Services companies, salaries are below market relative to other market segments (AMEX tends to be lower I guess for the privilege of working for the Blue Box).  As of late, the AMEX cultural "Blue Box" values of respect appear to have sunset-ed or at least shelved during times of rapid organization change.  Too bad as used to be the premier employer in the Valley of the Sun.

review_title: Politics Drama
pros: Great office, good product, good salary, good training. When you will first join you will feel great about yourself. Incentives are great but very hard to achieve.
cons: First of all the team leaders think they own the company. My TL was not able to pronounce the word AVAILABLE correctly but still she was there ruling 10 of us. Nepotism is a deal in the company. You are only restricted to your team. No outside interactions are allowed. The day you get 1 bad survey, they will make your life hell. Extremely slow growth in the company if you are not ready to go out of your way. Too much interference in your personal life by your TL. Card holders are never assisted properly. If you dont have any solution, we were asked to transfer them incorrectly which seems unfair. Mangers really need a reality check. Incompetent bunch of snobs.

review_title: Used to be a great company but lost its way after the 2008 financial crisis.
pros:
Work vs Life Balance is still OK.
Most managers would allow for 1-2 days of remote work depending on your job.
cons:
Internal moves have become increasingly difficult.
Lack of knowledge/experience caused by lay offs (every 2 years).
Knowledge/experience was replaced by politics and empty rhetoric.
Lack of real leadership (top managers leave strategy creation to lower managers. They come with conceptual ideals/goals and call that strategy). Very frustrating!
If you are good at getting the boss to like you, you'll go far.   
Used to be a great company but lost its way after the 2008 financial crisis. Bi-annual lay offs removed critical knowledge of the company and that was replaced by empty marketing and politics.

review_title: Good pay if you don't want work to be your life.
pros: Competitive pay and competition within the company isn't too stifling.  They offer great benefit packages and allow a lot of flexibility in how you want to work with a good work/life balance.  I have worked at two other companies prior to this and both other companies had much more serious cultures.
cons: It is a huge company and does have that huge company feel to it which carries some downsides like it becomes extremely important to be in the right group.  A lot of management is incompetent particularly where I work in HR and they would not get jobs at other firms but AMEX is pretty easy with their hiring.

review_title: Great company- one of the best work at home positions I have had
pros: American Express has great benefits, including decent health care, sick time and lots of paid vacation time. Team leaders, management and higher ups are all very nice and great to work with. This positions is also work-at-home which is a great option for those who can manage an in-home office.
cons: Incoming calls are continuous, and there is not a lot of down time. Calls can become repetitive with similar issues and inquiries. The job can be stressful when customers complain.

review_title: Losing its luster quickly
pros: Good benefits. Good people. Many jobs allow you to work from home. Good company for new graduates or empty nester types.
cons:
Terrible work/life balance in Business Development & Account Management roles. For this reason I left along with several colleagues. 
Senior Management has cut resources to the bare minimum and Sales people are unable to do what they do best because they are inundated with never ending internal operational and administrative requests.
Senior Management share their stories of success without acknowledging that the support structure they benefitted from in the past no longer exists.
No clear path of career progression and your leadership can impact your career aspirations.
Many Senior leaders rotate every two years and can be shortsighted in their goals. Long term planning is nonexistent for internal employee initiatives.

review_title: Very well run company for (its size) with all the pros and cons that comes with the large size...
pros:
The culture supported: work life balance; family friendly(popular with moms especially).
The prospect for growth:  great place to learn the credit card business.
The career trajectory:  you can always go up, however, sometimes outsiders who have worked at reputable firms get an accelerated boost.
cons: The company's business model is so strong that not much risk-taking or innovation is nurtured, nor is it required for success, since the company is essentially a well-oiled money printing machine on the scale of a large battleship.

review_title: Great place to work--you get out what you put in!
job_title: Customer Care Professional in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: American Express is a results driven company. You are rewarded well for performing well, both monetarily and in terms of career advancement. There is a big focus on work life balance because they want happy employees. Happy employees perform better. Everyone is super nice and it is fun to go to work.
cons: The job itself can be stressfull, your expected to make an emotional connection, solve the cardmembers problem, give them a "benefit" on every call, and do it in under 300 sec. Plus your phone availability needs to be 90%. So it is work, work, work.

review_title: Decent company with some major corporate flaws; poor outlook for an extremely powerful brand
job_title: Project Analyst in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
Mostly good people working for the company (band 35 and below)
Decent pay 
Superior brand

review_title: Great experience overall
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: I have been there for 7 years and they are very employee-focused.  It is a fun environment with great perks.
cons: They are constantly reorganizing - every year there are large layoffs, so it's not a very secure environment.  Also, to get promoted, it is often a lot of additional work - they encourage movement at the lower levels so you have to work on building your "brand" outside your group in order to get a new job - and you have to apply for promotions for the most part.  It's not just a work hard and get recognized environment - you have to work at your day job while working on finding a new job - constantly.

review_title: American Express global new accounts CCP
job_title: American Express Global New Accounts CCP in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: I worked at American Express for 10+ years. great pay, work/life balance, benefits. Job growth opportunities ,Good environment, Diverse employees Great people to work with.
cons: I can't think of anything

review_title: Amex UK
job_title: Project Consultant in Burgess Hill, England
pros: Great people, ability to work across multiple sites and from home, with high autonomy. Great benefits including a virtual GP service and onsite gym. High flexibility and support for working parents. The relationship building aspect of the culture shouldn't be underestimated. Coffee catch ups with colleagues are encouraged to ensure cross-line of business collaboration. Genuinely nice people work here and care about each other.
cons: Politics and a lot of alignment to make decisions and changes, perhaps stemming from risk adverse culture. Flatter organisation so takes longer to progress than in the past.

review_title: Awesome place! Highly reccommended
job_title: Product Management Manager in New York, NY
pros: Amazing work life balance - even working on some of the biggest investments in the company, the hours are really, really moderate.  I usually come in ~9:20 and leave by 5:30-6.  The work is great, and the culture is really relaxed.  AMEX is also really great with families, as they give alot of benefits to new parents.   Also, career mobility here is great as new roles are encouraged every 18 months - 2 years.  I've had experience all over the company already after only being here 4 years.
cons: Salary is competitive, but only when coming externally.  Getting promoted up doesn't allow you to keep pace with going market rates.  This causes alot of good talent to leave once they get a title promotion, in order to make a market rate salary.

review_title: Small Business Customer Care Professional
job_title: Amex Small Business CCP in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Work from home. Good pay and benefits. Great vacation and sick time policy. If you like to sell this is for you. You get to help card members and some of them are great.
cons: Too much pressure for sales. Software systems are horrible and metric expectations are unrealistic given what we have to work with. If you're not in the top 30% you can forget getting a decent schedule you'll like. Customer surveys carry too much weight and there is no appeal process to remove surveys that are negative even when they aren't your fault (i.e. customers mad about company policy you can't change, a survey that was for someone else but it got counted under your name).

review_title: Great Brand Name, cheap on benefits and compensation.
pros: Can't beat the brand name. There is something special about having this on the resume.
cons:
As many of the posters indicated here - the compensation at American Express is below industry averages. In addition, the healthcare / dental benefits do not compare to other Canadian companies. A portion of my paycheck goes toward my healthcare benefits [mandatory] and I can't even opt out of participation and the coverage isn't even that great - a lot of claims are not even covered. The insurance provider that AE has chosen [Great West Life] is a poor choice compared to others in the market.

The location of the headquarters in Canada is in Markham. I don't understand how a Fortune 100 company that is a major Financial Institution do not have its head office in the downtown core [other than for cost reasons].

review_title: I could be very happy here, but I want something more.
job_title: Customer Care Professional in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Stable, good money, seems like good benefits, lots of different opportunities, tuition reimbursement if it is work related, excellent training, mentor ship, workshops
cons: You have to be driven, it is a very data/numbers company- but employees are not robots...some people won't fit into the boxes they make for you. Not a lot of input is wanted from the minions.

review_title: It's a good company BUT...
job_title: Lead Technical Architect in Phoenix, AZ
pros:
Work flexibility...come and go as you please...WAH...as much as you want...ok pay.
It's a great name to put on your resume.
cons:
Working around the clock. You basically work 24 hours a day with a break thrown in for your life. Management makes delivery promises that are based on complete fiction. Then they slave drive you to meet these unobtainable deadlines.
Promotion or career advancement...don't even think about it! Basically if you don't make yourself "friendly" with a VP level executive, you will not get anywhere. It's really about who you know and who likes you more than your skills and abilities.
Work life balance...oh yeah they have it....it's ALL WORK AND NO LIFE!!!
Company has a chance to be really good place to be a good company but it falls short!

review_title: They will walk all over you
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: Great pay and benefits....that's it.  If you are looking for a place to make good money for a short period of time, American Express can do that for you.  As long as you don't mind being a punching bag while collecting your money.
cons: This is a dog-eat-dog company.  Management does what they have to do to make themselves look good and they don't care who they have to step on or destroy in doing so.  If you are looking for a place to create a carreer, THIS IS NOT IT!!!  It doesn't matter what experience you have nor what great things you do for the company, if you do not fit in to upper management's own agenda, you will not get anywhere.

review_title: SABE is worst team to work for in American Express, highly unethical and unprofessional.
pros: Good bonus, and IJP possible, only if you are leaders favourite, special Incentive for leaders favourite employee
cons:
Politics is way to much, leaders dont  how much insight about the projecct they bringing now  they don’t know how to handle project and only focus on doing politics, you raise concern n you will be shown door out of the organisation, discrimination is very high, personal relations are given more importance over individual's merit and performance. Yearly rating and bonus are pre-decided and given to only those who are leader's favourite.
Highly unprofessional and unethical Employee relation (ER/HR) )team, working hand in gloves with operations. Multiple mental harassment cases have been ignored and employee who raised such cases have been asked to leave the company. One employee even try to end his life specially when he was excellent performer.

review_title: Most ridiculous place ever to work at!!!
job_title: Platinum and CenturionTravel Representative in Lawrenceville, GA
pros: Plenty of vacation time,sick time, and you can buy a week of vacation.
cons: Surveys that do not belong to you,pay is not good,raisies are not good,too much work for one person with no more pay,morale is horrible,managers who are in positions who do not need to be in them.

review_title: Good ole boy network
pros: Vacation - American Express has an unbeatable vacation plan.
cons:
If you are a people leader, the company does three employee engagement surveys every year.  These surveys are part of your overall rating at year end (30%).  Employees know if they don't like their leader to score them low and Amex will put the leader on a plan and manage them out.  For people leaders, it is difficult to do the right thing for the company by holding people accountable.  I watched my leaders have anxiety and such each and every time a survey was rolled out.  Has to be a better way.

Make the right connections quickly.  That will be what saves you during any displacements.

review_title: Great compensation if you dont mind all the bureaucracy
job_title: Risk Mgt Representative in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: The commission pay was usually more than my hourly pay, that was great, except it sometimes get diminished by customers who did not comply or defaulted afterwards. The health benefits were also a plus. In addition the days off, sick pay and vacation are all great especially since you can take it in increments down to 10 mins at a time. I also loved their working motto and how you can easily move up the ranks if you perform well.
cons: You are constantly micro managed. You dont have just 1 supervisor but rather everyone in the company above you even in other departments listening in on all your conversations with customers to ensure you dont say a single thing out of script. They expect you to work on your goals during your off phone time while your not on the clock in order to make goals.

review_title: Coordinator or Executive Assistant
pros: Diversified and family oriented company.  Flexible working hours, healthy living programs for employees, causal dressing, virtual work office and great salary.  Little supervision from management, which I believe drive results and getting the job completed on time.
cons: There is hardly any cons to share, as American Express thought very hard in finding ways to make their employees comfortable and happy.  However, if I had to share something, I would would say that promotion can take time and challenging, as there are many experienced and knowledgeable people to compete with.

review_title: Great Work Life Balance
job_title: Project Manager in New York, NY
pros: I switched over to American Express from an investment bank and this company was a breath of fresh air. I found that the company is great with mobility, where you are encouraged to look for career opportunities internally every 18 months.  The work life balance is great where you have the option of working from home at least one to two days a week.
cons:
It is difficult to change from different departments. Once you are in a specific area, such as compliance, or marketing, it's difficult to meet and network with others in other departments. 

Also, people tend to stay at American Express for either short periods of time or for years. I think the company could do well with hiring external hires more often to provide a new view / opinion of current practices.

review_title: Great Company but very bad management in a lot of departments
pros: American Express offer some of the best employee benefits I have ever received including a generous pension, private healthcare, discounted gym membership etc. They also offer flexible working hours and have many groups you can join. Working for such a big global brand also looks great on your CV.
cons: Although the Company overall is well worth working for, it really depends on what team/department you are in. There is a serious case of poor management in many departments - especially travel & lifestyle and marketing. Quite a few grievances have been filed against managers and staff regularly have to go to HR for advice. Very varied salaries for people doing the same job and unrealistic targets. All this leads to quite a high turnover of staff and quite a toxic work environment.

review_title: Sr Analyst
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
-Great work life balance. People leave at 5/6pm. Group commeradery with lots of happy hours and team events.
-Management always asked for upward feedback and actually learns and makes changes.
-You get your own projects to own at entry level. Most group have a flat structure (vs pyramid)
-Lots of organizations to get involved to help build leadership skills outside of the role responsibilities.
-Company sees itself as much more than a credit card company.
-You can like 10 different careers there and find your passion because the company allows lots of internal movement.
cons:
-Alignment with compliance and legal can drag on for months or even a year or more!
-Sometimes there can be repeative work being done because groups don't always talk to each other.
-If you don't have a supportive leader it can be hard to move internally. (Most people do though.)

review_title: Great place to work
pros:
I spent 8 years at American Express after University. The company were really committed to my development, helping me get my professional qualifications and always providing me with mentors and people to talk to about development. 
The culture and people are great and there is a strong sense of recognition. 
There is also lots of oppurnity for career development. I worked my way up the company, rotated around different roles and got to work in London and New York.
I always recommend to my friends and think it's a great company to work for.
cons: It's a large company and decision making can be slow. Also it needs to fight to innovate in a technolical evolving market. Senior leaders often just rotate around the business after being there a long time so processes often change and then change back.

review_title: Travel Counselor
pros:
Potential to grow in the company
401k company match
GREAT employees! Got along really well with everyone
cons:
Position wears too many hats for too little pay
Is not the fun role they made it out to be
Training essentially made it seem like you would simply be recommending travel plans by using extensive destination knowledge, however in this role you are primarily an order taker; someone calls in and you will only be "taking their order" for hotel, flight, and car arrangements
If I knew it was going to be so boring AND difficult (no room for mistakes), I would have never applied

review_title: Great place to work
pros:
The work environment in my last 2 groups has been great (Risk and Service Engineering).  Overall, a great workplace (the one exception that I know of being the call center, and even that isn't too bad compared to other call centers).

The "work-life balance" is good (a la, they typically don't expect you to work much more than 40 - 45 hours a week.  Vacation time is reasonably plentiful, etc.

Also, it is a very good place to work, and while it is difficult to get the large promotions from within, it is very possible (as compared to other companies, where I would be surprised if it were less possible).
cons: I'm not sure, but I suspect that compensation is only "average".  Also, like other large companies, there is a fair amount of bureaucracy, red tape, time wasted in meetings, etc.  However, I don't think this is specific to only American Express, but rather, all large companies.

review_title: Good place to work
job_title: Senior Marketing Manager in New York, NY
pros: American Express prides itself as a company that values work/life balance and for good reason.  With four weeks of paid vacation, frequent teambuilding events, ability to work from home (laptops are provided for all), and 9-5 the norm, the work environment is great if that's what you're looking for.
cons: If work/life balance is not what you're looking for, the pay-off of relatively low salaries is not that great.  You'll get paid about 25-50% more in comparable jobs in other financial services companies.  Decision making is also incredibly inefficient and slow due to the corporate culture of "alignment" (which basically means that no one wants to take ownership of projects/initiatives) and the highly-matrixed nature of business units within the company.

review_title: Could have been better, had the middle management been more cautious of people's basic requirement.
job_title: Team Member Personal Cards in New Delhi
pros: Salary package offered is comparetively better than what any of the similar company's offer, its a brand that carries effect and an impression of being the best in its field. Not only an impression but its the truth as well.... Would also like to say here, Was definetely proud of the director of our process. He well deserved to be called the director of american express india operations. cheers to you SIR just incase anytime you get to read this review.
cons: Being the best in the industries the technology used is comparetively old. The communication channels are not proper. The middle management is not up to the mark as it should be. People are treated as workers and not employees.

review_title: lack of empathy
pros: the company has amazing policies for learning and encourages employees to brush their skills
cons: you got be under a right leader.. there are few leaders which are partial and some who make use of your will to learn by making you do a lot of things but without recognition...they want the employees doing the non production for 40 hours a week but with no bonus. sometimes you find yourself working for 12 -14 hours for weeks but at the end of the month you go no bonus.

review_title: Great Benefits, but sending a lot of jobs offshore
pros: The people are great.  Encourage flexible work style and offer great benefits.  Have really enjoyed it.  Sad to say that job has been displaced due to fall out from Costco loss.
cons: Over last 3 years been at the Company have seen entire groups jobs being sent to India and the US people displaced.  Large majority of people at Desert Ridge location are contractors and most of those are also from India.  Seem to be losing the "America" in American Express.  Sad.

review_title: Great company to work for
pros: Diverse opportunities within a (large) company focused on employee development and customer first.  Lot's of ways to move roles, gain experience and travel (if mobile).  Typically to be successful you need to do your role extremely well and also get involved in other activities - stretch assignments, workplace events, team events, volunteer etc. Become a mentor if you can and help others.
cons: Possible to get lost in such a large organisation. Amex is high collaborative and relationship based, which can work for and against you - just be aware of the cultural nuances.

review_title: AXP can turn out strong leaders, driven from the top all the way down
pros: Ability to make your own decisions and influence change within the organization from day one. At Amex, the quality of senior leaders is incredible across all business units, there is no doubt that we have lost talented people over the years, but if you have been a senior leader at Amex for a while it's because you have proven yourself in many instances and can lead people. Ken Chenault is potentially the most inspiring CEO I've ever had the opportunity to work with/for.
cons: Similar to any big bureaucracy we sometimes get in the way of our own success by creating rules and processes that slow us down and don't either help our customers, employees or business (in that order).

review_title: The American Express Culture
job_title: Customer Care Professional in Brighton, England
pros: Good salary and good bonuses in most departments.
cons:
American Express has this culture that I've never experienced anywhere else, where it's always about who you know. Nobody here gets a specific job because they have experience or the right things for the role, it's always about who is your buddy.
- never expect credit for something you've done, you can have had the best stats for 6 months but nobody will care or give you credit for it, especially if you're working for another market than UK. 
- changes will come and they will never be planned enough.
- If you're on the phone, compliance will find new ways to make it harder to do your phone call every week. New unplanned rules that suddenly just appears.
- Teamleaders have no idea what people on the floor are doing and almost never have experience from that team.

review_title: It's not how well you do your job that counts
pros: The work life benefits are very good.  There is nice flexibility to be able to have a decent balance.  The onsite cafeteria is a nice touch.
cons: The way employees receive "ratings" is flawed and insulting and a company as respected as American Express should be ashamed that this is what is done.  If a cardmember senses that you are a minority, you have an accent, or your name is "American" enough, you will get poor ratings losing money and holiday options.  And while these rating numbers are deemed as the ultimate determination as to schedule and promotions, cronyism and favoritism seem to trump them.

review_title: Good starting place
pros: Great place to get experience if you're younger and starting off your career.
cons: Not a great workplace to grow your career. The company really likes to keep you in your current role and continue to move laterally when you can move externally and get a higher position with a much better salary. The problem with the company is that they speak a lot about having interest in their employees careers and growth however there is never any action from the words no matter how hard an employee tries to grow and accelerate their career at Amex. This is why a lot of people leave, why stay at a workplace that doesn't recognize your knowledge and experience earning less money than you should and not challenging yourself anymore since you're only making lateral moves?

review_title: Promotion is about Who you know
pros: Having previously worked for other large Corporate companies in the Financial Services sector, Amex was a natural choice for me. The brand is one you recognise and would associate with a great place to work.
cons: My concern is that if you are a fairly new member of staff and have not worked their for over 10 years, the opportunities to develop seen to be very limited, if you don't know the recruiting manager of any open position. It does seen to be about who you know. Some open positions are advertised internally, however you may not get a look in, as they have already been lined up for someone specific. Recruitment and Selection process is bias.

review_title: Exciting...challenging....frustrating...rewarding
pros:
Good benefits....flexible with time off...ability to purchase an extra week of vacation....working virtual
Employees are helpful and willing to assist each other in reaching office goals.
cons:
Technology is sorely lacking for such a large organization.  They don't seem willing to invest in bringing their technology up to date vs their competitors.  An organization this large should be at the forefront.
Overloading Team Leaders with so much "reporting responsibility" that they have little to no time to develop their direct reports.  The "development plan" program appears to be nothing more than an empty promise, as there is never time allotted to work on your plan, so you are rarely ever able to obtain your goal.
Rolling out "cookie cutter" initiatives, which are branded to increase customer satisfaction with no leeway given to personalize the initiative to fit the individual clients.  These often result in the exact opposite of what was intended.

review_title: Experienced some great leaders here, and one sociopath.
pros: People are pleasant to work with. Pay, benefits and working conditions are better than average and healthy living is encouraged. Most groups are internally collaborative rather than competitive.
cons: It is hard to get credit for doing outstanding work unless you are on a project team. They are starting to increase density of work spaces (rows) with no privacy and a corresponding rise in sickness.  Outsourcing most HR seemed to result in little oversight when areas of the company needed proactive behavioral correction.

review_title: Used to be good to work for. Now employees don't matter anymore - only the bottom line
job_title: Risk Operations Analyst in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Decent health insurance without waiting period, on-site nurse practitioner, gym and cafeteria.
cons: Pay is below average, pay raises are minimal; performance review system doesn't allow room for multiple high performers in one department (bell curve and ratings from only 1-3); jobs are continuously being offshored and/or outsourced; tenured employees are not valued; knowledge and experience aren't valued; no opportunities for true promotions; leadership is clueless about what is going on in the forefront and/or are ignoring it.

review_title: All these Reviews are fake!
pros: Incentive structure is good, you need to work ur xxx off for this
cons: They treat ppl as robots! Leaves not given for genuine reason, accusing without having substantial evidence. Not employee friendly at all. No much benefits for employees. Only recruit people who knows hindi where in its not required for the job, what about ppl who doesn't know hindi? They are also indians .very biased! Very bad experience.

review_title: Great Place to work with - Place for passion, innovation and service
job_title: Human Resources Analyst in New Delhi
pros:
AMEX is just not a brand in industry, it's a way of living. 

What do I do  for my living ?
I ensure the best customer experience and change their lives by making them aware about the great work opportunities that we have at AMEX. 

What does AMEX offers: 
 It's a mecca of Innovation, Customer Service & Good Citizenship . If you believe in doing good for people around, then this is the place to be. 

What to expect: 
1. A great work culture that challenges you everyday to bring the best out of you. 
2. Leadership to look upto that inspires to achieve not only professional but personal goals as well.
cons: It's a positive trap. The work culture is so great that at times it spoils you and you come back to AMEX even after leaving the organization.

review_title: Great Work/Life Balance, Less Pay than comparable banks/ marketing firms
pros: Very supportive culture - ideas are widely shared and syndicated so everyone is brought along in the process.  Management encourages movement every 1.5 - 2 years, so an employee can easily obtain a wide array of experiences across a discipline (markeitng, finance, etc).  Generous flex work policy in certain business units.  Amex is very good at fostering team building, employee engagement, charitable giving activities.  Management regularly shares their views via Town Halls.
cons: Every idea has to be syndicated/ approved - making change/ decision making painfully slow. Less pay vs. marketing/ CPG/ financial services/ payments companies.  Likability is preferred over performance in many cases - which leads truly high performers to leave after the typical 3-5 year stint.  The HSA health plan does not favor single earners.  While movements within a business unit are encouraged, intra-business unit moves can be more difficult to effect.

review_title: Awful management. No work-life balance.
job_title: Senior Manager in New York, NY
pros: Nice downtown location in NYC with great views of the city.
cons:
I've been with the company for a year now and accepting the job was the biggest mistake I ever made which I will be correcting in a few weeks.
For the past 12 months I had no work-life balance because of the ever conflicting directions that you get from senior leadership and the very poor management in my direct chain.

They have an awful and obsolete rating system so even if you do an excellent job you may not get the rating you deserve just because you have to be rated against your team. When the team manages different functional areas this rating system is simply absurd.

As someone else mentioned before, people get promoted to management roles just because of their tenure with the company. Again, if someone is a good individual contributor that does not make them good people managers!

Also, in terms of technology the company is years behind and the employees are decades behind.

review_title: Terrific company - particularly for marketing professionals
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
> Extremely bright talent - everyone is very well educated, extremely bright and you learn from everyone 
> Very well run company with very strong senior executive leadership who have been in place for quite some time and know what they are doing
> Great place for women executives and strong programs in place to help women succeed
> Very strong marketing driven and consumer driven company 
> Collaboration and teamwork are very strong across the employee base
> Consistently ranks in the top #s of places to work in several publications and I completely agree having worked there for 10 years in marketing roles 
> Absolutely the favorite part of my career thus far
> World Financial Center location in NY is awesome
cons: Geography is limited - if you want a senior executive role there, it's pretty much just NYC with maybe a few other options

review_title: Up and down depending upon the management in place
pros: One of the first major corporations to allow employees to work virtual.  Primary reason was to save money.
cons: Entirely too much posturing, butt-kissing, and politics.  By no means a team spirit. Unchecked management lacked integrity and there were too many spineless people who didn't want to do the right thing.  Used to be a good company.  Sadly, they have let themselves go.  A stellar former employee applied for a job at AX, after her job was eliminated. During the phone interview, upon hearing that she is currently unemployed, the hiring manager cut the interview off in the middle of it!  The recruiter will not call the candidate back.  This is just one example of how AX treats former employees.  Shameful.

review_title: Great brand, great people to work with
pros:
everyone strives for excellence
there are teams and resources to support salespeople
they communicate effectively throughout the organization

review_title: If you're politically skilled and aren't a squeaky wheel, you'll probably like the Blue Box.
job_title: Marketing Manager in New York, NY
pros:
As Fortune 100 companies go, American Express is a pretty good place to work, at least when the economy is better. I do think they try to invest in people (although not as much as they need to in compensation) and want employees to establish a long-term relationship with the company. 

Most people tend to stay at least a few years, and they almost never get rid of people for petty reasons. Senior management is generally strong and good at communicating information about the company. If you don't know how the company is doing, it's your fault, which isn't always the case at companies. There is good opportunity to move around, sometimes too good, but you're usually not pigeonholed into a certain for your entire career with the company. In fact, you had better serve in different functions if you want to move up the ladder. 

Pay and bonuses are simply too low (see below), but PTO is generous, particularly when you get to manager and above. The Culture Card is an underrated benefit for New York employees. Generally, people don't stay too late. Amex is particularly good for women and people with kids. In fact, it almost seems like women have better chances of promotion and movement in departments like marketing. Be prepared to shell out money every week for the wedding and baby showers.

Overall, Amex is a decent place to work (you won't have too many days when you dread coming to work, which I can't say about some other places I've been), and it's certainly a good name on your resume. However, there are definite issues that ultimately drive people away after a few years.
cons:
OK, have to start with compensation. The pay is simply too low given the background and performance they expect from people. To spend $80,000 on a brand-name B-school and end up with a $90,000 a year job just isn't worth it. This is New York, where a studio can cost $2,000 a month, and American Express's compensation just doesn't cut it. Also, HR openly admits (at least they're open about it) that the goal is to be no more than average for the industry. For a company that constantly preaches to drive for excellence, I think it owes its employees something a little better than mediocre compensation. Also, the health insurance HSA is poor. All it takes is one expensive prescription and that "savings" account is wiped out. The 401K plans stunk when they had Ameriprise funds, but they may be a little better now. 

The jobs themselves, particularly in marketing, don't even really warrant the fancy degrees anyway. If you're smart and a quick learner, you can pick it up quickly. Most of the challenge is navigating the acronym maze to find the right person to get done what you need to get done, not actual strategy. Honestly, when you get a new boss, you may be much more of a subject matter expert than that person given all the movement in the company. 

The culture can be a mixed bag. It definitely has a bit of sorority/country club vibe to it. You have to be very careful about what you say, because there is a lot of gossip. You can look forward to a lot of "Well, some of your colleagues say x" type of feedback from your manager, making you wonder what you did to deserve that kind of feedback when it seems like your colleagues think highly of you. You also pretty much have to do extracurricular activities such as employee satisfaction committees if you want to be considered a team player. Most of them are just bogus talking shops that waste time, but you better get on one, and if you become a Director or VP, you'll have to lead them. 

Amex is very matrixed and consensus driven, leading to a very slow-moving, conservative culture. If you're looking to do cutting-edge, exciting work, look elsewhere. This is a place for people who don't rock the boat. The slow decisionmaking process always pops up in employee surveys, but it never changes. You will be doing a lot of "aligning", having meetings to prepare for meetings, meetings to recap meetings, and of course decks. Without Powerpoint, half the company would have nothing to do, particularly VPs and above. I actually think Sr. Manager and Director positions are more interesting than most VP roles because as Director or Manager, you actually do things, rather than talk about doing them. The majority of people in the company come from the same 5-10 b-schools plus a few different financial services firms and big consulting firms. This leads to groupthink, along with the obsession with meetings and decks. If you don't come from these places, you will have a hard time moving up and you won't get some of the special access these folks get (particularly B-school interns and recruits). Promotions are overwhelmingly from within, which is great for the most part, but as you get higher up, there is very little new blood or original thinking. 

Oh, and if you hear the words "American Express Technologies" associated with one of your projects, run away, run far away. IT is bad at best, shows what you get by skimping and having your tech people in Phoenix instead of Silicon Valley or someplace with actually competent talent.

The review/rating/posting process can also be pretty phony and political, as it is in most companies. The "Goal" rating is pretty straightforward, except that if you exceed your goal but everyone else does as well, you may not get a top rating since ratings are based on a fairly strict curve. While you want the company to do well, ultimately, you don't want your colleagues to do TOO well, or you lose money. Brilliant system. On the one hand, everyone preaches the value of teamwork. On the other, you want to make sure your "teammates" do worse than you so you can get a better rating. 

The "leadership" rating is complete New Age corporatespeak BS. It's basically based on how well-liked you are. If you're a rah-rah "I love the the Blue Box and every idea my boss has is fantastic" type, you'll be fine. If you like to question and are skeptical, you aren't a "team player" or you don't communicate well. Also, while HR talks a lot about 360 feedback and giving your manager upward feedback, good luck actually doing it. Amex managers don't tend to react well to anything but the most benign "upward feedback". 

As I mentioned above, one of the really positive aspects to the corporate culture is the ability to move around. Just know that the politics surrounding performance evaluation apply to posting for new jobs. The mediocre performer who goes with the flow and is on a bunch of ESAT committees gets the rewards, while people who question things don't get very far. Understand that when I say "question things" I don't being contrarian for the sake of standing out, but pointing out legitimate issues that could hamper a project and offering alternative solutions. If you aren't high up the food chain, this kind of thing can be seen as not being a team player.

Also know that even getting a good rating doesn't guarantee you a promotion. People from the chosen B-Schools and consulting firms are usually favored. In addition to the rating you see in your evaluation, there is also a 'shadow rating' - the so-called 9-box, that you are not allowed to see. This basically determines how far you go in the company. If the higher-ups feel you're great at your current job but don't have potential for advancement, even outstanding performance may not help you.

Ultimately, the culture leads to people staying for a few years, and then most people get sick of the red tape and politics. Or, they realize that the company thinks they have maxed out their potential based on the 9-box and know they won't move up. You see very few older people in the Tower who aren't senior management. It's not so much the case at the service centers, where promotion isn't as big a goal. 

To sum up, Amex is a good place to build your skills and brown-nosing ability, but it's more of a jumping off point for most than a home.
