...can be bureacratic given its undeniably larger corporate nature, but less so than similarly large organizations.  

It is a public company with dedication to its shareholders, so occassional cost cutting is also part of the culture.  Top performers are well protected, though, and displaced employees usually find somewhere else in the company to go.

review_title: American Jobs outsourced to India
pros: Direct management value their employees and direct leaders genuinely desires to see your advance in your career.
cons: Direct manager and leaders have no control with upper management decisions. Past few years, the bottom line matters most - improve shareholders profits. The company "Blue Box Values" DO NOT support loyalty to their American Employees!

review_title: Not what it used to be
job_title: Customer Care Professional in Plantation, FL
pros: Benefits start on your first day of work. Pay is great.
cons: Ken has taken the heart out of American Express during his tenure as CEO. No one cares for the little guy and thinks that just by throwing money at the CCPs they will be happy. Lip service paid to "Work/Life Balance". What they really want is for you to balance your life around work.  Do more, in less time, with less resources. Faster, faster, faster. Take away the niceties from customer service. "We won the JDPower award 7 times, there's no way we can lose it, no matter what we do" is the new mantra. Stress is the word of the day. Heart attacks and ambulances weekly at the call center. I miss the company I started with.

review_title: Great place to work if you can avoid being outsourced
pros: American Express offers competitive salary, office perks such as cafeteria, doctor office,  and gym and a great work environment with growth opportunities.  They're still innovative and growing.
cons: While the benefits are decent, they are substandard compared to some of their competitors. No paid holidays in their industry is absurd. Expect to participate in the PTO buy back program to have a decent PTO balance.  The health insurance is also strange where you have to contribute to an FSA. Depending on where you work expect constant fear and worry over being outsourced.  Managers seem to be in constant meetings as well.

review_title: Sales
pros: Work life balance is excellent for sales as we are virtual. The company does a great job providing all necessary equipment needed and makes sure communication is open and flowing. Once you figure out the system and if you are a true self starter, there is unlimited potential for income. It's all about what you make of it. Management is supportive and I, personally, have excellent leaders.
cons: The sales effort is growing quickly and changes are not happening fast enough to keep up with the growth.  This is a challenging position and you need to be self sufficient and be able to bring along business with you to sustain yourself until you have a good book of business built up.

review_title: inconsistent management and workhouse in operations like most large TMCs
job_title: Senior Travel Consultant in Woodbury, MN
pros: good benefits; opportunity to work virtually, adequate training, ability to earn more for after hours shifts
cons: micromanaged like most call centers, managers changed frequently, some were nonexistent presence, some were on your tail about everything; confusing process for agents. Afterhours team felt very impersonal.

review_title: Good brand, good benefits, so-so work/life balance
pros: Good brand that is going through a difficult year. Very passionate and smart people dedicated to the company and its products. Good health and time-off benefits. Some groups are open to varying work-from-home arrangements. Polite office culture -- more passive-aggressive than outright aggressive. Lots of opportunities to change roles and expand your experience.
cons: Work-life balance not what it was. Pay is often higher at other financial services companies in NY. It can be difficult to get things done because of the "matrixed" structure (which is a nice way of saying everyone under the sun needs to weigh in on your idea before you can move forward)

review_title: Team Leader
pros: Great products and service levels are excellent. Co. really makes the effort to develop employees. Always striving to improve with little investment in the business line.
cons: Co is regulated and under strict compliance with specific verbiage that must be in each and every customer interaction.  Some employees state interactions with customers are not natural and does not allow them to express their knowledge due to compliance requirements. Company continues to downsize placing additional stress on current staff.

review_title: AMEX
pros: The pay isn't bad and the benefits are pretty good. They offer a good amount of vacation time as long as you don't miss your quota.
cons:
There are a lot of changes that occur and very little communication. While I worked there we were switched from salary employees to hourly and management never informed us. We were actually promised by the Vice President of the department that our job classifications would not change which was incorrect.
This is a sales environment so quotas are expected to change. Unfortunately as the quotas increase the amount paid for production decreases. You could easily be told to produce 40% more while experiencing a 30% pay cut to your commission.
After all of the changes the pay no longer seemed worth it. 
Mobility within the company is extremely political.

review_title: Good Company to Work for, not quite 'Great' yet........
pros: Continuously improving culture, career opportunities - particularly if you are geographically mobile. Open and honest communication.
cons:
Benefits are outdated and do not suit all needs. Knee-jerk reactions to business issues are commonplace. You get promoted if you are seen to be doing a lot, or speak the fastest and loudest.

Outsourcing and off-shoring has been excessive over the last few years but the true success of these actions is definitely limited. There is no accountability or tracking as to the success of these major decisions. Reward is given for implementation only and not long term success of the decision. Some of the claimed financial benefits which drive these decisions are questionable and dubious. The cost of poor quality and re-work plus communication difficulties are unfortunately difficult to measure and as such are excluded !

review_title: Good company, great brand, cut throat management
pros:
Excellent brand and company values, good base salary and benefits if you can find them.
Keep smiling and you will be fine.
cons: Aggressive brutal and selfish senior management,  if your face fits your ok - either that or if you keep nodding and don't have an opinion unless its the right opinion you will also be fine.  All depends upon which business line you join.  Everyman for themselves with lots of corporate ladder climbers all saying the right thing to the right person.  Such a large organisation slow to deliver on plans or make any changes.

review_title: You can survive
job_title: IT Business Analyst in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Touch on a lot of things, lots of different tasks, good pay if you don't have a degree. Good work environment. Possibility to become full-time employee. Management can be flexible in most cases.
cons: Lots of management flaws, don't provide enough training and in some cases no training at all. Some people don't do their job and you end up doing it for them. Things that other people don't want to do are dumped on you. Management lack of communication skills. Job title is not consistent with actual job tasks, as business analysts, you provide level 1 phone support to customers. Most employees do not treat contractors with respect and as second class citizens.

review_title: Project Manager
pros: Acceptable to a convenient work from home policy. Great facilities to work at, they provide a really nice cafeteria. Clear about training and policies. They had a great organization structure app that you didn't realize how cool it was until you work at another large company that doesn't have any updated and readily available org charts.
cons: Very political atmosphere. Directors and VPs would pass you in the hall and not even say hello unless you were in their organization. Typical bureaucracy for purchasing, installing apps, etc.

review_title: Not very many companies like this left
job_title: Concierge (High Value/Executive Accounts) in Tamarac, FL
pros: The bonus structure is out of this word and awarded on a monthly basis. If you work hard you  will be compensated well for your efforts. The people are extremely supportive and nice. There are always events being held for employees and their families and staff appreciation events just because.
cons: When you first start if you start out in the customer service department you usually get stuck doing a grave yard shift and don't really have the ability to have a life. It gets better over time if you can stick around long enough to see it through, some people just cant and move on.

review_title: Great Company to Work For
job_title: Customer Service Director in New York, NY
pros:
- Work-life balance
- Great benefits
- Corporate Structure/ hierarchy exists but very collaborative environment 
- Big company but easy to find who does what, and is responsible for what
cons:
- Given the work-life balance, no real complaints about pay but lower than competitors
- Recent management direction is not clear given changes in market forces

review_title: Solid company with room for improvement
pros: Decent work/life, flexible schedule, young company, smart people, great offices in lower Manhattan, prestigious brand, long term view, exciting new CEO
cons: Below market pay, bad groups have no work/life balance, few promotional opportunities,  matured business model, extremely political, not a meritocracy,  takes forever to make decisions / not agile, many middle managers are incompetent, managing up is rewarded while managing down has been increasingly disregarded, constant reorgs, absurd amount of time spent on planning processes and decks for internal consumptions

review_title: Very stressful and fast paced.
pros: American Express does pay better than most travel companies for a travel agent position.
cons:
Performance measurement is too stringent and is all about numbers instead of the whole person.  It used to be a fun place to work, but has become very high stress, with very little
job security.  They terminate talented people, then hire inexperienced people that take too
long to train and get up to par.   It's become too much of a revolving door.

review_title: The experience will be very dependent in which unit/team you are in
pros: Able to develop different skills and interests overall. Mobility is encouraged. Flexi time and working from home is allowed when in a project based role (Operations for instance is very controlled). Big focus on Compliance everywhere. The company is sympathetic to personal situations. Team work is usually the norm.
cons: Lack of resources to attend professional training. Negotiating a pay rise internally from jobs to jobs is a pain, mostly externals and graduates have the edge here. A lot of politics slowing down the work for nothing but their egos. There is often a restructuration happening somewhere but that is the norm in a Blue chip.

review_title: Great company horrible politics
pros:
American Express has many pros !
-work from home 
-Great bonus 
-flexible schedule
-6 weeks vacation with vacation buy 
-time in a half for holidays 
-Great training 
-lots of support 
-amazing systems 
-way ahead of the Times
cons:
Too many politics 
Favoritism 
I had someone personally target me to make sure I would no longer be employed at Amex. This person did not even work with me nor did they manage me. 
HR did not do an investigation when I reported issues that was going on. 
Targeted because I was a high performer. 
They tend to go after the people making too much money. 
I was targeted when I went on a medical leave.

review_title: Working at American Express
pros:
Very employee friendly with good work life balance.
Get to work with smart people.
Chance to explore different roles and job functions across geographies. Lots to learn
cons: Fairly hierarchical organization. You will need to learn how to navigate the hierarchy and politics to be effective in your role especially as you get to middle and senior management. Though the current CEO Steve is committed to breaking down the silos and increase cooperation between groups. Within his first month in the role he did away with individual business unit ratings in order to align everyone to a common goal and mutual success. He also revamped the performance review process so people can be judged on their strengths/expertise and their contribution to the goals rather than judging everyone across a range of competencies

review_title: Amex - Grim.
pros: Pay checks do arrive regularly.  Until relatively recently there was an exceptional health insurance plan available, and retirement was reasonable - even expected.
cons: The neverending careerists and finaglers - the users and ill-trained managers.  The constant fear of outsourcing, and even now, 'in-sourcing' - as a global business there's really no good reason, according to management, to maintain their costly US based employees.  The threat is always, always there - and as a result, new hires treat the place as a slightly more high level fast food job.

review_title: Good place to work
pros: Work life balance.  Professional development.  Culture and brand.  All in all, it's a great place.  There are a lot of smart people that work at the HQ (NYC), but outside of HQ I wouldn't say it's above average.  Most people who move within the company from the field to HQ, don't last very long.  But if you start out in NYC, then it's a great place to develop.  You can move anywhere in the company every 2-3 years, which is a huge benefit.  The culture encourages movement, so you can get a very broad experience.
cons: You don't make any money until your a second level vp (band 50)

review_title: My experience with American Express was contemptuous.
pros: Overall organizational culture is definitive.  Pay rate higher then market value. Excellent benefit package.  Several options to support work-life balance. On paper and in theory multitude of training and career path options.
cons: Lack of cultural, social, and professional diversity which affects promotions and the office culture.  Majority of leadership, e.g. direct reports; lack formal training and education.  Local leadership with local viewpoints which are extremely shallow and unprofessional. Severe and several incidents of favoritism that borders hidden and subtle acts of racism.

review_title: A successful company for a reason
pros: This is only my 4th month in this company, but I can see some of the reasons why it has been successful for so long. They seem to understand that good results are based on a long term investment,  training, good leadership and a reasonable working environment. They seem to be very committed to their clients and connect employee quality toward that goal. In the travel industry, this can be rare.  In comparison to their competitors, their employees get a high standard of facilities, training, equipment and a long term development perspective.  The pay is also one of the highest in the travel industry.
cons: Could improve even more in the technology area.

review_title: Analyst
pros: Peers are nice and helpful. Pay is  good. Hours are flexible. Don't really see much by way of office politics.
cons: Job title did not equal actual job duties. If you are hired as a contractor, you may be told that it is an extended training program to FT, but actually you are are competing with your training class for a small number of opportunities to apply for the FT slots, which is misleading and leads to false hope for some people who are looking for stability.  Some supervisors treat you like you are dumb and have very little patience for questions when you are beginning. Performance reviews are discouraging and not helpful because you never really know how you are doing overall and walk out without direction.

review_title: High stress. Training is lacking at best.
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Charlotte, NC
pros: Excellent pay. Good benefits. Work from home.
cons: Extremely stressful work environment. The training is minimal at best. They pretty much throw you to the wolves and expect you to learn as you go. Then, God forbid you should make a mistake, they blame you despite the lack of training. I worked there for 3 years and was always a top performer but nothing you do there is ever good enough to allow you to move up, despite what they claim. Finally left because I was on the verge of panic attacks every day when it was time to log in. Just not worth the pay.

review_title: Good company, hopefully better times ahead
pros: Strong, collaborative culture. Smart, high-achieving colleagues. Values-based leadership. Brand is respected and well-regarded by consumers and employers. Good benefits and work-life balance. Opportunity to move within the organization to chart your own career path.
cons: Increasingly political culture with less impressive leadership at many levels of the organization. Passive aggressive culture. Pay is below market. Slow decision-making. Lack of alignment and accountability and shared goals across teams. Strong talk about innovation but very short leash when it's coming to building new businesses.

review_title: Slow to Change
job_title: Senior Manager in New York, NY
pros: Amex was a good place to work - with lots of stability, smart people and a generally collegial atmosphere.
cons: The company was trying to be innovative in various ways but - like in many large, established businesses - only somewhat successful.  The company has a 'don't kill the golden goose' mentality which makes it hard to take genuine risks.

review_title: American Express - a great place in challenging times
pros: American Express is extremely customer focused and invests a great deal in the front line.  There is ample opportunity to advance if one takes ownership of ones development and education opportunities.  I have been able to move to new department,s roles and responsibilities, on average, every 2 - 3 years. The current economic environment has impacted American Express similarly to others in the industry but our business model is providing a bit more resiliency.  Our senior leadership seems to have an acurate view of the times and circumstances and communicates honestly and treats employees fairly.  Even when it comes to letting us go.
cons: We are in a stuggling industry and it may be quite a while before we recover completely.

review_title: American Express Audit Director
pros: Amex respects and encourages a work life balance; there are numerous flexible work arrangements.  The company also encourages internal movement to broaden skills sets and support employee development.  Compensation is good when factoring in annual bonuses, which are contingent on business and employee performance.  The company is large and diverse enough to provide a life long career of opportunities.
cons: Like most companies, the culture is dependent on the specific department.  At times it can be exteremely competitive and stressful.  The annual performance review process needs to be revised.  It is too subjective and political.

review_title: Too much work and too many meetings for too little risk-taking, autonomy and compensation.
pros: Ability to work virtual. Ample vacation/personal/sick days. Smart and highly motivated client management and sales organizations especially in merchant services.
cons: Passive aggressive and politically motivated culture.  Comp is well below industry average.   Too much time is spent on non-business building tasks i.e. performance mgmt (hours spent writing/rewriting lengthy reviews and dev plans, numerous meetings to discuss talent and argue over ratings), employee engagement (hours spent in meetings addressing low employee satisfaction survey scores and then executing activities which have little to no relevance to employees)

review_title: Great company if you can put up with the corporate b.s.
job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: Great premium brand; smart focus on "big bets"; generally treats employees with respect; reasonable salary (not great, but work/life balance better than most companies); reasonable career pathing opportunities (hampered in recent years by recession).
cons: Tends to have "flavor of the month" hot projects, most of which don't pan out and disappear quietly; values "innovation" over leveraging best practices in the marketplace... you get way more credit for inventing something, even if it is never executed, than you do for making smart business decisions; consensus driven decision-making makes it hard to drive the business and demotivates smart people who end up entertaining fools all day; soft on low performers; moving most folks to work in "first come, first served" cubicles that strips away all personalization of work area.

review_title: Great brand, nice core values, good work/life balance
pros: Work/Life balance is important to the company, as well as healthy living.  Lots of focus on supporting the personal needs of employees.  Benefits are great as well.
cons: Inconsistent senior leadership qualities.  Lower pay scale than other companies in the same industry.

review_title: Review
job_title: Travel Coordinator in Jersey City, NJ
pros: Excellent company to work. There's a huge potential to grow as a worker in American Express. I worked shortly for a corporate account, I had a very positive and good experience. Everybody in the corporate liked me .
cons: If the Manager is not on the site for any corporate account, they need to communicate with all the new employee and make sure that they are getting the proper training and behavior from the supervisor for that corporate account. Sometimes the supervisor ( COULD BE JAPANESE OR ANY...) is very rude and do not provide you and tools and proper training. It is not fair to the new employee. Even though the Manager is very nice and helpful but she is not communicating rightfully with the new employee and is not aware of the surrounding.

review_title: Solid Brand, Toxic Culture
pros: Solid brand name recognition, discounted cafeteria food
cons:
Toxic, Toxic, Toxic work environment.  Directors and above always talk about the culture and hire people based on fit.  This mean NOTHING when those people are passive aggressive, self-promoting leaders.  This has created an endless cycle of corporate culture with the same toxic people.  

Too many "sorority" cliques where if you're not political aligned, you won't get promoted.

review_title: Product Management Director
pros:
- Work-life balance
- Culture supportive of transition / career progress
- Employee benefits
cons:
- Archaic technology systems
- Leadership out of touch with technical innovation and opportunity
- "Lean out" mentality - very low risk tolerance from leadership
- Poor communication - from CEO down to Directors
- Way too much red tape to get anything done
- All strong product & tech leadership left in a flight of talent in 2015-2016
- Bias toward internal growth at the detriment of organization advancement / entrenched thinking
- Weak internal compensation policies
- Vested equity is not granted even in the case of severance due to shifts in business priorities, and even for top-ranked employees

review_title: A big company with a lot of potential...and alot of politics that gets in the way.
pros:
-Big company with a lot going on
-Diverse set of products and services
-Surprising amount of opportunity / lots of gaps in the business model
-Strong brand platform; people really like seeing the name on your resume
-Younger folks tend to be quite smart and sharp
cons:
- Highly political culture; 2yr shuffle in roles means almost no one is an expert in what they do
- Over emphasis on brand; drink-the-koolaid mentality
- Mixed talent among mid-senior leadership = highly political environment at VP-SVP level
- Lack of big-scale strategic focus; alot of tactics, less transformation

review_title: Fun, pays well
job_title: Risk Investigation Team Customer Care Professional in Phoenix, AZ
pros: First, the pay is pretty good! Second,  Benefits are amazing. They offer emergency child care for a few dollars up to 20 days per child.  I highly recommend working here if you like to move to other departments and explore new career opportunities.
cons: AMEX is a global company so with it comes the stress of not knowing if your department will be outsourced. No security. Also, be prepared for your metrics! A large percentage of your metric is to have excellent satisfaction surveys from card members and merchants. However, they do not remove bad surveys when they aren't linked to you. So, if you get a few Poor ratings and the customer clearly states they were speaking to another rep, you get screwed.

review_title: Not very challenging
job_title: Finance Manager in New York, NY
pros: Amex has great work-life balance, which is fantastic for spending time with family, and exploring cities and travelling.  There are fantastic people, and since the environment is very collaborative, you get to work with very diverse and talented group of people.
cons: Amex has not been innovative in recent years, and not break the glass barrier to try new products like NFP or Mobile banking.  They have always followed the competition in new technologies.  Even employees use old technologies (phones and laptop) and medicre services to get their work done.

review_title: Customer Service from an English Major's Perspective
job_title: Customer Care Professional in Atlanta, GA
pros: Since I work from home, the best things are clothing & travel.  Your clothing budget is low and you're not affected by traffic, adverse weather, or car problems.  The benefits are also good and the pay is adequate.  The vacation & sick time are great and the bonus payouts monthly are wonderful.
cons: Communication is difficult as is bonding.  Working from home also makes it difficult to learn by listening, and there tends to be less emphasis on training.  There is something to be said for interactive learning.  It can be draining at times because you can begin to feel a bit robotic.

review_title: Company Culture takes a downslide
pros: Company is great with being a contributor to the communities we live in.  They have great company benefits and company events.
cons: Base pay for IT personnel is below market.  Difficult to maintain work/life balance.  Didn't feel valued as there's no consistency across the company in how people are rewarded.  Your work experience depends on what organization you work in because some organizations have great leaders and others don't.  Didn't feel like the "bad" leaders were held accountable for anything.  No formal way to provide upward feedback.

review_title: Merchant Service Representative
job_title: Merchant Service Representative in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Great 12 week training class.  Great start salary. Secure parking. Insurance benefits start on day one. Vacation package is great and most holidays off.  Monday through Friday schedule.
cons: Ben as a dedicated employee.  Your job is NEVER secure.  You can be a top performer one month and fall below next month and be gone.  Your job performance is based on reviews.

review_title: Virtual Customer Care Professional
job_title: Customer Care Professional in Memphis, TN
pros: Great pay. Great training. Pay for internet provider. Coaches & TL's are extremely supportive. Cool atmosphere to be apart of... Meeting coworkers from all over the world.
cons: SURVEYS! Each CCP is rated by the card members they have spoke with. If you receive excellent 9's & 10's it awesome. If you receive a Very Good 7 or 8 it hurts your score & those surveys are suppose to be neutral.  Anything below that you're done with. 1 bad survey takes 3 or 4 excellent 9 or 10  to have it removed. You can be an angel to card member and they would STILL rate you bad. You may even get a survey that had NOTHING to do with you. Pure trash.

review_title: My dream job, my dream company.
job_title: Senior Analyst, Marketing in New York, NY
pros: First of all, you will be working with very talented people who are intelligent and have strong communication skills.  Secondly, the organization as a whole is very focused on people devleopment: you will be accessed 2/year on leaderhip skills and ability to drive results.  They are always focused on where you want to be in the next 3-5 years- and will help shape your goals accordingly.  Overall, the oganization is very open and specific with their goals & strategy.  Finally, great work/life balance.
cons: Very process oriented- long lead times!  You will find it takes lots of individuals to make a decision, given it is a matrix organziation and many teams are involved.

review_title: Solid company to work for
pros: People here are hard working, knowledeable and friendly,  the matrix organisation works well when every one is engaged in a project.   The company is very good on listening to staff needs and pays a lot of attention to employee engagement.  I've worked for one terrible VP (on maternity leave now thankfully!!!) however general management standards are very good.  Work life balance is promoted and management are keen to ensure that people are informed of any news as soon as possible,  good location in london for commuters near Victoria station.  Overall one of the best companies I've worked for,  and I've worked for a few!!!
cons: Pay isn't the best to be fair.

review_title: performance, learning and competency at one place
pros: I personally feel AMEX is one of the best organization which provides a proper work / life balance to its employees. At AMEX we adhere the Blue Box Values which sets us apart from the mass employees. Working with AMEX for the past 2years had been a great experience.
cons: Indeed one can not get everything at one shot, there are certain small shortfalls with us as well e.g some of the staff is treated differently than the other AMEX staff. They do not get equivalent compensation and benefits as the other staff.

review_title: Great Brand, Great Company
pros: Outstanding work life balance (EMPOWER allows you to control your vacation/time off, no need for approval as long as time is available), lots of room to grow. AMEX is very interested in making sure their employees find their right fit in the company. Very diverse. Talented group of people. I really enjoy working here.
cons: LOTS of changes! Be ready to move around. Although the work life balance is amazing, it comes with a price.  You must be very flexible, meet/exceed goal to get the schedule you desire.  If you have a family, the schedule can be a challenge.  I don't have a family and I do find the constant schedule changes difficult to adjust to.

review_title: They WERE good, but not so much now
pros:
opportunities for advancement, depending on department
opportunities to learn - career path planning, ongoing training
cons: the level of leadership really depends on what department you work - some have better leadership than others (Call Center Operatons and Tech were good;   Business Operations, not so much)

review_title: Great Company
job_title: Strategic Planning, Manager in Phoenix, AZ
pros:
Great company to work for. Most of the supervisors / Directors actually care about you and your development.Work can be challenging and problems interesting. You will need some kind of project management skills to continue to move upward above a manager level.
Covid-19 has brought out the best in this company, covering medical and testing expenses for employees, as well as ZERO layoffs at least until the end of 2020. Not many companies can say that.
cons:
Your direct supervisor has a huge influence on your experience. Good boss = good experience, while a difficult supervisor can leave a bad taste.
Not a ton of "team building" such as happy hours or team parties, so get to know your peers and supervisor.

review_title: Better than average. Politcal, untrained and lazy managers spoil the experience.
pros: Overall great place to learn about and implement world class customer service. Blue box values are about integrity in business. Great opportunities for learning. They used to provide $5000 per year for employee education, maybe still do. Lots of empowerment for decision-making. Giving programs are established to benefit the greater community. Beautiful values.
cons: Major drawback is politics that enable incompetent, lazy leaders to benefit from the system, promote their friends and hold back everyone else's growth. Another problem is lack of job security. Sweeping layoffs are followed by hiring at a lower pay rate.

review_title: Great company to work for, but...
job_title: Service Delivery Manager in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Great profit sharing, 401k and roth IRA matching. In the height of the recession, American Express was the only financial institution to actually make a profit. On top of that, during the same period, the president, Ken Chenault passed on his own bonus to trickle that down to employees. That's why I took the job. I know what American Express stands for, it cares about its people, has great benefits, has great stability, and you feel proud to say you work for this company.
cons:
Painfully slow to adopt new technology (completely normal for a financial institution)
Too many veterans and not enough fresh talent. 
Terrible work-life balance
Extreme and dated outlook on working from home/remotely. Working from home/remotely is frowned on and discouraged. If you're looking for flexibility, go elsewhere.
Outsourced, contracted and, in some cases, grossly underpaid and under-skilled technical talent.

Stupid bonus system for full time employees that "unofficially" unfairly pits you against your peers to determine what kind of bonus you're going to get this year. I say unfair because it's completely subjective, is based off of your top 3-4 "goals" for the year, and has more to do with who knows your name than how good of an employee you are. Unless you are really good at bragging about yourself or making yourself sound important, you won't get a good bonus/raise. It's just broken and doesn't award the people that make the biggest contributions to the company.

review_title: Great place to work... except
job_title: Executive Assistant in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: The culture is amazing, with very talented and savvy people.
cons: The biggest con is that every 3-5 years they look for ways to cut back, and it's always by cutting people. I worked there at total of 17 years, and was the victim of "reduction in force" five times. Three times I found a new job within. One time I left and was gone for three years. The last time happened last year, and I think this time it's for good. I've heard that they're hiring again, but it is a constant cycle and one you have to be aware of and learn to not take personally if you want to stick around for the long-haul.

review_title: An absolutely wondef  place to work
job_title: Global Account Manager in Chicago, IL
pros: Pay, benefits, bonus structure, and paid time offf are all so generous. It's also a huge perk to get to work from a virtual office, many of their positions are work from home.
cons: Although the pay and perks are amazing (e.g. 4 weeks vacation for a manager, starting immediately), the company expects A LOT from employees. You've got to be a major self promoter to make it here - and have thick skin. The company is always going through reorgs, cuts and the goal structure for sales and Account Development is very challenging.

review_title: Integrity suffers, good old boy network thrives during bad economic times.

review_title: Very busy with themselves, typical hire-fire mentality you find in most large corp's, unfortunately.

review_title: Use to be great place to work but over last few yrs deteriorated
job_title: Risk Manager in New York, NY

Leaders assigns jobs out to you and you end up in a new group/ boss and the message is, be thankful you have a job.

review_title: Good for certain people
job_title: Customer Care Professional in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: I loved working for such a well known company. American Express is highly respected and a great company to work for. Their benefits are great (dental, health, vision, tuition reimbursement, life, legal, PTO etc.) And people that work there are well compensated. It is not rare to meet people who have been there for 10, 20, 30 years. American Express also recognizes employees for things they do well (rare in corporate America these days). I would work for American Express again if I had the chance, and I enjoyed my time there.
cons: Work- life balance is non existent. Part time jobs are almost unheard of (very rare).

review_title: Leadership turned Amex into Titanic!
job_title: Senior Director in New York, NY
pros: The company has a great history of upscale products and services. Some of it's products still deliver good value for the price.
cons: Internal politics are a big deal. Amex leadership supports only the people close to them. If you are not part of the close team, you better find a job somewhere else. I worked for the company more than 10 years and it is sad to seeing it going down. There are so many decision making layers that just turn into bureaucracy. Innovation is just a word at Amex, not an action. With all the recent workforce reductions, there are no opportunities to grow int he company. Compensation is below market.

review_title: Was once a good company, now have lost their way a little
job_title: Senior Manager, Marketing in London, England
pros:
People are still relatively loyal and hardworking

review_title: Salary
pros:
Lots of travel-related benefits.  You can apply for the Platinum card.  Work from home position with regular business hours.  They provide all of the equipment and pay for internet access as long as you can connect with an approved provider.  
Excellent pay and bonuses.
cons: Training is a little crazy because they don't quite have it figured out and not consistent across the board with the different trainers as to where or what group you'll start with and then possibly be moved to your main group.  Lots of time spent testing on security and privacy measures.  If you've never worked on the booking systems used by travel agents, it may be intense in the beginning until you get used to it.

review_title: Relationship Manager-Credit Card Sales
pros:
Brand is just amazing

review_title: Hostile work environment
pros: The benefits and location are excellent. Standard benefits for Fortune 500 company. I love that they have a health clinic and mobile dentist onsite.
cons:
The culture in the Credit, Fraud & Risk department is toxic. 
There is no training or systems documents for new employees. You are on your own. Directors have no time to train their new hires, but expectations are very high to get up to speed quickly and you are called out publicly if you don't live up to the expectations.
It's even worse for women who are at an extreme disadvantage in this environment. 
I would not recommend this company to anyone. They pay well, but the stressful environment doesn't make it worth it.

review_title: On the way down, the view isnt as nice
pros: Good entry for the resume.
cons: AMEX was a very good company years ago...the golden years were the 1980's. After 9/11 the company never quite recovered and the gloves came off way before the current financial crisis. While never competent at basic processes like human resource management and information technology, AMEX did very well through creative marketing and talented people. Now, it's just another lame duck bank which doesnt even pretend any more to be at the forefront of current management trends. Unfortunately, AMEX has run out of ideas and is quickly running out of talent. The only long term plan is short term survival....while AMEX will be around for a long time, it's a pale shadow of the exciting and dynamic company it once was.

review_title: Great company for long-term career!
pros: For such a large, old company, the leadership is quite progressive.  Built on solid foundations with an innovative spirit, working there can feel like being part of a start-up without the risk.  People are generally collaborative in nature and the sky is the limit on what you can accomplish.  There is an atmosphere of accountability as well. I witnessed people at all levels taking responsibility for all aspects of their performance- good or bad.
cons: As a large company, sometimes there's disconnect between what's happening at the merchant/customer-facing level and the executive level.  Those incidents are usually resolved quickly and acknowledged as opportunity to improve in the future at all levels.

review_title: Merchant Services
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY

review_title: Promised we wouldn't be part of global layoffs, then did so anyway
job_title: Account Protection Specialist in Salt Lake City, UT

review_title: Steadily going downhill
pros: Above average pay and benefits, relatively speaking. Doesn't suck as bad as the competition.
cons:
Stress level is through the roof. More and more responsibilities are piled on the employees as the staff gets cut repeatedly and less new employees are hired. Most employees now do 3 or 4 former employees' jobs. Pay is rarely 'cut', but the ever-changing bonuses become harder and harder to attain, which results in worse pay each year. 

Management is extremely pro-gay and pro-female, so prepare to be forced to listen to gay groups caroling in the hallways, etc., and be fired if you complain. Qualifications are of little importance as long as you're female/gay. 

Never ending errors and system 'glitches' that never get fixed. Double check your statements! 

Some managers are great, some are horrible, so your experience at Amex will greatly vary, depending on how lucky or unlucky you are regarding which team you end up working for.

review_title: Call Center Mill - New Accounts Associate
job_title: New Accounts in West Valley City, UT
pros: The benefits are good: medical, vacation pay, and sick pay. The building is nice.
cons: Working in a cubicle, taking call after call all day long burned me out. Customers called in and were upset and yelled about their bills or deals they didn't get on a new card.  AmEx expects you to have low avg call time and after call wait. You have to login within a couple of minutes of your shift and they watch your stats really closely. It was a call center mill to put it simply. I had good stats, but it still burned me out.

review_title: Global Company that is highly constrained by bank holding status
pros: Large company with a global mindset and presence.  Extremely supportive of employee growth and driving opportunities from within.  The technology organization consist of highly tenured and loyal employees.  Overall compensation is consistent with the market.
cons: Recent change in technology CIO is taking the technology organization in a new direction.  The vision is exciting.  Unfortunately, the exec team is unable to make decision in a timely manor, impacting the overall organization from implementing the infrastructure and cultural changes required to be successful.

review_title: Pays great, but can be frustrating
job_title: Senior Marketing Executive in London, England
pros:
The people are great. I have really enjoyed everyone that I have met and worked with at AMEX.
The work life balance is great, this may very team to team, but my team can work from home 1-2 days a week, which is really nice.
cons:
AMEX is an endless changing beast and sometimes people get fired and others are expected to pick up their work streams for an undetermined amount of time without additional compensation. 
Sometimes fees like upper management does not care. They will meet with you to hear what you have to say, but then just blatantly disregard it.

review_title: Good company to work for
job_title: Travel and Lifestyle Consultant in Brighton, England

American Express as a company does have the right values and I have always felt supported in terms of health and family issues.
cons: Schedules are quite strict, the daily breaks are set, you must adhere to them or request permission to change them. Your time and performance being tracked all the time can be stressful but this is what you sign up for when working for a big corporation.

review_title: RIM-COE: All depends on the Team, experience in some teams is horrible

5.) Lack of respect for employees and their aspirations

review_title: Good company to work for.

review_title: American Express invests in its most valuable resource, their employees.
job_title: Corporate Account Administrator in Phoenix, AZ
pros: AMEX is a well organized corporation in that training is precise and useful to employee.The benefits offered by AMEX illustrates how they value their employees. And if security is an issue, AMEX has it covered. As an employee you'll pass a minimum of three check points before reaching your work station.
cons: The interview process is somewhat like interview for a lead acting role. I guess it designed this way to see how well the prospective employee processes information spontaneously in front of a group of peers and management. Also, if you are a working parent this is not the company for you. Finally, if sitting in place for long periods of time is a problem, this is not the company for you.

review_title: Great company with consistent values
pros:
Amex stands by core values:  integrity and doing the right thing.  There is a rock solid sense that you will be backed up if you do the right thing for customers and you do everything in an ethical way.  Amex takes this really seriously and it is one of the reasons I have stayed over 10 years.
There is a lot of variety - you can move around every 2 years or so and experience different roles and functions.
The people are outstanding - smart, caring, and friendly.  I have made great and true friends at Amex.
cons:
The review system (stack ranking) was instituted in the last few years and has eroded the core value of collaboration.
Given the environment, promotion can be hard to come by.
Doesn't pay as well as its competitors.

review_title: One of the 'good' corporates, lots more positives than negatives and a lot of really great people.
job_title: Senior Business Development Manager in London, England
pros:
Strong employee policies (benefits, entitlements) and supportive culture (employee networks, 'office floor' chat, etc)

Really great brand, 160 yrs of history and success, and a clear long-term vision

Major player in a fascinating industry where things are changing very fast

Huge organisation - unlimited potential for sideways and upwards career moves
cons:
Risk-averse, which includes their approach to cost controls - as such, the cyclical cost-cutting/restructuring efforts are unavoidable

Participants in the 'annual performance review, stack ranking' performance management methodology which can be frustrating and bureaucratic

Being such a large company it has layers and layers of hierarchy and matrix of functions which can mean getting stuff done requires a lot of "stakeholder alignment" and sign-offs before anything can happen.

review_title: Compliance Analyst in the FIU
pros: AMEX hires a lot of people without relevant work experience, so this position is a great opportunity for someone to change the trajectory of his or her career.  AMEX looks good on your resume.
cons:
If you're in the FIU outside of NY, career opportunities are fairly limited.  The organization is setup as follows:

Analysts and Senior Analyst (these are the people that do the actual work)
Managers and Senior Managers (basically their job is to babysit the analysts)
Directors and VPs (they babysit the managers)

review_title: Collections Specialsit
pros: I have never worked for a company that took better care of their employees while at work. They have a full cafeteria that costs a fraction of what it costs to eat out and a break room filled with games.  Benefits are affordable and a great 401k program.
cons: The job itself is awful. American Express knows this and that's why they cater to their employees while they are there. It is emotionally and mentally draining.  They are very strict on adherence and how long you're in after call work. The schedules are terrible you will have to work a weekend or work till 9pm if you want a Monday thru Friday and good luck getting a weekend off for PTO.

review_title: One of the best places to work...
job_title: Marketing Manager in New York, NY
pros: American Express prides itself on Work/Life Balance.  Obviously, there is some variation based on the group, but overall, does a phenomenal job of it. There are many opportunities for development and advancement because Senior Management is goaled and evaluated against whether their direct reports are achieving their development goals. It creates a culture of collaboration and mutual respect.
cons: As a large company, it is sometimes difficult to move things quickly or without at least 3 other parties wanting to have their say on an issue.

review_title: Transformational
job_title: Business Systems Analyst in Phoenix, AZ
pros: American Express has a keen focus on development: personal, team, technology, company, and world development. With a passion for excellence, a true pursuit of integrity, and a collaborative spirit, my company is increasingly becoming a superior firm that I can proudly support. Leadership is strong and opportunities abound.
cons: American Express has many opportunities for process improvement, mostly in the realm of establishing lean, balanced processes. With a tendency toward a heavy process, my company's renewed vision for optimization and flawless execution will strike a positive balance of efficiency. For me, process improvement (and the associated change management) is both fun and intuitive. Thus, this drawback is actually an exciting challenge for me.

review_title: Sweet n Sour experience after working for > 7 years
pros: The culture, compensation and benefits were impeccable in India prior to 2008. However, everything seems to have taken a downturn ever since.
cons: Promotions and career growth based on relationships rather than on merit. When I joined, there were no issues as far as resources were concerned, but after 2008, it is a struggle to get the basic resources like obtaining a back-up when laptop crashes, getting a notepad etc. Although work from home is an option, it interferes with career growth. Also, fitting the bell curve leads to unfair rating practices and sometimes leaders use it to pursue their own selfish ego

review_title: Great place to work IF you DO NOT work in customer service
job_title: Platinum Customer Care Professional in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: The only good thing I can say about working here is that I liked my coworkers, the pay was decent, and the food in the cafeteria was very good. THATS IT.
cons:
This is a VERY stressful call center environment. The turn over rate in the customer service department is high for a reason! I had to deal with abuse day in and out from customers who speak to you as if you are a dog. The supervisors you call for "help" are not very helpful at all. In fact, they all hate their job, which makes yours even more difficult. I had to deal with other departments dumping (transferring calls without letting the customer know) calls on me when the customers were upset so that they wouldn't have to get a bad survey. 

OH and the survey system they have in place is ridiculous and put in place just to avoid paying you a bonus. The bonus structure is very generous, but you will never see an ounce of your money you worked for if you get a bad survey.(bad surveys to amex means a survey that is not EXCELLENT, so even if the customer rated you VERY GOOD, its still bad to them). Bad surveys stay on your report for 30 days and commission is paid once a month so you do the math. 

The schedule is soooooooo strict. You are not even allowed to use the bathroom whenever you want with out being questioned. You get one 40 mins lunch break and two 10 mins breaks if you work an 8 hour shift. If you don't handle your bathroom duties during that time, you can expect to have a meeting with your team leader about you not adhering to your schedule. 

The PTO structure is also generous (23 days per year) BUT, if you work in customer service and you want a federal holiday off you will have to use your PTO days. But you can even forget about having any holidays off your first year working there. Time off requests are based off seniority and availability. Once everything is taken, then too bad for you, you just lose your days. The sick time was accrued at a rate of 4 hours per month and you can roll over sick days.

review_title: Travel Counselor
job_title: Travel Counselor in Salt Lake City, UT

cons: Lack of management support.  Perks to the job are  a plus but you never get to use them.  Very stressful job.  Customer surveys are great if you do  an excellent job.  However, if you get a survey back for someone that you  didn't help, they do not take this survey out of away from your rating.  Impossible to meet or exceed the goals that are expected.   Do not recommend being a Travel Counselor for this company.

review_title: Stress!
job_title: Customer Service Representative in New York, NY
pros: The company offers a great benefits package to their employees and the vacation time isn't bad either.
cons: I think I lost about a decade of time from my personal mental stability and physical health.  This job isn't for the faint of heart, as not only will you be dealing with exceptionally difficult situations on a day-to-day basis, but you will also have to deal with extreme metrics that are sometimes not even realistic.  Career opportunities are a joke, volume of work is insane, and work/life balance can be challenging.

review_title: Well-paid resources
pros: Pay is good. Benefits good. Work-life very good. Amex doesn’t have to be your life. The stability of a big company that always makes money is very comforting.
cons: They refer to their people as resources. They’re moving away from the outsourced contractor model but the mindset runs deep in the culture. Someday perhaps they’ll make an honest transition to a digital product company, but for now they are still struggling to understand the differences between products and projects. review_title: Very political

The Ombudsperson is a joke, the company does not care for you at all.

review_title: Great Company to work for

review_title: Been here almost two decades, that should tell you I think it is a very good company to work for!
