Extremely Cheap - does everything they can to not pay employees their bonuses. The salaries are incredibly low for a such a company
Colleagues are sharks, they will push you under the bus to get ahead
Have to book all vacation time in January for the rest of the year
Bonuses are based on luck of the draw

review_title: Program Manager
pros: Good benefits and compensation.  Easy going.  Good severance packages.
cons:
Yearly reorganizations and staff cuts.  Big, siloed, administrative, slow.  A lot of nonsense.  Very political at director and VP levels, focused on their "brand" and impressing individuals above them to plan their next promotion instead of efficiently managing their organization.  Career is driven by who you know.
Many in IT have extensive work with staff in India and high percentage of contractors.  This results in many calls at odd hours, and the unnecessary burden of working with people with poor professional experience, organization skills and communication skills.

review_title: Plenty to learn but plenty of platitudes.
pros:
Good opportunities to network across functions. 
Many colleagues are approachable. 
Individual growth is down to the appetite of the employee; strong work ethic will be rewarded. 
Strong advocation of mentoring relationships.
Individuals feel well-connected to organisation's objectives.
cons:
Constant change in various departments over 2-3 year cycles over longer term planning gives appearance of seeking magic bullets. 
Major projects can be carried out without enough input from end users or informed stakeholders, producing suboptimal results. 
Initial cost vs long term quality balance in process overhauls not addressed adequately.

review_title: Benefits and drawbacks
pros: Good work/life balance, work is challenging. Employees are encouraged to pursue opportunities and develop their careers. Frequent feedback is provided in the form of anonymous surveys and management to employee interaction. Depending on the Business Unit, employee metrics for measuring success are reasonable and clearly defined.
cons: Depending on the Business Unit, it can be somewhat to extremely difficult to accomplish objectives and feel challenged by the work. Both software and hardware systems are aged and can be unreliable. More "traditional" ways of thinking often hamper fresher, more efficient ideas. Depending on the Business Unit, politics and territorialism can make it very difficult to accomplish objectives, and favoritism can play a stronger role than quality in determining promotion and/or recognition.

review_title: Great Company.  Great Leadership.
job_title: Employee Relations Consultant in Greensboro, NC
pros: Great culture that allowed employees to develop and explore other opportunities with the company. Core company values that led company in a positive direction.  Smart leadership that positioned company effectively during economic environments.  Great work life balance, compensation and benefits
cons: While the overall company was great, if you worked in an area where you do not agree with leadership decisions your only options are to leave for another position internally in a different department or externally.

review_title: Enjoyed the ride
pros: Well perceived company with respected, distinctive product. Good training and benefits. Positive workplace for women.
cons: Beaureaucratic, and hung up on credentials as opposed to talent.

review_title: TCA Business Consultant
job_title: Lead Business Consultant in Glendale, AZ
pros: The overall culture is amazing and the people you work with are amazing. pay was pretty good!
cons: You could close 23 deals over the phone a month- but if the business's are NOT credit approved- you DO NOT get credit or job security for selling over phone and converting sales. You only get credit for business's that are approved only for their business cards. You become consumed with making monthly goal

review_title: Hands down the best place for work-life balance from a big corporation
pros: the friendliest and most collaborative colleagues I've ever had.  there are a ton of development opportunities (but only if you seek them out).  work from home and taking vacation is encouraged as well as taking on jobs outside of your expertise.  very big on diversity and including all backgrounds.
cons: pay is below market average, but overall will work less hours a week.  with any big company there's a lot of politics to weed through to get promotions, the top bonuses, etc.

review_title: Great Environment, Great Benefits, Great Work-Life Balance
job_title: Senior Data Analyst in Sunrise, FL
pros: I'm given freedom to work from home when I want, the Sunrise campus has plenty of amenities on site, and the environment (Analytics Area) is relaxed and friendly. I never work over 40 hours a week unless I want to. Everyone is very friendly. Leaders do not micromanage and are mostly supportive.
cons: At the manager and director level, there are a lot of old guard that I feel limit progress of the company because of their outdated mindsets and unwillingness to learn new technologies. Amex will almost never fire or reassign someone though. No Stock Purchase Plans is also a downer.

review_title: Good company, smart people, bureaucratic
pros: American Express hires very smart people that are energetic with a sincere willingness to drive change within the organization.  Though times were challenging in 2009, the company made some tough decisions, but has done a good job of reinstating some of the previous practices.  I am very pleased with Ken (Chenault) as CEO.
cons: Though the company has made significant efforts to encourage alternative work arrangements, the culture has not truly embraced these which limits employees ability to progress.  Upward movement is extremely challenging if you are not located in NY or willing to relocate to NY.

review_title: Sincere Commitment to Career Advancement and Worklife Balance
pros: Your leader is likely going to be evaluated by their ability to develop a winning team - career development, especially internally, is a very transparent process - your current leader will be working with you to help you identify your next internal role/promotion. From a worklife balance perspective, American Express is very flexibile with telecommuting and with providing a generous amount of time off, including 4 extra summer flex days.
cons: You are not going to make as much money as you might at other financial services companies. There is a fair amount of politics that goes on in terms of how work gets done/access to information and people, but that's likely true for most large companies.

review_title: Definitely one of the best run companies I've ever been with
job_title: Customer Care Professional in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Great benefits, outstanding employees, and care to give employees a nice work-life balance.
cons: It can be very stressful and demanding work on the phones. You're literally tied to the phone your entire shift with very little time to breathe. There were plenty of days I never had the opportunity to utter a single word to the person sitting next to me because the call load was so heavy.

review_title: travel (now GBT)
pros: work at home options and good vacation allowance.  Ken C seems to be a nice guy.   Ed Gilligan was wonderful.    Use to be a great place to work and exuberated pride in the product - prior to 2009.
cons: extremely stressful, impersonal, departmentally competitive goals which hurts customer service, very internally unorganized, constant changes hurt customer service- and provide no security for employees, poor internal communication.   Don't express your opinion or else attitude. not open and honest about JV, compensation cuts due to bonus plan restructuring

review_title: Back in the 80s
pros:
Salary and benefit 
Some people are pleasant to work with
Fancy title to add to your resume 
A great place to start your career
cons:
Constant layoffs and restructuring 
Some people in certain group are toxic 
Old school and mentality, out of touch with current market, trends and the world 
Lack of innovation, manual processes, mundane tasks
Lack of team and system cohesiveness 
If you are creative, self starter, and a go getter, this might not be the right place

review_title: Good while it lasted
pros: Great pay, decent benefits - initially thoroughly enjoyed the work and responsibility
cons: Slow to change, WAY too many road blockers via management and layers of steps to get anything done.  By the time something made it through, it was no longer relevant.  Constant concerns about being displaced - spent over 20% of my time there under official displacement notice so my job could be moved to India.

review_title: Very Good Company
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Sunrise, FL
pros: Great Pay, with nice bonus pay. Beautiful Building. Nice people, great atmosphere, Excellent Cafeteria.
cons: Training isn't good at all. Floor managers act like they care, but they don't have your back. They should replace the managers with a software program (it would be the same result). 80 to 100 inbound calls a day, and they want to limit the time you talk to cardmembers. They keep changing their quality standards every quarter, to get you to mess up, and then 3 strikes and you're out the door. No Room for advancement. (Only Temporary advancements, then they make you go back to your old position.)

review_title: Need to be on the right team
job_title: Senior Analyst in New York, NY
pros:
Decent work life balance (depending on the team) 
Great maternity and paternity leave 
Good PTO/Sick time
People that work here are really smart, and really pleasant to work with for the most part.
cons:
Personally I work on a team that has leadership not invested in the actual work, but more presenting the work- which is fine but I dont really have much guidance and have quite a bit expected of me. 

Youre broken down into band levels which essentially determines everything about you before they know you. Band 30= entry(1-3years)
Band 35=associate(3+)
Band 40=experienced(8-10 yrs experience)
Bands above that are not interacted with much- at least on my team.

review_title: Fun work environment and good people
job_title: Senior Analyst in New York, NY
pros: The people I worked with were really great and I had a great time there and met a lot of people in such a short amount of time. Employee engagement was a part of the company culture and there was a lot of diversity and people seemed to always be willing to help or chat about their line of work. Advancement opportunities are out there but it helps to know people in the right places. Work/life balance and benefits are pretty solid.
cons: Like any other place, Amex re-orgs its teams pretty frequently as well; not sure if it’s a proactive or reactive measure. Pay is relatively low compared to other companies and bonuses are only paid out to Managers and above.

review_title: It's a tough working environment
job_title: Customer Care Professional in Kuala Lumpur
pros:
Senior Management takes care of their employee. They understand how stressful the job can be and are always open to talk if you need any assistance with work or struggling with your personal life.
Classroom Training and OJT provided. You can count on your coaches to guide you through the learning curb. 
Attractive Salary + Allowance + KPI Target Initiative.
cons:
Because it's a financial institution, all calls are recorded and monitored. It can be quite stressful as you always have to courteous on call.
After the learning curb, the job can be quite tedious as you're mostly on call 8 hours a day, 5 days a week. (Senior Management sometimes provide logout for meetings) 
Night Shift (Servicing US Market).

review_title: American Express Rocks!  Pinnacle Travel Sucks!
job_title: Systems Administrator in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Great I.T. Team!  Best I.T. manager and director I've worked with in my long term tech career.
cons: The Pinnacle Travel Service team.  Supervisors, especially Lora is very demorilizing.  Lots of racial and demoralizing harrassment toward others is tolerated in the service center environment.

review_title: Over all great place to start work -grow quick - leave - come back - rule the roost!
pros: Strong integrity business ethics and values, Great work place for women, policy driven, easy to excel, confident attitude towards competition, Formal and independent approach of managing talent, employee centric, great rewards & recognition, brand & service conscious, Highly level of employee engagement (on paper),
cons: Tactical, VP's stint too short, very year-on-year approach, incompetent senior mid management, Traditional thinking, risk averse which in turn effects business, Conservative (most aspects) , poor collaboration skills within teams, prefer tenure over talent which effects pay and productivity, double standards in expectations, Favouritism, slow on innovation, do-less-pronounce more-look busy and we will promote you.

review_title: Great Company, Too Much Outsourcing and Reorgs
pros:
Great Company to work for
Work Life Balance
Remote Opportunities
Easy to move internally
cons:
Outsourcing is a huge issue in IT and quality of work has suffered greatly due to this
Internal moves are easy, but pay is not comparable to external candidates
Too many reorgs, in other words, layoffs. Company has gone through 2-3 this year

review_title: Takes a lifetime to actually accomplish something
pros: American Express is overall a good place to work.  Great people, teamwork and a focus on excellence.  Great benefits, work from home a huge plus and salaries in line with the industry.
cons: Politics, Politics, Politics...Senior Leadership over commits and expects those doing the work to deliver.  The scope of the project changes mid-stream after months of hard work.  Change is not cascaded downward in the organization but must be pushed out from mid management.  This causes resistance and push back.

review_title: Supportive culture with work-life balance, up or out mentality
pros: The work life balance at AXP is fantastic - they really support working mothers and their adjustment.  Many of us also have the ability to work from home at least one day each week.  Also, leaders are extremely focused on development and take professional development very seriously.
cons: AXP is very bottom heavy and has many people at the analyst/manager level.  However, if you don't progress up fast enough, they push you out.  Also, they claim that it is a very collaborative environment, but in the race to the top (or a promotion), people can be back-stabbing and competitive.

review_title: Corporate Card Sales Manager - Micromanaged...
pros:
Great company
Rich value proposition
Home office
Reasonable pay
cons:
Working in Canada for an American company, Canadian offices usually get looked over or is a last minute consideration. 
From 1990 - 2004 this was a great company to work for. Since 2004, they have hired 4x the sales staff and become a micromanagement organization.  Sales employees are required to 'log' everything from their home office. Managers can remotely supervise you and get 'alerts' when you computer is inactive for > 15 minutes... horrible work environment for an independent sales person.

review_title: Sad Trajectory
pros:
Solid Benefits
Large Organization allows motivated employees to gain exposure to new areas without leaving the company.
Competitive Salary
cons:
Current CIO and his Executive Team is horrible.  CIO is an autocrat and his team is too scared to address it with him.  The culture of the organization is more about protecting one's job than it is about doing what's right for the company.
Constant Lay-offs are just the way it goes at Amex.  Ask any employee, and they will have either been laid off or know many who have.  It absolutely destroys culture and motivation.

review_title: MM Corporate Payments - Manager Account Development
job_title: Manager Account Development in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Virtual work from home and great company benefits. The team members are great to work with. Flexible for vacation time.
cons: Overworked, lack of engagement with employees, same employees get recognition over and over for one project, Directors only recognize Managers for leadership performance and not Goal achievements. Role is account development but the pay is not pay for performance. Lower salary compared to other companies with same type of role

review_title: Great Pay for Customer Service/Sales
job_title: Customer Care Professional in Phoenix, AZ
pros:
great pay
great opportunity for bonuses
several opportunities for growth
pay increase is performance based, not based on seniority
sick time accrues monthly (4 hours each month, never expires as long as you work there)
downtime
tuition reimbursement if you're not on any form of counseling
cons:
constant hours on the phone all day
strict sales numbers policies, you must offer or you are more than likely on your way out the door
short break times
8 hour shift gets 40 minute lunch and 2 ten minute breaks

review_title: Good chill job
pros: Good Work life Balance. There are a lots of hardworking, intelligent and humble people who help each other in learning.
cons: Too hierarchical- Each work goes through lots of layers with little improvement though most of them.  This creates a situation where a few analysts working and a lot more people advising. In such situations much effort goes to satisfy the fonts and colors of PPTs for each person rather than actual work. Learning opportunity may seem  low after a point of time.

review_title: American Express is a great place to work (not just a slogan!)
pros: Great benefits; great opportunities to be a part of a global company and global projects; great brand and name recognition; lots of on-the-spot recognition and 'gifts' for employees; diversity efforts are very important and are not just the 'flavor of the month'; lots of women in leadership roles
cons: political posturing; huge hierarchy/beaurocracy--sometimes takes forever for projects/ideas to be realized (if at all); lot of favoritism related to promotion--not always the most competent person is the one chosen; layoffs common; people in senior management don't always communicate information like they promised to; working 24x7 is tough to balance work/life; don't have childcare arrangements

review_title: In Good Times An Outstanding Employer; In Difficult Times A Ruthless Profit-Driven Company At The Expense Of Employees.
job_title: Information Security Engineer Senior in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Company environment is extremely professional yet work shift flexible and business casual at most times.  Workforce is professional, experienced, and well educated.  In good times, pay and bonuses are above average.
cons: Management culture is mostly resistant to positive change and innovation in the area of information security and regulation compliance unless facing legal scrutiny.  In difficult economic times, layoffs, pay cuts, and budget cuts are rampant and affect mostly the lower two thirds of the pay scale.

review_title: Good company, but PMPs suck
pros: Ability to telecommute, Pay is in line with other companies, Bonus is good and profit sharing.  FMAL and management working to support you.  Nice environment.  Ability to pick your own holidays.  Good amount of PTO.  Good medical & dental.
cons: Managements lack of competency. Favoritism.  Spineless leaders.  Too many meetings.  Decisions take to long to make.  No flexibility to work at campus nearest to you.  No process to rate your leaders.  Performance process SUCKS, it's how well your leader like you, not to mention a bell curve.

review_title: Extremely Corporate
pros:
Fellow colleagues are smart, professional, driven, energetic, fun
Strong brand recognition and team culture 
Opportunity to reward employees through team events, networking engagements, etc.
Opportunity to work on a global team and travel to UK, Singapore, Australia, etc.
cons:
Extremely corporate and very bureaucratic; senior leaders use their positions to push people out  when they don't like you...not based on your actual performance
Employees are encouraged to move on after limited time in role (18 months); causes "gaps" in handing off roles and knowledge
Leaders do not help outside hires transition in to the company with on-boarding, training or adequate support/resources
Company communicates they have a flexible work environment but certain leaders frown upon you working from home

review_title: Not what it used to be
pros: Good work life balance and flexible working arrangement and schedule. Company consistently cares about employee family life and presents opportunities to ensure that family is first.
cons: Some in management are woefully under qualified to lead people. When I started we had a leader that inspired the the team. She moved on to better opportunities and it was clear that her replacement didn't have the knowledge, leadership skills, or experience to command a team that size. After the new leader came in, she created an inefficient hostile environment and a mass exodus of good talent occurred on our team including myself. The new leader consistently garnered bad reviews from her employees on the pulse survey and at times was standoffish and unapproachable and seemed overwhelmed.

review_title: Disappointing
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Good work-life balance, good benefits, trusted brand, good location, great cafe and gym onsite.
cons: Lack of diversity especially at the management level, very cliquish culture, minimal growth opportunities (particularly for minorities), bureaucracy slows productivity, culture that's resistant to change, broken technological systems with little to no investments made to fix them.

review_title: A company you can grow in
job_title: Senior Brand Manager in London, England
pros:
American Express really push you to explore your personal development and strive to move around the business. 
There company is so large, you can easily move roles within specialist areas (such as brand, digital, consumer marketing, b2b marketing) and find yourself with 10 years tenure before you know it
cons: The company is so large, you often find yourself working in niche functions, such as sponsorships and there's so much work to keep you and a small team busy on just that - it's hard to gain breadth of experience without moving roles/teams/departments.

review_title: Has great work culture and promotes out-of-the-box ideas
pros:
1. Work culture is very professional and warm and friendly at the same time.
2. Global exposure since we get to work with other teams (in the same business unit/department) based across the globe. 
3. Managers promote creative freedom and show keen interest in an employee's skill development.
4. Lot of flexibility and benefits such as - work from home, healthy and organic meal options in cafeteria, Maternity / Paternity programs, festive discount coupons etc.
cons: 1. Slow vertical growth. That is, it might take long to get promoted to the next level. Because their organization structure is such. However, I have seen extremely talented people climb the ladder quickly either by Internal Job Posting or by building good connections and showcasing their abilities.

review_title: PTO could be better
pros: Flexible and focused on technology and customers. Great culture.
cons: PTO is deceptive because the number of days they give also includes all holidays.  So you are required to use PTO for any holiday.  Other banks will give you about 20 days plus all federal observed holidays.  That's around 27 days off per year.  Amex only gives about 23 days so that's translates to 16 days if holidays are not counted.

review_title: Amex is a great place to work if your spouse has lots of money.
job_title: Risk Manager in New York, NY
pros: Work Life Balance.  4 weeks vacation + 4 flex days in the summer.  Work here if your spouse is independently wealthy and you don't need the money.
cons:
Pay is terrible.  Never had the money to take a vacation and enjoy the time off.  

Top down management was very stifling.  Any new ideas were blown off.  

No transparency for promotions and boss didn't care to think about my long term career at Amex.  No visibility to high impact projects.  Didn't feel appreciated or recognized by leadership.  Didn't take advantage of my skills either.  They didn't know how to promote good people either.  

Anytime I suggested to get some skills I thought could help me in my job, I got shot down.  Any interaction outside of my team was viewed with suspicion and discouraged.

review_title: Great company to work for if you are seeking to balance your personal and professional life!
pros: Supports work / life balance and flexible work arrangements, including virtual and part time positions. Offers great benefits including training, tuition reimbursement, 401K match, employee assistance programs, legal assistance program, etc. American Express is actively involved in giving back to the community, and encourages employees to do so, particularly through the employee charity gift matching program. Good development and growth opportunities. Measures employee satisfaction and holds leaders accountable for improvement where needed.
cons: Because of company size and upgrade ramifications, the progression in technological improvements is slower than optimal. Individuals or groups supporting specific processes or applications seem to constantly change. The result is lack of ownership and slow response and resolution when issues arise.

review_title: Economy has not been kind
job_title: Director of Customer Service in New York, NY
pros: Strong work from home program and BYOD solutions.  Emphasizes professional development and individual growth.  Anchors the business on connecting the brand to the respect of it's customers.
cons: Very siloed organization.  Uses a curve for performance rating the forces people into the lowest rating level even if they exceeded goals.  Pressure from shareholders drives business decisions whether or not the are right for the company culture.  Work from home limits career paths as many roles are still anchored to hub locations.

review_title: Vice President Marketing
job_title: Vice President, Marketing in London, England
pros: It's like a club of bright, switched-on professionals.  They are open to trying new ways of building business and give a lot of autonomy at every level.  The pay is above market rate for similar levels of experience, and the HQ are very conveniently located in Victoria.
cons: It's like high school all over again, with people jockeying for position to be in the popular crowd.  In order to "prove yourself", there is pressure to initiate re-organisations every 18-24 months, which is a painful distraction from getting things done.  Some top management encourages rivalry instead of collaboration.

review_title: Good company to work for, just in a bad location like Gurgaon
pros: Superb environment and work culture. All my leaders and colleagues are highly committed to their work and are highly professional. A lot of fun too! Oh yeah, we have a cab facility for everyone who lives in Delhi NCR.
cons: Gurgaon traffic is the main turn off. If you are unmarried and are trying to find yourself an accommodation here - you literally have very few options. Most often than not you will have to share the flat with someone you don't know.

review_title: Supervisor
pros: The company provides great benefits and clubs to join. The pay is average compared to other companies. The other great thing is that they teach you the best customer service out there.
cons: The pay is average and you need to learn about a lot of different products. Also, the expect for you to be available 96 percent of your schedule. l do not know of any other company that keeps tabs on your availability as closely. They do not keep in consideration, bathroom breaks or if you had a rough day and you need to log off for a moment.

review_title: Travel agent wah
job_title: Travel Consultant in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Tons of overtime along with incentives to work overtime during the busy season
cons: The refer to friend process leaves a lot to be desired. You get written up even if poor reviews of the company have nothing to do with you and there are specific comments from the card members stating their issue is with someone else, or another department completely. Poor rtf scores affect your raise, bonuses, and your shift. Lots of micromanaging.

review_title: American Express - corporate America to its fullest. You want to climb the ladder? You have to sign up for life.
job_title: Senior Manager in New York, NY
pros: Work life balance is the number one reason to work at Amex. Secondly its a great place to start your career, its a great training ground full of free resources and information for learning critical business skills.
cons: You have to play the game. Everybody talks fluff and you have to play along. People do not like constructive confrontation or debate of any sort. Things take forever to get completed - so much red tape. Getting promoted can be hard. You must have a solid network of people that will vouch for you. Its all about who you know.

review_title: ok place to work
pros: work culture is very nice.respect for people.good compensation.
cons:
Management should be sensitive towards the employees who have left too. andf help them to get their accounts setlled .It shoulkd not be out of sight out of mind.You are so customer centric that you do folllowup calls and C-SAT calls but what about the employees satisfaction.

It really hurts after given my sweat and blood to the company for 4.5 years that it took 1 year for my clearance account to settle.leaders were least bothered.no follow up....

review_title: Loyalty and Experience Doesn't Matter Upon Reapplying for Postion Which was Outsourced
pros: Great managers and coworkers, always room to learn more, constant changing technology, nice benefits, gives bonuses, fair when it comes to performance reviews.
cons: Jobs easily outsourced for less money. Work long hours and no extra pay or time off to benefit from going above and beyond. Won't rehire after being laid off.

review_title: Director of Technical Delivery
job_title: Director of Technical Delivery in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Aggressive bonuses for Director and above based on productivity (Cash & Stock).  Great benefits outside the norm.  Company culture focused on ethics and doing right by customer.
cons: Technology group undergoing massive change, I experienced 9 new leaders in 3 years.  After becoming a bank, company saw increased regulation taking many departments by surprise.  As a result, new applications needed to be developed via extreme programming causing high turnover as you cannot expect qualified resources to work 12-15 hour days with no end in sight compounded by no VP cover during inevitable escalations.

review_title: American Express ROCKS!
job_title: Senior Marketing Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Wonderful company to work for! Amex cares about it's employees and invests a lot of time and money in people support and development. Excellent work-life balance. Great leadership!This is a company that cares about its people and also cares about giving back to the community and the world.
cons:
Sometimes it can take a long time for decisions to get made, but mostly because Amex is a consensus driven company -- so it's understandable and not a job dis-satisfier.

It is definitely a big corporation so there are a number of bureaucratic processes, however you would find this at almost any big company. The pro here is that Amex invests a lot in its systems, training and resources.

review_title: HATE IT
pros: there are many virtual (work from home) positions.  i honestly can't think of any thing else that is a pro, i hate this place.
cons: horrible management, everyone passes the buck.  constant stupid training calls that don't really train you and are just tooting the horns of someone in 'advisory services' or marketing.  management loves to talk about how great they are.  don't ever say anything that is not completely positive b/c you will be black listed.  stupid development plan process.  training new hires is a joke, the current employees have to do it all in between their own work, management can't do it b/c they don't have a clue.

review_title: Emerging Markets need more focus on talent development
pros: Great place to work and build a career.   Focus on work life balance is authentic.  Great brand that opens lots of doors.
cons: Historically the contribution from international markets has been very low and emerging markets not relevant.  This has resulted in minimal attention from senior management thus propagating mediocrity in these markets.  Leadership in these markets get paid alot for so called hardship postings resulting in huge inequity among peer set but the real tragedy is that these people are transient and never deliver on expectations.

review_title: If you want fast moving, exciting projects, than Amex ain't for you.
pros: Good work/life balance, good benefits, easy to grow your career within the organisation - people are encouraged to move role every 18 months - 2 years.
cons:
Overly collaborative nature of the organisation can make it very difficult to deliver projects effectively. Too much emphasis on job titles, and not enough on experience and expertise.
Like most large financial services companies, projects tend to be quite conservative and long winded.
My onboarding experience wasn't well designed, spent much of my first few weeks bored, with little to do.
When people move roles internally, there is very little handover, which can be very frustrating.
Middle management is a bit of a mixed bag, a few good people, but many poor middle managers.

review_title: Worked as I expected
pros:
Extremely flexible schedule with ability to schedule last minute paid time off
Laid-back management style
Accountable to stats, not manager/supervisors
Decent pay
If you need a job that you won't go home thinking about at the end of the day, this is the place, just make sure you are making personal improvements as you work in this job (pursuing a degree and getting other relevant skills) as this job will not leave you in a marketable position when you get tired and decide to leave.
cons:
No room for growth
Job becomes stale and robotic (call center employee)
Little incentive to advance
Survey results impact your position for bidding on new schedules; you might get stuck with a schedule you hate, even though customer feedback on surveys is sometimes intended for other call center agents.

review_title: WAS one of the best companies to work for now slowly stagnating - Gurgaon
job_title: Senior Business Systems Analyst in Gurgaon, Haryana
pros: Good Culture, Good professional environment, Salary structure in general is slightly above market rate, Internal job postings system is awesome.
cons: Since HR is outsourced its no longer employee friendly, employee related policies need to be re-evaluated, most people issues get solved by "my way or the highway approach" which is again HR related, external hiring of managers is blurring the work ethics and culture which was earlier strong, Slow with technological change

review_title: If you want to work for a company that has an excellent record of treating employees fairly and honestly this is it.
pros: American Express provides insurance and benefits that are hard to find at this level in many other employment opportunities. review_title: Great Pay and Benefits, Controlled Culture and Poor Acceptance of Alternative POV's
pros: Generally, Amex pays higher than market for entry-level professional (Band 30) and above positions.  They also have great benefits, from health and welfare to expanded offerings such as tuition reimbursement and the legal plan.  In addition, on site programs such as College Coach and on-site snow day child care make it hard to beat.
cons:
The exceptionally high salaries paid to employees have caused me to compare American Express to a ruthless drug dealer.  They lure you in with the sweetness of the salary and benefits addicting you to the "high", but once you are "hooked" they begin to turn the screws demanding more and more output.  The incremental increases in compensation tends not to keep up with the pressure, resulting in a growing personal dissatisfaction.  However, you cannot leave because you are unable to find comparable compensation elsewhere.  

Senior Management follows the same communication cycle every year:  1st quarter - Last year was a banner year, however, this year will be one of our worst.  Everyone needs to buckle down, cut back and prepare for the worst.  2nd quarter/3rd quarter - Results have been better than expected!  We're up where we should and we're down where we want to be.  Let's stay on course and try to finish the year strong!  4th quarter - Wow!  It was one of the best years ever!  We're killing the competition and profits were amazing.  Then it repeats all over again.  As an employee, you cannot tell when there truly is a reason to be concerned about any given year during the first quarter.  It always made me feel like the Senior Management did not "trust" employees with the true information about the current environment.  It would be much better to say that the company operates extremely conservatively during the 1st & 2nd quarters of the fiscal year.  I'm not a child.  Please don't act like you need to "shield" me from the operating philosophy and performance of MY company.

Amex operates so conservatively as to be inefficient.  The company does not want new and innovative ideas that may incur cost, even when that incremental cost could have huge returns.  A prime example is the condition of the technology at Amex.  It is outdated, difficult to maneuver, and extremely inefficient.  The systems used by customer-facing reps are so dilapidated and outdated it is embarrassing.  These should be priority 1 for upgrade and redesign, without delay.  The restrictions on technology development are so overbearing that it feels useless to suggest any new ideas or changes.  And this feeds into the internal culture of "we'll make it ridiculously difficult for you to make any progress so eventually, you'll stop bothering with your nonsense".

review_title: Highly Enjoy Working at American Express
job_title: Finance Manager in New York, NY
pros:
Development: Good opportunities, particularly in Finance - if you are a strong performer, there is much room to move, and to move upward quickly. The roles within Finance are varied and generally interesting. Here are some of the groups where you could work, at either HQ or LOB levels Planning & Analysis, Strategic Business Analysis, Pricing / Deal Support, Results Analysis, Investment Optimization, Controllership, Treasury, Tax, etc.

Work/Life Balance: the company really promotes work/life balance. Most days I work 9 to 6:30, and it's very flexible if I need to leave earlier. Occasionally work from home when I need to. There may be a few late nights in a month (after 7pm, ranging to maybe around 10pm max). It's generally manageable in terms of career and also personal life.

Salary: They changed the Bonus Incentive compensation structure recently, so for Managers, your bonus is all in cash. It used to be 50/50 cash & stock. This past year I banked a $24K cash bonus, which isn't bad considering the very good hours I work (for NYC), the development opportunities to move around and grow my career. Keep in mind I'm a Manager, at the Director level, you're looking at $40-$60k cash bonus + $20k in stock. VP's will generally take home a $50-100k cash bonus + stock + other leadership performance type bonuses. So while we don't pay investment bank salaries, neither does AmEx work you to death either.

Generally you will find the Managers at American Express to be in the 25-35 year old range, and Directors can be in the 28-40 year old range, and VPs+ and above can be in the 30-50 yr range. Obviously the star performers would be young. So if you're talented, you can rise at AmEx quickly, work good hours, and bank $100k - $250k a year (depending on level). Not shabby.

People: Very diverse at AmEx. Obviously many Asians and Indians, given it's Finance. People are generally incredibly very nice, easy to work with -- make sense, given that HR really screens to ensure a culture fit within AmEx. We like collaborative, easy to get along with, and smart people.
cons:
So if you're just an average or low performer at AmEx, you may find it hard to move around and grow your career. Every 18-24 months is generally a range of time where you would be applying for a new role within the company. If you're not very good, you would find it harder for a new team to want you.

Networking: you will need to do a fair amount of networking (surprise, surprise) at AmEx in order to move around. I think that's the case though with any big company. It obviously helps to network and the more people u know, the more opportunities.

Dead Weight: A company like AmEx is not very cutthroat or lean - it tends to carry a lot of deadweight around in terms of people who are not very good, but may still be at the company for a while.
