job_title: Premium Travel Consultant in Toronto, ON
pros: Job security as a well established company, and great colleagues for the most part. Thorough training with lots of support for learning.
cons: Those with seniority who work day shifts get priority over everyone. The office culture is set up for engagement during 9-5 hours but the majority of the Travel team works late evenings and weekends. I miss out on a lot of events and do not even have a place to buy food as the cafeteria closes after lunchtime. If you aren't performing well enough you'll hear about it, but get little recognition for performing well.

review_title: Way behind | Dated culture
pros: If negotiate properly, you can get a good package and few perks at workplace
cons: the technology department is very outdated. Leadership is not technical, however takes most of the technical decisions. No scope for developing tech. skills. A lot of bureaucracy. The company culture needs a lot of development. Leaders expect employees to treat them a gods.

review_title: Delivering extraordinary customer care and developing future leaders.
job_title: Team Leader in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros:
American Express is one of the most admired companies in the world.  Upon learning of my position at American Express, the reaction of friends and family has always been, "Wow!  That's a great company!  Congratulations!"
Beyond the prestige, American Express offers its employers countless of opportunities to be a part of the process to deliver extraordinary service to its customers as well as make a positive impact to its shareholders.
The leadership development for myself and for my peers goes beyond any expectation I had coming out of college.  I have received intimate learning sessions on proven leadership tactics, such as MBTI, Crucial Conversations, and Situational Leadership, under the Adult Learning Theory.
As for career development, the company offers many opportunities to network with influential members of the leadership team, supports efforts to meet peers in offices around the country (such as Pheonix, Salt Lake City, and New York), and encourages employees to take on projects that require multi-department teamwork.  The most impressive resource American Express offers for leadership development is a personal mentor to guide employees through all aspects of their career with the company; the mentor is always a senior leader at American Express.
cons:
In my time at American Express, I have found two negative aspects about the company.
The first is typical amongst most large companies: Poor communication from the top down.  In specific, managers of front-line employees (employees dealing directly with customers) have little initial input on the directions upper management decides upon.  Instead, these managers receive general goals to achieve, and must express these goals effectively to their employees and only when the direction headed poses challenges do managers have the opportunity to offer solutions.
The second issue I have stems from the first.  Managers at this level, because of the large gap in the heirarchy with their bosses, are not influential enough to have spirited debates with their superiors, but are very vulnerable to disrespect from their direct reports.  To offer a metaphor, being a front-line manager at American Express is like being between a rock and a hard place: You can't talk to your boss the way you might like to, but your employees are at liberty to express their emotions, how they see fit, to you.

review_title: Amex = great company; provides growth opportunities, ability to move within its divisions & promotes talent from within.
job_title: Dedicated Account Representative in Greensboro, NC
pros: Senior leadership seems to have the best interest of the company as well as the employee in mind.  Work/life balance is important & practiced in every role I've worked in with the company.  Like any job out there, a large portion of your "work satisfaction" really comes down to your immediate leader.  I've been extremely fortunate that most of my leaders have been strong performers & genuinely cared for the development of their direct reports.  American Express also provides the ability to move within its many divisions and is focused on promoting talent from within.  If you have the will to succeed, are willing develop your skills and put the effort into it, American Express is a great place to work.
cons:
The newly retooled medical benefits took an average benefits package and made it slightly below par.  Also, when work load demands it, professional level employees can be expected to put in more than 50 hours per week.  While one's effort is usually recognized for the extra hours, it can be discouraging if you're continually asked to do this.  While I'm sure this is not unique to Amex, it is still a downside. 

The inverse is also true & can have an equally negative affect on your job satisfaction.  If you're looking to coast in your 9 to 5, Amex is large enough where you can do the minimum if you have a poor enough leader.  It makes it challenging to accomplish your tasks/goals when you are forced to work with these individuals.

review_title: American Express a good place to work
job_title: CCP in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: I think that overall working at American Express has given me the knowledge of how Credit Card companies work, and the basic functions of banks.  This knowledge is something that I'll be able to carry with me for the rest of my life.
cons: At times it seems like opinions are not heard,  Many times my functions deal with how the card member responds to marketing solicitations.  When are mail piece has misinformation about the card product then the job can become more difficult.

review_title: Amex supports diversity
pros: Amex offers full benefits and flexible work schedules.
cons: Has a tight reign on job advancements and training. Very old boys club with upper management. Pay for entry level is very low, upper management retain salaries similar to entertainers.  Outsourcing is very big for customer service.

review_title: Good place to spend 8+ hours a day, frustrating matrix culture
pros: Look, Amex is a good place to have to go every day. The work is stimulating, the people are (for the most part) bright, and the company is one of the good guys in terms of CSR and responsibility in financial services.
cons: The matrixed, cultlike culture focuses on "band level" to a fault and decision making is frequently based on the interpretation of a senior leader sneeze vs. the right move for customers and shareholders.

review_title: survey driven
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: Its a very big company with a big name and sounds prestigious. They are extremely concerned with employee satisfaction and their ranking among large companies so they go out there way to have the employees think and say good things about the company.
cons: They are so concerned about the associates feelings that sometimes they give too many chances to unproductive employees and that angers the productive ones.  Management hands are tied and always seemed to be focused on the next survey coming up

review_title: Great place to work.
pros: Company is truly led by visionaries.  Leaders are focused on where the financial market is headed and decisions are made accordingly.  It is a large organization, but you feel like you are working for a small company because management, even the most senior leadership, make an effort to know you as a person.  Work life balance is great.

review_title: It was okay
pros: Very staff oriented policies and procedures. Being an employee is great in American Express. From the moment you join you are taught that you are creme-de-la-creme.

review_title: Great Benefits and Perks, Upper Management needs to re-think Metrics

pros: Great benefits.  Frequent gifts and lunches.  Free flu shots.  Free nurse on location.
cons: Customer surveys count against representative even if they were for technical issues or another rep.  Direct management has no control over surveys but will write up a rep regardless.  One track counseling - behavior and performance count against you in one track instead of individually.

review_title: Nice people, Nice culture, company you can be proud of
job_title: Lead Project Manager in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Good culture and environment with really nice people. Salary is very good, very fair.  Exec level team is innovative, communicates with employees worldwide, and cares about involvement in the community.  Can be proud of company.  I switched to Amex from a company that offered none of these things.
cons: Long term employees should go work at other companies where there is no community involvement, poor exec level team, and unprofessional co-workers.  they complain about small things.  Sometimes it's slow, bureacratic and hard to move things forward.

review_title: An iconic brand and a smart leader in the corporate world
pros:
Amex is huge. This is a door opener for anyone you try to do business with while at Amex.  It's public, and very corporate, but fair and treats employees well. There is tremendous opportunity for growth. 

Amex's culture and values are beyond fair. It is a company that takes being honest, legal and trustworthy very seriously.
cons:
The corporate culture can mean that things are sometimes slow-moving.  There are sometimes several levels and layers of approvals. 

The compensation may be lower than competitors.

review_title: Used to be good, Now really bad

job opportunities

review_title: Interactive Development
job_title: Senior Manager in New York, NY
pros: Opportunity to move around, generally good work-life balance (though big variability depending on team/leader), interesting projects.  Smart people.  Company has an old business model but is actively trying to push the envelope and innovate.
cons: Slow to change.  Re-organizations are a way of life.  Relatively lower compensation for NY.  Some business units have highly political/entrenched cultures - particularly the one protecting the 'golden eggs' of Consumer Card.  No clear advancement path - very individual initiative-driven.

review_title: Customer Care Professional
job_title: Customer Care Professional in Brighton, England
pros: Young and vibrant culture within the New Accounts team. Lots of people from different countries. The department was an amazing opportunity to make friends.
cons: The work was mainly the same. Not a lot of room for change, and even if one tried to push through a change, this took ages - even though this was encouraged by the management. The work is doable for a year, but if you're a graduate, you will be very very keen to move on to a different position after this period. Also, the bonus scheme came across as rather unfair.

review_title: American Express is living in the dark ages relative to performance appraisals
pros: Great brand, decent benefits, smart people
cons: The culture is not collaborative or innovative , as they deploy Jack Welch's "Top Grading" philosophy.    So, people are only collaborative to a point, and they try very hard to make sure that at least one person is on their boss's radar screen to get the lowest performance review rating at the end of the year.

review_title: overall a good place to work - depends upon the team really

 Age old softwares which they are never willing to change. Just patch work mostly when it comes to enhancements.

review_title: Excellent opportunities across the company, work life balance, and UK offices
pros:
Great company to work for if you wish to move around and experience many different jobs and learn many skill sets.  Good opportunities for career progression if you're flexible and have good core people skills.  Friendly place to work.  Strong executive leadership team.

Very flexible working arrangements that allows individuals to manage their own work life balance.  Excellent for those with families - one of the best companies ever worked for in this area.  Good place if you enjoy volunteering.  Generous salary, bonus and benefits.  Many opportunities to move overseas and support the Company in one of the International markets or US.

New building in Brighton with a good gym and excellent classes, also recently renovated office in Burgess Hill are highly recommended.
cons:
Heavily US focused as can be expected and as there are greater opportunities for career progression in the US, less experienced staff can find themselves getting a promotion much quicker than those based outside of US.  This can actually present a great opportunity if you are happy to move over to the US.  

It can be difficult at times to grow internally as a specialist as the Company proactively encourages staff to move around and tends to then hire externally into more senior specialist areas.  While this is less the case in US it is felt more in other countries like UK.

Year end based on a bell curve that can create competition rather than collaboration between those at the same grade and encourages business teams to work in silos.

review_title: Simply a great place to work.
pros: A very correct, human and caring company that puts a lot of effort in making the employee feel at home.  Both team leader and HR played a crucial role and managed to deliver a work environment that invited me to go the extra mile.
cons: The recruitment process demanded some patience but from the moment I was accepted, local HR took over and handled my employment   in just a few hours. I'm very grateful for their help.

review_title: Amex wants your money but not your jobs

So they still want to make profits from North American customers but dont want to leave the jobs here.  The talent in those countries is dismal at best!  Local banks do not outsource!

review_title: Innovative HR
job_title: Human Resources Analyst in Phoenix, AZ

review_title: American Express is a great, if not perfect, place to work!
pros: (1) Management's attention to work/life balance, especially given our industry and HQ location (NYC), is exceptional. (2) High level of management integrity. (3) Employees can take pride in working for a company that believes in doing right by our customers -- both card members and merchant partners. (4) AmEx also is a good corporate citizen; we do and/or fund a lot of charity work where we are, and around the world. (5) Very female-friendly -- if not at the very top, still, a high number of female executives. Also, maternity policies are very generous.
cons: (1) Matrixed organization can slow down decision making. (2) The flip side to having so much work/life balance is that the pay does not stack up against other financial services companies, at least not at the middle manager level and down. (3) The cafeteria gets old fast, and there aren't that many other good food options in the World Financial Center.

review_title: Great place to work (as long as your not an admin)

cons: For admins: minimal chance of promotion without an ivy league mba, the workload is ridiculous, the amount of work you do for the compensation you receive makes you think twice about your future there.

review_title: Once a good employer
pros: Generous PTO, casual dress work environment, travel benefits

review_title: Might be good for a first job but not much growth opportunity
pros: I worked in AMEX for four years right after my PHD studies. My first year experience was good, second year was ok, in my third year I was trying to get out and in the fourth year I couldn't take it anymore and was ready to accept any job offer outside the company. The pros is you can learn some basics about cards business and there are lots of young people, so if you are a young person you would like it. There are lots of employee activities and you can participate in any of them provided that you complete your work on time. There is also an Asian Employee network.
cons: The culture there requires you to find a place to transfer internally after a couple of years. If you cannot find a place then you would be stuck there for a while and do things that create no value for your career and the company. The management looks democratic but actually similar to dictatorship. There is too much politics going on there and there are many very talented, knowledgeable people who have never been promoted because of all these politics. Do not expect to climb the ladder in AMEX unless you are a minority or know someone in high position.  The pay is very low for New York City standards but since most people commute from NJ this is not a big issue. You work with internal business partners and their bad opinion about you counts but good opinions are ignored most of the time. If you have low rating because your boss thinks that way, you are given some time to correct your performance but I never witnessed anyone who went through the process and able to keep his job. In other words if they don't like you for any reason -non work related, they find a way to send you away.

review_title: Unfair treatment of one department over another

review_title: Canadian organization is an after-thought of the US organization which Canada is so tightly bound to.

review_title: Life at American Express
pros:
All my work experience has been in just 2 companies. So my review is based on my limited exposure and what I have heard from other sources (including the various interviews I have faced).
-Good starting salary which is above the general trend.
-One of the few companies that have 8.5 hrs shift.
-Good work culture. Better than most other companies.
-Easy to have a good work life balance.
-Number of training programs.
-Good infrastructure. Feels good to be there. (This should not be ignored while considering a job change. I found this to my peril. Went to the second company and the surroundings there, left me disappointed from the very first day). There are few companies which have better or equivalent facilities and what Herzberg called the Hygiene factors. E&Y is one example. Went there for an interview. Good package plus very good infrastructure.
-Management quite friendly.
-Very quickly one gets used to the company. To me it was like second home. Used to feel very comfortable there. Even if the job's not to one's liking you feel like going there.
- It is a testament to these facts that AMEX is usually in the top ten in India in terms of employee satisfaction.
cons:
-As mentioned one gets used to AMEX and then moving on becomes exceedingly tough especially if the next company is not in the same league.
-Everyone working there or going there might not agree to my views as it's my experience and what I felt personally. Somebody with more experience in more companies may not agree or may not find AMEX so agreeable.
-Again it is, at the end of the day, a place of work, a firm on a contractual relationship with thousands of employees. Whilst better in many ways it still has the other issues usually found at companies. To a lesser extent but yes they are there. The company is far from being a Semco like company which I feel, based on what I've read, is an ideal place.

review_title: as a newbie, id say that experience is great

It has a great cafeteria, pool tables, table tennis, and fuse ball. Beautiful professional people with smiles on there face.
cons: Bonuses takes a long time to come in (2-3 months), and bonus amount can change every month.

Resources

review_title: Work/Life Balance
job_title: Senior Manager in New York, NY
pros: AmEx has a great work culture with leaders that focus on hard work, but also stress the importance of family.  It's a company that realizes that burning out employees reduces productivity and increases turnover.
cons: A couple of Cons are that compensation is decent, not great.  Also, while movement is encouraged it is difficult to move without politics getting in the way.

review_title: Product Owner for Mobile
pros: The culture is great and fosters a clear path to career development. Highly collaborative, which could end up being a handicap, but everyone is supportive. Enterprise Growth is a fantastic place to work for if you are driven and want to build new things.
cons: Like any corporate company things can take too long to get done. Also, people like to pass the buck and decisions happen to get done by committee a lot.

review_title: Good company if you enjoy politics and mediocrity
pros: Decent salary and benefits. Stable job if you can keep up with frustration working in slow and chaotic environment.
cons:
Company has too much of bureaucracy. Too many people working since last 20, 30 or 40 years and don't want to change. Company culture is to keep everyone happy than get the actual work done. Employee/contractor ratio is around 30%/70%, so employees are only supposed to only manage contractors and not do any work. This adds up huge costs to any development/maintenance activities and creates very high political environment. 
Year end bonus system is very contentious and creates toxic environment. Top 5% employees get 5-10 times more bonus than rest of 85%. This makes people not to collaborate, not to share knowledge and not to respect colleagues in the same team. Everybody is more concerned about what the best about them they can put in the year end paper. Leaders look at only the individual contribution and not at how this person helped the whole team.
Experienced employees are expert enough to take advantage and steal the ideas from new and naive employees and present to senior management since they have better network. Promotions are non existent which in turn makes environment more frustrating and good bonus is the only way to make more money. 

If you are looking for collaborative, challenging and productive environment, this is definitely not a place for you. If you want a stable, average paying job, willing to put up with ugly politics and deceptive colleagues, not want much growth in your career, you will enjoy this place.

review_title: People are great, Politics are beyond comprehension in a bad spot
pros: Smart individuals and great culture except for a select few
cons: There are employees that are very "AmEx-ized", resulting in no career development or support. I was given excellent year-end ratings and feedback, only to have the same people tell me I'm not ready for a promotion and sabotage me from interviewing with other teams (who wanted me to interview for positions which would've been a promotion for me).

review_title: Credit/Current Accounts
pros: Great training to start.  Benefits are good.  If you get the right manager, you can go far.
cons: The odds of getting and keeping a great manager are slim to none.  You will hear loads of talk about your career and moving up within the ranks, but it is mostly talk.  Dynamic leaders are crushed by upper management in the credit department and the only managers that seem to get anywhere are the ones who can effectively eliminate the employees who haves lost their way or have become trapped in their role.  Not good enough to promote (the promotion decisions consistently confused many employees where I worked) but  good enough for Target practice when the environment changes.  Incentive pay calculations constantly change, up to several times per year - could earn a 2K monthly bonus in October, have the same performance in November, might get $300, if any, because of the "re alignment".  Single track counseling: if you get to a level two or three, you're doomed.  You can't apply anywhere for up to a year after getting off counseling, and you have a black mark on your record forever, regardless of what they tell you. Also one of the most frustratingly political companies I've ever worked for.  Diversity is celebrated, but if you are conservative, straight laced and " vanilla" you will probably be overlooked.

review_title: Team Leader
pros: American Express promotes a healthy, professional, stable, and innovative culture with a huge focus on being number one in customer service.  American Express is very good about ensuring proper training for each employee within their respective roles. There are plenty of advancement opportunities within a large network of business units as long as you work hard and focus on development, there
cons: The only con would be along the lines of the numerous reductions in force.  Understood that it is a necessary step in continued growth.

review_title: Great Company but low pay
pros: the company has excellent benefits and work-life balance. I was there for over 15 years and enjoyed it very much. The work was challenging and I felt I was significantly contributing.
cons: Low pay. Even if I got a 1 review it was only a 5-6% raise. I could never bring up salary because leadership basically took the position there is nothing they can do.

review_title: "L is for Likeability Not-Leadership"
pros: Work Life Balance, Generous PTO Allowance, Decent Health Benefits and Life Insurance, Tuition reimbursement.
cons:
Micro Management, Constant witch hunts, less than stellar incentives, pay for performance is unfairly measured and you are held accountable to "others" outcomes for the Customer Experience which holds the greatest weighting for incentives. Forget trying to rebut or ask for a reassignment of assessments that clearly belong to others - you will not be successful. Directors, Managers and Some Team Leaders do not understand the front line personal/position/balance/discussions/call backs to card members and you are targeted for call handle time - since upper management does not want you to research for the card members. 
Upper Management also should reconsider their "Targeting" of employees to falsely term based on their personal bias and not true performance.  If you stay in the box - and suck it up - agree with management - you will go far in this company after all it is political and L truly does mean likability!

review_title: Great place to work
job_title: Lead Programmer in Cedar Park, TX

review_title: Decent place, but not what it used to be

review_title: Great Benefits but Competitive

review_title: Not bad - would not turn it into a career

cons: This particular position has a low retention rate. They change the pay structure very frequently and it never benefits the consultant. The location of the office is quite far. You have to wait 18 months before switching roles. Micromanagement does happen.

review_title: Disappointed and disillusioned
job_title: Virtual PCP in West Palm Beach, FL
pros: The starting salary and incentives are high and you can make good money if you can tolerate the hours and the team leaders
cons: Training program, it’s really a sales position Scheduled hours are not by seniority and the schedule times do not allow for a work / life balance. Competitive environment

review_title: A good company to work for in tough times, but improvements are needed!
pros: The best reasons to work for American Express are  the benefits, opportunities and skillbuilding.
cons: The downsides of working for American Express are inconsistencies with dealing with policies and procedures, scheduling, vacation request policies, lack of proper training, lack of communication from management.

review_title: If the people make the company then American Express is in trouble.
pros: The opportunity to work with diverse cultures.  We routinely speak with people in India, England and Mexico.  We regularly work with people in New York and Florida.
cons: Everywhere there are people in jobs they aren't qualified for.  Usually it's because the organization or job has changed a lot but management is too afraid to get rid of the people that haven't kept up.  People were promoted before they were ready.  We've outsourced jobs to very unqualified people.

review_title: Good name for your resume, but thats about it
job_title: Associate Brand Manager in Toronto, ON
pros:

- entry-level employees are young, bright, generally lots of fun
cons:
- the Brand Managers (who are responsible for specific products and who manage the ABMs) are generally unremarkable

- execution rather than strategy focused role

review_title: Remember Talent

review_title: Good resume builder but very political
pros: Compensation was adequate, and opportunities for advancement were available for those looking to take on extra responsibilities. Additionally, there is still some cachet behind the Amex brand, which makes it a great stepping stone into other opportunities outside of the company.
cons: Very political force-ranking review system. At the end of each year all members of the pay band above you meet to force rank employees as a class and determine merit increases and bonuses. E.g. All managers meet to rank their direct reports against those of other managers, all Directors meet to rank the managers on their team against the other managers in the company and apply ratings on a bell curve. The bell curve provides prescriptive guidance for merit increases and bonuses. In many cases, the merit increase and bonus (where applicable) for an employee is not determined by their individual contribution, or measured against a yard stick. Instead, the force ranking system leads to less than idea outcomes based on the ability and desire of a given leader to influence his/her peers during the rating session. As a leader, this can lead to strange conversations with your direct reports - In some cases a direct report will receive a middle of the road rating simply because of their position on the bell curve, while the leader can provide no specific guidance for improvement. In other cases, employees who would have been rated poorly by their managers were instead lifted into the median rate and provided with a raise and bonus while the leader has to deliver the message that they are not performing up to par, but will be compensated as if they are.

review_title: AAC Claim Adjuster

review_title: Not so bad not so good
job_title: Industrial Engineer in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros:
The best pro is the resources you have, the company aims to have the latest technology for the people to succeed. Also, the people, you get to work with very talented and smart individuals. Finally, if you work hard and deliver climbing positions (up to the Director level) is relatively easy. Depending on your team your work and contribution will make sense and you will be actually able to see (and even use) what you created. Also, at least in the engineering dept, senior leaders try their best to showcase their vision to their teams so everybody is clear on what is the objective and what is expected to achieve.

In terms of benefits, PTO is the best perk, you get plenty of it and basically are free to take it whenever you want. Also the tuition reimbursement and health insurance is ok, it is not very expensive, has good coverage but the deductible is high. 

Salary-wise I believe is not bad to be honest, could be better, but not bad.
cons:
If I say it’s people in the Pros I need to say it’s people in the cons as well. There are plenty of unprepared, with lack of vision tenured employees, which makes everyone’s life harder. Their unwillingness to help and support other teams is exhaustive to a point that people quit because of this (even me constantly thinking about it) it is an inexplicable level of laziness, that basically shames everyone else in the enterprise. I would say the constitute maybe 20-30% of the workforce, hopefully in some years this isn’t a problem anymore as I know that amex is trying to hire talented and prepared individuals. Believe me when I tell you that dealing with people who are there just for a paycheck and nothing else is EXHAUSTIVE.

Then after this is bureaucracy, you may lose days, weeks and even months getting alignment on next steps on projects.  I have been in a situation that I had basically nothing to do on a day just waiting on an email to come back and proceed (thankfully for the company I always try to keep myself busy helping others) This makes this move slow, the amount of time wasted on formalities is unmeasurable, and some times you don’t even know what is the purpose of what you’re doing. Such as having to run an analysis 2-3 times because leadership wanted to be very sure, leading to the conclusion that they don’t have courage to take risks.

review_title: Why to join and why not to join
pros:
1. Great infrastructure and facilities. One of the best in the industry.
2. Leaders working since last 5 or more years are the best people to work with. You will learn a lot from them which will eventually make you a better person.
cons:
1. Since their cost cutting initiatives have started from last 2 years, they’ve started hiring leaders from outside which are paid handsome amount but doing cheap tactics to save cost. Feels like a typical 3rd party BPO environment now. Even people working from more than 5 years feel the same.
2. Agent level jobs are most unsecure now since automation has kicked in most of the processes. You will not be sure when you’re going to be kicked out. I was part of a batch which was laid off suddenly without any notification as we were no longer required in the process. I don’t blame the company here, but the leadership team. Most of the lay offs are happening in India only as they have their one of the biggest offices outside US in India only.
I myself saw at least 4 top executives from executive board leaving after almost 15-20 years of career because of some or other reason just after cost optimisation started.
3. Now, a project that can be handled by 8 people if they work 9 hrs a day, is being done by 2-3 people on,y by working at least 12hrs a day. Work life balance has gone for a toss here especially back office operations. They are facing the maximum lay offs. If you’re working in back office in any line of business, your job is not secure anymore in Amex.

American Express on Thursday became the latest iconic American firm to announce major layoffs triggered by the worst economic crisis in seven decades, unveiling plans to slash 7,000 employees.
Highlighting that even some of the most creditworthy and wealthiest Americans are having trouble paying their bills, American Express said that it is cutting 10% of its staff, suspending management salary increases and instituting a hiring freeze. See related MarketWatch First Take commentary. 
American Express, a component in the Dow Jones Industrial average, is following moves by other major firms like Hewlett Packard, Goldman Sachs, Whirlpool, and Yahoo, which have all recently announced layoffs of 5% to 10% of their staff. 
So far this month, Goldman has said it would cut 3,200 jobs, Whirlpool dropped the axe on 5,000 staff, Yahoo cut 1,000 positions, and Hewlett unveiled a stunning 24,000 job losses. 
And, while full details are unclear, analysts at Keefe Bruyette & Woods said earlier this week that probably about half of Lehman Brothers worldwide staff of about 26,000 employees, 10,000 of whom are inside the U.S., would lose their jobs after the company went bankrupt earlier this year. Barclays has acquired Lehman's U.S. brokerage business, and Nomura acquired parts of Lehman's Europe and Asia operations.

- Good amount of leaves, certain processes allow WFH
- Your skills (if you are good at your job) would be recognised much quickly then your office politics game (every office has some amount of it)
- IJPs are open all the time if you are stuck in a profile you dont like, keep applying you'll find something better
cons: hmmm...not too many, although Amex is a paymaster when it comes to external hires, internal promotions do not come with a big hike...those are just ok

review_title: Great Company - Choose Division Carefully
pros: The benefits are great and the array of what you are eligible for is impressive.
cons: Having an open office with out any sound barriers makes it difficult to focus, pay increases are non existent - you're lucky to get a 2% every year and the culture is generally passive aggressive. Mid-level leadership is inconsistent - junior level VPs don't get a lot of support and are often a barrier to improvements.

review_title: This job is for peole who want to sit and be monitored around all day for a slightly higher paycheck.
job_title: Customer Care Professional in Greensboro, NC
pros: The reputation of the company is really good. I worked in their phone center though and it is very different form the rest of American Express.
cons: Being tied to the telephone and not able to have the freedom to walk around. Customers were rude over the phone. Requesting time off was hard especially calling in sick. The penalty system is a 3 strikes and your out, and the strikes could be breaing any of the thousands of rules they have.

review_title: Great place to work despite areas for improvement
job_title: Senior Vice President  in New York, NY
pros: Excellent Brand; unlimited opportunities to learn; really bright and motivated colleagues; strong vision; market-leading products; recognition of the importance of talent
cons: Still somewhat political; management conforms to a somewhat "Stepford" standard of behavior that can inhibit creativity and innovation (and opportunties for those who don't fit the mold); matrix too complex and disruptive; gender diversity in senior management still a somewhat elusive goal

review_title: Solid place to work but recent layoffs leave me questioning the integrity of Senior Mgmt
job_title: Marketing Director in New York, NY
pros:
People are great - smart, nice, talented, lots of integrity
Generous vacation time
cons:
Salary is not great
You spend too much time bldg PowerPoint presentations and not enough time adding "real" value to the company
Pretty political environment - a lot is about who you know, how you position things, and what "wins" you grab for yourself

review_title: Good for intermediate level technical roles, but little room to grow beyond
job_title: Senior Programmer Analyst in Phoenix, AZ
pros:
Work is pretty easy, lots of BAU work
Large company, which means there is room to laterally move around
Good if you want to move into a managerial role
Telecommuting possible
cons:
Lots of red tape
Soft skills (politics) valued much higher than technical competency
Very few highly technical positions, which means advancement peaks early
Teams usually consist of 80% contractors and 20% employees

review_title: Great Company with plenty of opportunies and advancement
job_title: Finance Manager in New York, NY
pros:
Opportunity for Growth
Advance Training Offered
Development is important
cons:
VERY POLITICAL
It is mostly about who you know
People use you to get a job or information

review_title: Great brand, interesting work but poor compensation
pros:
* Work for a great, premium brand.   
* Everyone is "nice" - a phenom that is not always prevalent in NYC firms.
* Work can be interesting and challenging
* Work life balance can be very good, depending on your role and leader(s).
cons:
* Compensation is not competitve.  Salaries and bonuses are below market average and raises are small.
* Work life balance can be very bad depending on your role and leader(s).

review_title: Home Based CCP agents
job_title: Customer Care Representative in Hartford, CT
pros: Great pay and benefits. Wonderful health packages.
cons: Call taking week 3 with out full training. Customers not referring company to a friend in surveys  count against you.

review_title: Great Company to work for
job_title: Business Development Executive in Markham, ON
pros:
Leadership has a real focus on Career Goals and Development planning
Invests in their employees with training opportunites
cons: Recent re-engineering efforts has put more work onto middle managers and staff making it difficult to deliver on all goals and maintain work life balance. So much process behind everything makes it hard to maintain energy and take risks.

review_title: Great learning experience, tough to break through late in a career.
job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros:
Really smart people.
They treat people very well.
Financially generous.  
Great resources available to be able to really exceed.
Great emphasis on work/life balance.
Opportunities to work remotely.
cons: As someone who didn't grown up through the ranks at American Express, I found it challenging to become part of the "inner circle."  Most people that are life long employees are always thinking about their net move and take the safe route with programs.  It could be a more collaborative environment.

review_title: My experience with American Express has been great. The people are nice and the work has been engaging.
job_title: Director of Product Management in New York, NY
pros: Good culture, good work life balance. Company is completely focused on delivering great customer service. Leadership is pretty smart. Challenging and you learn a lot. A lot of opportunities to move across functions or to specialize. Good leadership is extremely valued in managers.
cons: Very hierarchical. Compensation isn't great.  Promotions aren't easy. Way too many meetings and alignment  before a decision could be taken.

review_title: Nice OK
pros: It's not terrible.  There are desks and chairs and cubicles and you might even get a laptop.  There are tall people, short people, men and women.
cons: There are not enough kittens.  Also there's too many managers and kind of a lot of beauracracy.  Some management teams are extremely against working from home for inexplicable reasons considering the fact that the infrastructure is provided and there's not enough physical space for the department in the building

review_title: Good benefits and culture. Work-life balance
job_title: Senior Manager in New York, NY
pros: flexible work schedules, family friendly benefits, opportunities for advancement. Friendly people who are smart and driven. Good culture for personal development.
cons: Relationships matter almost too much when going for promotions, it becomes about who you know rather than the merit of your work. This means when jobs are posted internally there usually is already a candidate "on deck" and the posting is just to abide by the official policy.

review_title: In most cases, great management and Leaders!
job_title: Account Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: Dedicated workforce, leadership is very good.  In the 9 years I have worked for American Express I have only encountered 1 leader where I wondered how he got his job (he was incompetent).  Work/Life balance usually good, but this depends on your leader and organization. Great group of people.
cons: Pay is not up to market level standards.  I know if I went out of the company I most likely would do better.  Career opportunities are limited if you are in the field.

review_title: AWESOME JOB
job_title: Travel Consultant in Home Gardens, CA
pros: Great pay, work from comfort of my home, no boss or micromanagement, excellent benefits, friendly staff, self paced work.
cons: sometimes it can be hard to get help when you need it working from home because everything is  on IM so training is tough but once you graduate you are on  your way

review_title: Amex IT - Leaning Towards LEAN IT SHOP
job_title: Senior Technology Project Manager in Plantation, FL
pros: Good Benefits, Good corporate brand name to have on your resume.
cons: Low Salary, no work-life balance, 60+ hrs per week on IT side of house. Focus on LEAN IT and cost avoidance / optimization has impacted quality and will ultimately customer experience.  Off-shore models too aggressive.   Considerable segregation between FTEs and Contractors.

review_title: Amex Review
pros: Brand and product recognition, work life balance programs, opportunities for internal promotion are abundant, for a Wall Street organization, the corporate culture is relaxed and the majority of people are nice, hard working, and open to collaboration.
cons: The normal cons of a big corporation: silos, politics to get leadership approval, constant re-orgs, high levels of bureaucracy and non-value added processes. Leaders take forever to make decisions

review_title: You'll succeed here if you're part of the good ol boys club
pros: Very generous PTO, fitness center and wellness centers on site, on site cafeteria
cons: Health benefits are a joke with high deductibles that continue to increase each year. Doesn't matter if you report sexual harassment or sexual assault, as long as you don't go public with it, they don't care about your well-being. The classic over-worked and under-appreciated scenario, no matter how many times you show your hard work.  Unless you're part of the good ol boys club. You'll get a raise and promotion. They definitely don't live up to their so-called "Blue Box values."

review_title: Could be better, could be worse...
pros:
- virtual positions are plentiful
 - depending on department/leader you have the freedom to do your job
 - ok salary, ok benefits
 - supports work/life balance
cons:
- too much work, not enough people
 - everything is a priority
 -  very siloed and complex company structure.  a lot of duplication of efforts
 - some business units are very myopic

review_title: Good Company.  Advancement Difficult
pros: Good work life balance.  Friendly environment with supportive workers.  Variety of roles you can take and learn from to develop yourself and build your own expertise.
cons: Consensus culture can limit ability to get decisions made and implemented (if act decisively, not seen as a team player, or stepping on toes).  Reaching higher levels (Director/VPs) difficult to achieve given strong bench of talent and limited opportunities.

review_title: Good industrial exposure
pros: The work tests my abilities gained from my university and let me test my strengths. the way i apply my creativity to deal with the work makes it more fun
cons: there are no scope of learning new Computer technologies from computer engineer point of view, although good place to know everything related to IT dealing with financial sector

review_title: Long Career At American Express
job_title: Director, Business Development in New York, NY
pros: Lots of opportunities to grow your career.  Lots of flexibility to find the right role for your long term objectives.  Promotions are merit based.  Work life balance is exceptional.  Core credit card business is exceptionally well run.
cons: Huge corporate bureaucracy and meeting based culture means getting things done is challenging.  Pay is below competition  and longevity at American Express means your pay will fall significantly below your peers, thus poaching from top banks is rampant

review_title: customer care professional
job_title: Customer Care Representative in Phoenix, AZ
pros: it is a large company with a lot of oportunities to move around between departments. the phoenix campus is large enough to have some decent amenities ie cafiteria, small fun room, small cardio fitness room.
cons: a lot of the departments in phoenix are being shipped to india. there have been a lot of lay offs within the last couple years. the management in my business unit treated people like a number and not like the experience you hear from other business units at amex

review_title: REVIEW FOR YOUR FAVORITE CARD COMPANY WHAT WORKING HERE IS REALLY LIKE.....
pros:
-great people
-diverse culture
-flexible work arrangements
cons:
-health benefits could be better
-people are sometimes afraid to speak up and want to keep up "appearances"
-some leaders need people management training 101 as in they have the knowledge to do the work but lack the people skills
-you can land your next role on who you know and not what you know
-your band level defines who you are
-constant restructuring and unstability

review_title: mediocre at best!
pros:
*established player in the market
*strong brand
*work-life balance
cons:
*too large to "pviot" or innovate
*too much regulations
*too much politics
*too few positions from middle-management upward
*pay is low
*some standout leaders and staff, but too few to feel inspired
*more of a marketing company than financial services
*apparent gap (in age and generation) between upper management and those doing the work

review_title: Financial Analyst
pros: Great company to start your career and lots of opportunities to learn best business practises
cons: Politically correct culture. Only people who belong to the inner circle of friends of Sr. leaders gets promoted regardless of skillset and education. This practice has really exiled a lot of talent and adversely impacted the company's bottom line in a huge way.

review_title: Getting from bad to worst
pros: Good training.. Development program. A lot of activities and fun things happening.
cons: Employees made to put on show/performance whenever there is visitor. Feel like we are entertainers. Even told by my team leader that we have to be mindful when having any skip level. Felt suppressed.. And Not sure why travelling still happening when company keep talking about cutting cost.

review_title: Business Development
job_title: Specialist, Business Development in Toronto, ON
pros: Great Work Environment, Managers were also wonderful to work with. The company fostered a learning environment as well. I would recommend working there.
cons: Very hard to make it past two years in a sales role at AMEX.  The market is also very competitive, so the brand name American Express, doesn't resonate as much as it use to.

review_title: Great company, currently poor leadership in Commercial Payments unit.
job_title: Sales Manager in Frankfurt am Main
pros: Great product, great reputation, great talents. In Germany currently only the Merchant Services is a great place to work where the leadership truly lives the Amex corporate values.
cons: Poor leadership in B2B payment area of Commercial Payments. Sales team has to follow predefined unsuccessful approach since years. Leadership in Germany not courageous enough to trust its sales team.

review_title: Constantly Unsettled
pros: Benefits, Time off, and Hours.
cons:
I've been here a year, and the company seems in constant state of flux when it comes to state of each department (which also means the feeling of job security never really sinks in). Within four months of being hired, we found out they were outsourcing our division. Rough way to start.

Also, many positions aren't exactly how they are presented.

review_title: Good benefits. Lots of politics and red tape.
pros: Good benefits that come with working for a large company.
cons: Departments don't work well together. Hard to navigate who you need to talk to to get stuff done. VERY political. Lots of red tape and inefficiencies. People are totally focused on what they can put on their annual review. But that is a useless process. Your review is already determined by who likes you or who you have pissed off. Rub someone the wrong way and you are done.

review_title: American Express
pros: Benefits are great - you work your tail off but can work virtually a few days per week. Amex even offers a child backup care option in each major US city if your nanny is suddenly unavailable. Very global jobs and organization along with diversity of employees.
cons: YOY re-orgs and new team structure which can result in inefficiency and loss of momentum. Great upward mobility as long as you are in the NY HQ. If you are not, you will not progress much after a certain point in your career.

review_title: Great work-life balance with a culture that promotes development.
job_title: Marketing Manager in New York, NY
pros: Your leaders are empowered to help you grow. Upper management pays attention to the pulse of the their teams and strives to provide a pleasant working environment. Some teams have the flexibility to work from home a few days a week.
cons: Big corporate machine is not as nimble to get products and creatives to market. There tends to be a passive aggressive undertone that is present all around the company.

review_title: Great culture and robust leadership
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Very people centric organization, you can build a career here with the right sponsorship. It is encouraged to look internally for roles that enable professional growth
cons: Slow moving or you can say that every decision is very thoughtfully made which leads to lags and delays. If you do not have the right sponsors in the company, you cannot move forward.

review_title: Endless Opportunities + Amazing Benefits
job_title: Business Analyst in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: Offer experiences and training to grow my career and a  positive culture to make work life enjoyable. The benefits are by far the BEST!
cons: Salaries are on "band levels" which are set in place to be fair so I understand that aspect around equal pay, however the ranges within the band levels vary so much.

review_title: Simply the Best!
job_title: Interim Learning Specialist in Sunrise, FL
pros: I have never encountered a company that made me feel so welcome and inspired from day one! All of the employees really do act as one big family and are quick to help you  succeed without hesitation.
cons: There really are not any cons that I can think of in working at American Express. You are the captain of your own ship/ career so your experience really depends on you and what you want to achieve.

review_title: Winners Stay Away
job_title: Director of Marketing in New York, NY
pros: Laid back atmosphere. Job for life type environment.
cons: Very few people have fire in the belly.
